1-4B-3: VIOLATION:
It shall be an automated traffic law violation for a vehicle to disregard a
traffic control device by entering an intersection against a steady or flashing
red signal indication in violation of Section 11306 of the Illinois Vehicle
Code, 625 ILCS 5/1 1-306, as captured on recorded images by an automated
traffic law enforcement system. (Ord. 19-41, 8-6-2019)
1-4B-4: SIGNAGE:
Any intersection equipped with an automated traffic law enforcement system must
have a sign posted which is visible to approaching traffic indicating that the
intersection is being monitored by an automated traffic law enforcement system.
(Ord. 19-41, 8-6-2019)
1-4B-5: NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
   A.   In the event an automated traffic law enforcement system records an
automated traffic law violation, which shall be deemed a non-criminal violation
for which a civil penalty of One Hundred and Dollars ($100) shall be assessed
and for which no points shall be assigned by the State of Illinois motor
vehicle code point system for license suspension to the owner or driver of the
vehicle. the Village shall issue a written notice of the violation to the
registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, which shall be mailed by first class
mail within thirty (30) days after the Illinois Secretary of State notifies the
Village of the identity of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, and
in no event later than ninety (90) days following the violation, except that in
the case of a lessee of a motor vehicle, service of an automated traffic law
violation notice may occur no later than two hundred ten (210) days after the
violation. The Village shall only be required to notify a lessee if the leasing
company/lessor provides the lessee’s name by an affidavit and a copy of the
lease within sixty (60) days of the original notice’s issuance. If the driver
information is not provided within sixty (60) days, the leasing company/lessor
may be found liable. If any notice to an address is returned as undeliverable,
a second notice shall be sent to the last known address recorded in a United
States Post Office approved database of the owner or lessee of the cited
vehicle. The second notice shall be made by first class mail postage prepaid.
Service of such notices shall be deemed complete as of the date of deposit in
the United States mail.
   B.   Each notice of violation associated with an automated traffic law
violation shall require a review of the associated recorded image by a law
enforcement officer or retired law enforcement officer of the Village Police
Department to determine whether a violation has occurred or whether one of the
defenses enumerated below in Section
1-4B-11 is visibly applicable upon inspection. Upon determination that the
recorded image captures a violation and that no defense applies, the notice of
violation shall be served upon the registered vehicle owner or lessee in the
manner provided for above. The Traffic Compliance Administrator, or his or her
designee, shall retain a copy of all violation notices, recorded images and
other correspondence mailed to the alleged violator.
   C.   Based on inspection of the recorded images produced by the automated
traffic law enforcement system, each notice of violation shall constitute
evidence of the facts contained in the notice, is admissible in any proceeding
alleging an automated traffic law violation under Section
1-4B-3, and shall establish prima facie evidence of a violation, subject to
rebuttal on the basis of the defenses established in Section
1-4B-11.
   D.   Each notice of violation shall include the information required by law,
and such other information as the Village may determine, such as following:
      1.   The name and address of the registered owner or lessee of the
vehicle, as indicated by the records of the Secretary of State, or, if such
information is outdated or unattainable, then the last known address recorded
in a United States Post Office approved database;
      2.   The registration number of the motor vehicle involved in the
violation;
      3.   The vehicle make, if available and readily discernible;
      4.   The violation charged;
      5.   The location where the violation occurred;
      6.   The date and time of the violation;
      7.   A copy of the recorded images;
      8.   A website address, accessible through the internet, where the
violator may review the recorded images of the violation;
      9.   A statement that the violator may elect to proceed by paying the
civil penalty or challenging the alleged violation in an administrative hearing
or by mail (if a non-resident) or, following the administrative hearing, in
court;
      10.   The date, time and place of the administrative hearing at which the
charge may be contested on its merits, a date that shall be no less than 15
days from the mailing or other service of the first notice of violation;
      11.   The amount of the civil penalty imposed and the date by which the
civil penalty should be paid if liability for the violation is not going to be
contested;
      12.   A statement that a failure to pay the civil penalty by the date
noted may result in an additional late fee being assessed against the owner or
lessee, and the amount of the late fee;
      13.   A statement that the recorded images are evidence of a violation of
a red light signal;
      14.   A warning that failure to either pay the civil penalty or contest
liability in a timely manner is an admission of liability and may result in a
suspension of the driving privileges of the registered owner or lessee of the
vehicle in addition to the specified penalties for failing to contest liability
or to pay the civil penalty in advance of the hearing;
      15.   A statement that payment of the indicated civil penalty and of any
applicable penalty for late payment shall constitute a final disposition of the
violation; and
      16.   The signature and identification number of the party reviewing the
recorded images and confirming that a violation took place. (Ord. 19-41, 8-6-
2019)
1-4B-6: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION:
The Village may utilize its existing personnel and system of administrative
adjudication for vehicular standing and parking violations, and violations
regarding the display of municipal stickers/licenses, for the adjudication of
automated traffic law violations, consistent with this Article and as specified
in Article 1-4A. (Ord. 19-41, 8-6-2019)
1-4B-7: HEARINGS:
Administrative hearings on automated traffic law violations shall be conducted
in conformance with Article 1-4A of this Code. A failure of the motor vehicle
owner or lessee of a vehicle to appear at the hearing will result in a finding
of liability. In the event of a failure to appear, a determination of liability
shall be sent to the owner or lessee. The owner or lessee’s failure to pay the
amount by the date specified in the determination of liability shall result in
a final determination upon either denial of a timely petition to set aside that
determination, or upon expiration of the period for filing the petition without
a filing having been made. Administrative hearings on automated traffic law
violations shall be audio recorded, and the Hearing Officer shall conduct the
hearing in accordance with his or her powers and duties, enumerated herein and
in Article 1-4A of this Code. The Hearing Officer shall enter either a default
judgement or determination of liability or non-liability in accordance with
consideration of the facts and testimony, if any, and shall constitute a final
determination of liability from which an appeal may be taken. (Ord. 19-41, 8-6-
2019)
1-4B-8: FINAL DETERMINATION OF LIABILITY, NOTICE OF FINAL DETERMINATION OF
LIABILITY, NOTICE OF IMPENDING SUSPENSION:
   A.   Notices of determination of liability shall be sent in conformance with
the general mailing provisions in Article 1-4A of this Code.
   B.   Final determinations of violation liability shall occur pursuant to the
provisions set forth in Article 1-4A of this Code.
   C.   Notices of final determination of liability shall be sent in
conformance with Article 1-4A of this Code.
   D.   Notices of impending suspension of a person’s driver’s license shall be
sent in conformance with Section
7-2-102(B) of this Code. (Ord. 19-41, 8-6-2019)
1-4B-9: PETITIONS TO SET ASIDE DETERMINATION:
A petition to set aside determination of violation liability may be filed by a
person in the manner and subject to the restrictions and grounds as set forth
in Section
1-4A-7 of this Code, along with the following grounds:
   A.   The person against whom the determination of liability is made was not
the owner or lessee of the “cited vehicle” on the date the vehicular standing,
parking, or compliance regulation violation notice was issued.
   B.   The person’s having paid the fine or penalty prior to the determination
of liability for the violation in question. (Ord. 19-41, 8-6-2019)
1-4B-10: PENALTY:
   A.   The motor vehicle owner or lessee of a vehicle found to have committed
an automated traffic law violation is subject to a civil penalty of one hundred
dollars ($100).
   B.   If the civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100) referred to in
Subsection A. above is not timely paid or the Notice of Violation is not
contested timely, a One Hundred Dollar ($100) late payment penalty will be
assessed in addition to the original One Hundred Dollar ($100) penalty by way
of “Final Determination of Liability.”
   C.   The Village may establish procedures for the collection of the civil
penalty imposed. (Ord. 19-41, 8-6-2019)
1-4B-11: DEFENSES:
The hearing officer may consider only the defenses set forth below when offered
by an alleged violator contesting his or her liability for an automated traffic
law violation. The defenses shall be weighed by the hearing officer and shall
only rebut the prima facie case established by the notice of liability insofar
as one or more defenses are established by a preponderance of the evidence:
   A.   The motor vehicle or registration plates were stolen before the
violation occurred and were not under the control of or in the possession of
the owner at the time of the violation. This defense may be demonstrated
through the submission of a certified copy of a report concerning the stolen
motor vehicle or registration plates was filed with a law enforcement agency in
a timely manner;
   B.   The vehicle was an authorized emergency vehicle;
   C.   The driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection when the
light was red either to yield the right-of-way to an emergency vehicle or as
part of a funeral procession;
   D.   The facts alleged in the Notice of Violation are inconsistent or do not
support a finding that a violation occurred;
   E.   The operator of the vehicle received a Uniform Traffic citation from a
police officer at the time of the violation for the same incident as captured
by the automated traffic law enforcement system and either paid such citation
or successfully contested said citation;
   F.   The vehicle was leased to another and within sixty (60) calendar days
after the citation was mailed to lessor, lessor submitted to the municipality
the correct name and address of the lessee of the vehicle identified in this
Notice of Violation at the time of the alleged violation, together with a copy
of the lease agreement, the lessee’s driver’s license number and any additional
information that may be needed; or
   G.   The respondent was not the registered vehicle owner, lessee or renter
of the cited vehicle at the time of the violation. (Ord. 19-41, 8-6-2019)
1-4B-12: NON-RESIDENTS:
Where the registered owner or lessee of the cited vehicle is not a resident of
the Village, but seeks to contest the merits of an alleged automated traffic
law violation, the registered owner or lessee of the cited vehicle may contest
the violation using the same available defenses in Section
1-4B-11, and the same procedures, by either attending an administrative
hearing, or by submitting documentary evidence no later than the hearing date
referenced in the notice of liability, together with a written statement
reflecting that they are non-residents of the Village. (Ord. 19-41, 8-6-2019)
CHAPTER 5
OFFICIAL AND CORPORATE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
1-5-1: Corporate Seal, Official Logo And Village Flag
1-5-2: Elections
1-5-3: Electronic Attendance At Meetings
1-5-4: Indemnification Of Village Officials
1-5-5: Rules Concerning Public Comment And Participation
1-5-1: CORPORATE SEAL, OFFICIAL LOGO AND VILLAGE FLAG:
   A.   Corporate Seal: The corporate seal of the village shall be as follows:
A disc, circular in form, with the words "Village of Berkeley, Inc. May 20,
1924, Cook Co., IL".
   B.   Official Logo: The logo on file in the office of the village clerk and
displayed on the village website is hereby adopted as the official logo of the
village for all municipal purposes. The use of the logo for any private
commercial purpose without prior approval by the village board of trustees is
hereby prohibited.
   C.   Private Use Prohibitions:
      1.   Flags And Emblems: It shall be unlawful for any person to use the
village flag, standard, pennant, any village badge, or any imitation or design
thereof without the prior approval of the village board of trustees, except for
the usual and customary purposes of decoration or display. No person shall
print or stamp thereon or cause to be displayed thereon any letter, word,
legend or device not provided for in this section.
      2.   Corporate Seal Or Official Logo: No person shall fraudulently forge,
deface, corrupt or counterfeit the corporate seal or any official logo of the
village including, but not limited to, any patch of the police or fire
department; nor shall any person, other than a duly authorized public official,
make use of said seal or logo without prior approval of the village board of
trustees, except for the usual and customary purposes of decoration or display.
(2016 Code)
1-5-2: ELECTIONS:
Elections for village offices shall be held in accordance with Illinois
election code, 10 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-1 et seq. (2016 Code)
1-5-3: ELECTRONIC ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS:
The electronic attendance at meetings policy approved by the village board is
by this reference made a part of this section and is the official policy of the
village regarding attendance of members of all village boards, commissions, and
committees to participate in public meetings by means other than physical
presence. (Ord. 06-41, 12-19-2006, eff. 1-1-2007; amd. 2016 Code; Ord. 23-47,
10-3-2023)
1-5-4: INDEMNIFICATION OF VILLAGE OFFICIALS:
   A.   The village policy as to indemnification of village officials is as
follows:
      1.   The village has the power to indemnify its officials, both elected
and appointed, pursuant to law.
      2.   The term "officials", as used in this section, shall mean the
president and trustees, the village administrator, department directors and
appointed committee and commission members, as well as all other officers of
the village, whether or not currently serving.
      3.   It is in the best interest of the village to provide for the
indemnification of its officials, both elected and appointed, against claims,
expenses and liabilities to which such persons may be subject by reason of
their having acted in their capacity as a public official.
   B.   The village shall indemnify any official who was or is a party, or may
become a party, to any threatened, pending or completed action, suit or
proceeding, whether civil, administrative or investigative, by reason of any
act or omission, error, misstatement or misleading statement, or neglect or
breach of duty or any other action which could reasonably be construed to have
been committed, attempted or allegedly committed or attempted by such person in
the discharge of his or her duties in his or her capacity as an official, both
elected and appointed, against expenses (including attorney fees), judgments
and amounts paid in settlement actually and reasonably incurred by him or her
in connection with such action, suit or proceeding, if such person acted in
good faith in a manner in which he or she reasonably believed was in the best
interests of the village. This indemnification shall not apply to any claim,
suit, action or proceeding:
      1.   Which is for the return by any such official, both elected and
appointed, of any remuneration paid in fact to him or her without the previous
approval of the village if it shall be determined by judgment or other final
adjudication that such remuneration is in violation of law or if such
remuneration is to be repaid to the village under a settlement agreement.
      2.   Which is for an accounting of profits made from a purchase or sale
by such official, both elected and appointed, of village property for any
transaction prohibited by the village ethics ordinance.
      3.   Which is brought about or contributed to by the fraudulent or
dishonest acts of such official, both elected and appointed, if a judgment or
other final adjudication adverse to such official establishes that acts of
active and deliberate dishonesty were committed or attempted by such official
with actual dishonest purpose and intent and were material to the cause of
action so adjudicated.
      4.   Which is brought about or contributed to by any criminal activities
of such official, and there has been a judicial determination of said criminal
activities.
      5.   For which the village is not authorized by law to provide
indemnification to the official, either elected or appointed.
      6.   With reference to any of the aforementioned enumerated items, a
presumption shall exist that indemnification shall apply unless a judicial
finding to the contrary is made.
   C.   The termination of any action, suit or proceeding, contrary to the best
interests of the official, by judgment, order, settlement or other resolution
shall not create a presumption that the official did not act in good faith in a
manner in which he or she reasonably believed was in the best interests of the
village. To the extent that an official has been successful, on the merits or
otherwise, in the defense of any action, suit or proceeding or in the defense
of any claim which qualifies herein for indemnification, such person shall be
indemnified against expenses (including attorney fees) actually and reasonably
incurred by such person in connection therewith. However, the village shall not
withhold payment of attorney fees until the conclusion of any legal
proceedings, but shall pay the attorney fees of the official on a timely basis.
   D.   The village shall indemnify only those officials, either elected or
appointed, from whom or with respect to whom the village has received written
notice of a claim. To the extent practicable, any notice from such official
shall be mailed as soon as practicable and shall identify the official seeking
the indemnification and contain information with respect to the time, place and
circumstances of the claim, the names and addresses of any injured persons or
other claimants and the names of any available witnesses. In the case where
legal proceedings have been commenced, indemnification may be denied if the
official fails to mail to the village, within twenty (20) days after receiving
service of process, a copy of such process relating to a claimed wrongful act
unless: 1) the village has otherwise received a copy of, or written notice of,
such process; or 2) the failure to notify within such twenty (20) day period
does not adversely impact upon the village's ability to defend against such
claim. Notice of the claim shall be made in writing to the village clerk.
   E.   The village shall indemnify the official for any damages, expenses,
court costs and legal fees incurred in connection with any defense of or
settlement of a claim, action or proceeding where such settlement has been
approved in advance by the village, or where the village refuses or fails to
approve such settlement, such settlement is deemed to be reasonable by
independent legal counsel chosen by both the village and the official.
   F.   Any indemnification pursuant to this section shall be made by the
village upon a determination that indemnification of the person is required by
this section. Such determination shall be made: 1) by the president and board
of trustees by a majority vote of a quorum of the board who were not parties to
such claim, suit, action or proceeding; or 2) if such quorum is not obtainable
or, even if obtainable, where a majority of a quorum of the board fails to
approve the indemnification, by independent legal counsel chosen by both the
claimant and the village board.
   G.   Any official against whom any action, suit or proceeding is brought may
employ his or her own attorney; provided, that such attorney is reasonably
acceptable to the village; and provided further, that the costs of such
attorney shall not be paid by the village unless the village attorney or
independent counsel for the village shall have advised the village that such
official's interests should not be represented by the same counsel that
represents the village in such action, suit or proceeding.
   H.   The indemnification provided herein shall be in addition to and not
exclusive of any other indemnity or insurance or other protection to which the
indemnitee may be entitled. The indemnification provided herein shall be
payable whether or not the village has obtained insurance therefor and, in the
case of the death of the indemnitee, shall inure to the benefit of his or her
heirs or successors. (2016 Code)
1-5-5: RULES CONCERNING PUBLIC COMMENT AND PARTICIPATION:
The public comment and participation policy approved by the Village Board is by
this reference made a part of this section and is the official policy of the
Village regarding participation of members of the public at meetings of public
bodies of the Village. (Ord. 23-48, 10-3-2023)
CHAPTER 6
ELECTIVE VILLAGE OFFICERS
SECTION:
1-6-1: Commencement Of Term
1-6-2: Inauguration
1-6-1: COMMENCEMENT OF TERM:
The terms of elected village officers shall commence at the first regular or
special meeting of the corporate authorities after receipt of the official
election results from the Cook County clerk of the regular municipal election
at which the officers were elected, but in no event will terms commence later
than the first regular or special meeting of the corporate authorities in June
following the election, or as otherwise established by state law. (2016 Code)
1-6-2: INAUGURATION:
The date for inauguration of newly elected officers of the village shall be
immediately prior to the commencement of business of the meeting established in
section
1-6-1 of this chapter. (1976 Code § 2.10.020; amd. 2016 Code)
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE PRESIDENT
SECTION:
1-6A-1: Reference To Mayor
1-6A-2: Election And Term
1-6A-3: Bond And Oath
1-6A-4: Compensation
1-6A-5: Powers And Duties
1-6A-6: President Pro Tem
1-6A-7: State Of Emergency
1-6A-1: REFERENCE TO MAYOR:
The village president, in his or her discretion, may be addressed, designated
or referred to as mayor. (2016 Code)
1-6A-2: ELECTION AND TERM:
The village president shall be elected for a term of four (4) years and shall
be president of the village board as provided by statute. (1976 Code §
2.04.010)
1-6A-3: BOND AND OATH:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the president shall give bond,
with sureties to be approved by the board, conditioned upon the faithful
performance of his duties, in the sum of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00). He
shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute. (1976 Code § 2.04.040;
amd. 2016 Code)
1-6A-4: COMPENSATION:
The annual salary of the village president shall be eight thousand dollars
($8,000.00), until the same is amended or modified by subsequent ordinance.
(Ord. 94-18, 11-1-1994; amd. 2016 Code)
1-6A-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The president shall have all the powers and perform all the duties
hereinafter set forth and as are provided by the laws of the state of Illinois
or by the village ordinances. He shall be the chief executive officer and
representative of the village. Among other things, he shall perform the
following duties:
      1.   Preside at all regular and special meetings of the board of
trustees, unless unavoidably prevented.
      2.   Nominate persons to fill the appointive offices of the village.
      3.   Investigate all matters pertaining to the interests of the village
and well being of the residents.
      4.   Countersign all commissions, licenses and permits authorized by
statute or village ordinance.
      5.   Sign all contracts and warrants on behalf of the village, approved
by resolution.
      6.   Generally, be charged with the responsibility for the proper conduct
of the village affairs and the enforcement of all ordinances of the village.
   B.   The village president shall submit to the board of trustees a report
relative to the affairs of the village, and he shall recommend for
consideration by the board such measures as he may deem expedient. (2016 Code)
1-6A-6: PRESIDENT PRO TEM:
If a temporary absence from the village or disability of the president
incapacitates him from the performance of his duties, but does not create a
vacancy in the office, the board of trustees shall elect one of its members to
act as village president pro tem. The village president pro tem, during this
absence or disability, shall perform the duties and possess all the rights and
powers of the village president but shall not be entitled to vote as president
pro tem and trustee. (2016 Code)
1-6A-7: STATE OF EMERGENCY:
   A.   The Village President is authorized to declare of a state of emergency
within the Village of Berkeley based on the following findings and supporting
facts:
      1.   There has occurred, or there is actual imminent danger of occurring,
a natural disaster, catastrophe, pestilence or contagious disease, which is
likely to cause loss of life, loss of productivity, hardship or suffering to
the persons residing in or doing business in the Village.
      2.   That the declaration of emergency is necessary in order to prevent
loss of life or injury, alleviate damages, loss, hardship, or suffering.
   B.   During a declared state of emergency, the Village President is
authorized to exercise, by executive order, such powers of the Village
President and Board of Trustees as may be reasonably necessary to respond to
the emergency.
   C.   A declaration of a state of emergency shall:
      1.   Be executed under oath.
      2.   Set forth the basis and underlying facts supporting the declaration
of a state of emergency.
      3.   Make reference to published statements of federal, state or county
agencies whose duty it is to address emergency matters.
      4.   To the extent possible, specify the procedures and protocols to be
followed during the state of emergency.
      5.   To the extent possible, make specific reference to any regulations
which may be subject to suspension during the state of emergency.
      6.   Consistent with Section C.8. below, set forth the duration of the
state of emergency.
      7.   Be filed with the Village Clerk as soon as practicable.
      8.   Expire no later than the adjournment of the first regular meeting of
the Village President and Board of Trustees after the state of emergency has
been declared.
   D.   A declaration of emergency pursuant to this authority may not suspend
in any way the rights of persons under the Illinois or United States
Constitutions.
   E.   The authority granted to the Village President herein is in addition to
the authority of the Village President elsewhere in the Village Code to address
emergencies in the Village of Berkeley, including, but not limited to, in
Article 6-38. (Ord. 20-19, 3-17-2020)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-6B-1: Election And Terms
1-6B-2: Oath Of Office
1-6B-3: Compensation
1-6B-4: Meetings
1-6B-5: Quorum
1-6B-6: Committees
1-6B-7: Rules And Order Of Business
1-6B-1: ELECTION AND TERMS:
The Board of Trustees, consisting of six (6) members, shall be elected to
office for a four (4) year term as is provided by statute. This Board shall be
the legislative department of the Village government and shall perform such
duties and have such powers as may be delegated thereto by State Statute. (1976
Code § 2.08.010)
1-6B-2: OATH OF OFFICE:
The members of the Board shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute.
(1976 Code § 2.08.020)
1-6B-3: COMPENSATION:
The annual salaries of Village Trustees shall be five thousand dollars
($5,000.00), until the same are amended or modified by subsequent ordinance.
(Ord. 94-18, 11-1-1994; amd. 2016 Code)
1-6B-4: MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The Village Board of Trustees shall hold its regular
meetings on the first and third Tuesdays of each month at the hour of six
thirty o’clock (6:30) P.M. Meetings are held in the Bicentennial Room.
   B.   Committee Meetings: Committee meetings, when required, will be held and
notice given in compliance with the Open Meetings Act 1 . Committee meetings
shall be at the Village Hall of the Village of Berkeley unless otherwise
ordered by the Board of Trustees.
   C.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be called by the President of
the Village or any three (3) Trustees upon at least seventy two (72) hours'
notice to all Trustees and the President.
   D.   Open Meetings: All meetings provided for in this section shall be
according to the directives and regulations of the Open Meetings Act provided
in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/1 et seq.
   E.   Disturbing Village Meetings: It is unlawful for any person to disturb
any meeting of the Board of Trustees or of any committee thereof. (1976 Code §
9.16.040; amd. Ord. 98-29, 9-1-1998; Ord. 03-55, 9-16-2003; 2016 Code; Ord. 19-
72, 12-17-2019)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
1-6B-5: QUORUM:
   A.   A majority of the Village Board constitutes a quorum.
   B.   Approval of all ordinances and of all resolutions or motions creating
liabilities or for expenditures requires the concurrence of a majority of the
Village Board. (2016 Code)
1-6B-6: COMMITTEES:
   A.   Standing Committees: The Village President shall make Trustee
assignments to the following standing committees:
      Administration, Zoning, Technology,
      Community and Intergovernmental Relations,
      Finance and Economic Development,
      Fire and Public Health,
      Police and Property Maintenance, and
      Public Works and Utilities. (Ord. 18-10, 3-6-2018)
   B.   Other Committees: The President shall appoint such other and further
committees as may be necessary to properly carry on the business of the
Village. Written minutes shall be made of all committee meetings and submitted
to the Board of Trustees at the next regular meeting.
   C.   Committee Of The Whole: In addition, a Committee of the Whole shall
consist of the Village President, the members of the Board of Trustees, and the
Village Administrator, if there be one. The Chair of said committee shall be
the Village President. The Village President shall be an ex officio member of
all committees. (2016 Code)
1-6B-7: RULES AND ORDER OF BUSINESS:
The following rules for the government of the meetings of the Board of Trustees
are hereby adopted:
   A.   Order Of Business:
      1.   Regular Meetings: The order of business at all regular meetings
shall be determined by roll call vote at each meeting. The agenda for each
meeting may include the following items but not in any particular sequence:
         a.   Call to order.
         b.   Pledge of Allegiance.
         c.   Roll call.
         d.   Presentations and appointments.
         e.   Approval of minutes of any regular meeting and special meeting.
         f.   Approval of the directive to pay, and consideration of, bills
against the Village.
         g.   Consent agenda.
         h.   Reports of committees.
         i.   Village President report.
         j.   Reports of the administrative staff.
         k.   Old business.
         l.   New business.
         m.   Public comments and questions.
         n.   Adjournment.
      2.   Special Meetings: The order of business at special meetings shall be
as follows:
         a.   Call to order and calling of the roll of the Trustees.
         b.   Consideration of the object of the meeting.
   B.   Rules Of Procedure:
      1.   The Village Board may adopt rules of order and procedure and if not
governed by those rules or State Statute, meetings shall be conducted in
accordance with "Robert's Rules of Order".
      2.   The President shall decide all questions of order, subject to an
appeal to the Board; and in all cases, where these rules are not applicable,
the Board of Trustees shall be governed by parliamentary law, as laid down in
"Robert's Rules of Order".
   C.   Suspension Of Rules: The rules of the Board of Trustees, other than
those prescribed by statute, may be suspended during any one meeting by a
majority vote of the members present.
   D.   Written Resolutions And Ordinances: All resolutions and ordinances
shall be reduced to writing before being presented to the Board of Trustees for
action.
   E.   President And Trustees To Attend Meetings: It shall be the duty of the
President and Board of Trustees to attend every meeting of the Board of
Trustees and their respective committee meetings unless unavoidably detained.
   F.   Referring Documents: All ordinances, petitions, resolutions, orders,
and communications to the Village shall be referred by the President or
presiding officer to the proper committee, officer or employee.
   G.   Committee Reports: Each committee shall make a report in the committee
minutes or orally on the state of the matters before that committee. (2016
Code)
ARTICLE C. VILLAGE CLERK
SECTION:
1-6C-1: Election And Term
1-6C-2: Bond
1-6C-3: Compensation
1-6C-4: Vacancy In Office
1-6C-5: Duties
1-6C-6: Deputy Clerk
1-6C-1: ELECTION AND TERM:
The village clerk shall be elected and serve for a four (4) year term and until
his or her successor is elected and qualified as provided by statute. (1976
Code § 2.09.010)
1-6C-2: BOND:
Before entering upon his or her duties of office, the village clerk shall
execute a bond in such amount and with such sureties as may be required by the
board of trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties.
(1976 Code § 2.09.020)
1-6C-3: COMPENSATION:
The annual salary of the village clerk shall be six thousand dollars
($6,000.00), until amended or modified by subsequent ordinance. (Ord. 94-18,
11-1-1994; amd. Ord. 01-15, 6-19-2001)
1-6C-4: VACANCY IN OFFICE:
In case the office of village clerk becomes vacant for any reason, the
president and village board of trustees shall appoint a successor as provided
by state statute. (1976 Code § 2.09.110)
1-6C-5: DUTIES:
In addition to the statutory duties and those contained elsewhere in this code,
the village clerk shall:
   A.   Attend all meetings of the board of trustees; and post notice of and
record all proceedings of the board of trustees; and make available for public
inspection that record, within seven (7) days after approval by the board of
trustees.
   B.   Tape, or make a digital recording of, all closed meetings of the board
of trustees pursuant to the Illinois open meetings act 1 , secure such recorded
media in a safe place where it shall be kept in confidentiality, and otherwise
assure that the requirements of the open meetings act are met with respect to
their release and destruction. If the village clerk cannot attend a closed
meeting for whatever reason, the village clerk, a deputy village clerk, or
another designee of the clerk shall be responsible for assuring compliance with
the requirements of this subsection. The person taking minutes for such meeting
shall record the meeting and then provide the village clerk with the original
recorded media for security thereof. No copies of such recorded media shall be
made by any person other than the village clerk, or an authorized deputy clerk.
   C.   Keep a record of all ordinances and resolutions of the village in a
book or books provided for that purpose. For every ordinance requiring posting
or recording, the clerk shall, when so required, have noted thereon the date of
such posting or recording, and make a certificate of such posting or recording
and attach the same to the original ordinance kept in the records of the
village.
   D.   Seal and attest all ordinances, resolutions and contracts of the
village, certain licenses and permits, and other such documents as shall
require this formality. The seal of the village may be mechanically or
digitally printed on certain licenses, permits and other such documents, so
that a manual seal by the clerk is not necessary, but all documents with a
mechanical or digital seal, as provided herein, shall nevertheless be
considered officially sealed village documents.
   E.   Serve certain notices, either by personal service, by publication or
posting, required by statute, local ordinance, or by order of the president or
board of trustees to be served and in the manner by law required, unless
notices are expressly ordered to be served by another village official.
   F.   Keep a complete and accurate file of the official papers of the village
so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had by any properly
authorized elected official, village officer, or village staff member.
   G.   Countersign, in writing, all contracts, bonds, other agreements, or
evidence of indebtedness, of the village made in the name of the village, and
by the authority of the village president and board of trustees.
   H.   If created by the board of trustees, keep a list of all village board
committees, and a record of the business brought before them.
   I.   Be the custodian of the village seal and shall affix its impression on
documents whenever this is required, pursuant to subsection D of this section.
   J.   Perform all, and such duties as are, from time to time, imposed by the
village president or board of trustees. (2016 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
1-6C-6: DEPUTY CLERK:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment; General Powers And Duties: There is hereby
created the office of deputy clerk. The village administrator is authorized to
appoint a deputy clerk, who shall have the power and duty to execute all
documents required by any law or ordinance to be executed by the village clerk,
and affix the seal of the village thereto whenever required. (1976 Code §
2.09.120; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Signature: When signing any documents, the deputy clerk shall sign the
name of the village clerk followed by the word "by" and the deputy clerk's own
name and the words "deputy clerk". (1976 Code § 2.09.120)
   C.   Duties: The deputy village clerk, under the general supervision of the
village clerk and village administrator, shall:
      1.   Maintain custody of all village records;
      2.   Publish and post notices of all public meetings and copies of
resolutions and ordinances adopted by the village board when appropriate or
directed;
      3.   Maintain the corporate seal and certify the authenticity of all
copies of village documents;
      4.   Serve as local registrar of all vital statistics kept by the
village;
      5.   Attend meetings of the village president and board of trustees when
the village clerk is unavailable and keep a record of their proceedings;
      6.   Receive developer escrow fees; and
      7.   Perform such functions or duties as assigned by the village clerk or
village administrator. (2016 Code)
CHAPTER 7
OTHER VILLAGE OFFICERS AND PERSONNEL
SECTION:
1-7-1: Retirement
1-7-2: Social Security
1-7-1: RETIREMENT:
The village president and board of trustees elect that the village shall
participate in the Illinois municipal retirement fund, effective January 1,
1969. (1976 Code § 2.32.010)
1-7-2: SOCIAL SECURITY:
   A.   Policy And Purpose: It is the policy and purpose of the village to
extend to the eligible employees thereof, effective as of August 1, 1954, the
benefits of the federal old age and survivors insurance system as authorized by
the federal social security act and amendments thereto. In pursuance of said
policy, and for that purpose, the village clerk shall take such action as may
be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (1976 Code §
2.32.020)
   B.   Execution Of Agreement With State: The village president is authorized
and directed to execute an agreement with the state employees' retirement
system (social security unit) to secure coverage of eligible employees as
provided in subsection A of this section. (1976 Code § 2.32.030)
   C.   Withholdings; Remittance: Withholdings from salaries or wages of
employees for the purpose provided in subsection A of this section are
authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by
applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the
state agency in such amounts and at such times as are designated by state laws
or regulations. (1976 Code § 2.32.040)
   D.   Employer Contributions: Employer contributions and administrative
expense shall be paid to the state agency in accordance with applicable state
laws and regulations from amounts appropriated for such purposes. (1976 Code §
2.32.050)
   E.   Records And Reports: The village finance director shall maintain such
records and submit such reports as may be required by applicable state and
federal laws or regulations. (1976 Code § 2.32.060; amd. 2016 Code)
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
SECTION:
1-7A-1: Office Created; Appointment And Term; Qualifications
1-7A-2: Oath Of Office
1-7A-3: Compensation
1-7A-4: Powers And Duties
1-7A-5: Conflict Of Interest
1-7A-6: Removal From Office
1-7A-7: Acting Village Administrator
1-7A-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT AND TERM; QUALIFICATIONS:
There is hereby created the office of village administrator. The village
administrator shall be appointed by the president, with the advice and consent
of the board of trustees, for such term as determined at the time of his or her
appointment or by contract or as otherwise provided by law. The village
administrator shall be chosen solely on the basis of his or her executive and
administrative qualifications, with special reference to his or her actual
experience in, and knowledge of, accepted practices in respect to the duties of
his or her employment as set forth herein. At the time of such appointment, the
village administrator need not be a resident of the village, but shall reside
either within the village or within reasonable distance therefrom during the
term of office. (2016 Code)
1-7A-2: OATH OF OFFICE:
Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, the village administrator
shall take and subscribe the oath as set forth in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/3.1-10-25, as may be amended from time to time. This oath, so subscribed,
shall be filed in the office of the village clerk. (2016 Code)
1-7A-3: COMPENSATION:
The village administrator shall receive such compensation and benefits as the
president and board of trustees shall determine by ordinance, or alternatively,
pursuant to any contract which defines said terms. No compensation shall be
paid to the village administrator in addition to that provided in the ordinance
or by the terms of any contract; except, however, the village administrator
shall be entitled to reimbursement for any reasonable actual expenses incurred
by him or her in the performance of his or her duties. (2016 Code)
1-7A-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The village administrator shall be the administrative director of all
departments of the village. He or she shall be responsible to the president and
board of trustees for the proper administration of all affairs of the village.
The village administrator shall perform such duties in addition to those which
may be prescribed by law, and shall be subject to such other rules and
regulations as the president and board of trustees may provide by ordinance
from time to time. Specifically, but without limitation, the village
administrator shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   Supervise and coordinate the work of all departments of the village now
in existence or that may hereafter be created by the president and board of
trustees, except as limited or restricted by any ordinance of the village;
   B.   Recommend to the president and board of trustees in regard to the
hiring of all employees of the village. He or she shall recommend to the
president the removal or suspension of any department director or employee when
such removal or suspension shall be consistent with the village personnel
manual and/or any relevant provisions of the Illinois state statutes. All such
recommendations for the hiring of employees shall be based upon merit and
qualifications. Any recommendation for either hiring or removal shall be made
without regard to political belief or affiliation;
   C.   Review, annually, salaries, wages and hours and conditions of
employment of all department directors and employees under his or her
jurisdiction. No expenditure shall be made on account of or pursuant to such
appointment or employment by the village administrator unless authorized by or
under the annual budget of the village, and all such expenditures shall be
subject to the approval of the president and board of trustees;
   D.   Act as purchasing agent of the village and make or supervise all
necessary purchases of equipment, materials and supplies by the village, and
all contracts therefor. The village administrator shall have the power to enter
into contracts for services and purchase goods and materials involving up to
and including twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) without the prior approval
of the village board, as long as those services, goods and materials have been
previously budgeted. Contracts and purchases in excess of this amount shall
require the prior approval of the village board, whether or not they have been
previously budgeted. The village administrator may issue rules and regulations
governing requisitions and the transaction of business of purchasing between
himself or herself, as purchasing agent, and the department directors and
employees of the village;
   E.   Make recommendations concerning compensation for each department
director and employed position in the service of the village, including
minimum, intermediate and maximum rates;
   F.   Recommend the creation, consolidation and combination of offices,
positions, departments or units of the administrative and executive departments
of the village;
   G.   Investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning the
administration of the government of the village and services maintained by the
public utilities in the village, and see that all franchises, permits and
privileges granted by the village are faithfully observed;
   H.   Prepare and present to the president for his consideration at the end
of each fiscal year an estimate of income and expenses for the ensuing year;
prepare the annual tax levy ordinance in the form and within the time required
by law; and prepare the annual budget; and submit such ordinance and budget to
the president for his submittal to the board of trustees, together with the
village administrator's opinion and recommendations covering their important
features; and upon the adoption of such ordinance and budget, the
administration of the same. To the end that all financial matters of the
village are coordinated, the village finance director is hereby directed to
cooperate with the village administrator and to assist him or her in the
performance of the duties imposed upon him or her by this article;
   I.   Act as business manager for the village under the direction of the
president and board of trustees and in cooperation with the village finance
director and clerk; control and direct all expenditures made by the village;
supervise the keeping of all necessary records and books of accounts of the
village that are not under the supervision of the finance director or clerk, by
ordinance or statute;
   J.   Attend all regular and special meetings of the village board, and
committees thereof, unless excused by the same;
   K.   Render or cause to be rendered monthly to the president and board of
trustees written statements showing the exact financial condition of the
village as of the end of the preceding month, including the statement of
current assets and liabilities, and a summarized statement of receipts and
expenditures;
   L.   Make recommendations to the president and board of trustees, or
appropriate committee thereof, relative to the adoption of such ordinances and
resolutions as he or she may deem necessary or expedient; meet with the
committees of the president and board of trustees as often as necessary and
when requested;
   M.   Make special reports or recommendations to the board of trustees, or
the appropriate committee thereof, as the board of trustees may request;
   N.   Render to all department directors of the village, and said department
directors shall render to him or her, all such assistance as is possible in the
performance of their respective duties, and all department directors and
employees of the village shall furnish and disclose to the village
administrator such oral or written information and material relating to the
affairs of the village as he or she shall request;
   O.   Keep a current inventory of all real and personal property of the
village and the location of such property; be responsible for the care and
custody of all village property which is not by law assigned to some other
department director or body for care and control;
   P.   Devote his or her entire time during reasonable hours to the discharge
of his or her official duties. He or she shall hold no other employment for
compensation; except, that he or she may receive occasional stipends for
consultation with others not connected with the village, making speeches,
writing professional articles, and the like; provided, that such secondary
duties do not conflict with his or her duties as village administrator; and
   Q.   Perform such other duties as may be required of him or her by the
corporate authorities not inconsistent with the statutes of the state of
Illinois or with the ordinances of the village. (2016 Code)
1-7A-5: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
The village administrator shall abide by the relevant provisions of the
Illinois Compiled Statutes pertaining to conflicts of interest, disclosures of
economic interests and contracts, including, but not limited to, 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-55-10 and 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 420/4A-101 et
seq., and as the same and any other relevant provisions of the state statutes
may be amended from time to time by the Illinois general assembly. The village
administrator shall promptly disclose any potential conflict of interest to the
president and board of trustees. (2016 Code)
1-7A-6: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The village administrator may be removed by the president on any formal charge
whenever the president is of the opinion that the interests of the village
demand removal. Such removal is subject to the payment of any valid remaining
portion of his or her contract, if hired by contract. The president shall
report the reasons for such removal to the village board at a meeting to be
held not more than ten (10) days after the removal. If the president fails or
refuses to report to the board of trustees the reasons for the removal, or if
the village board, by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of all its members authorized by
law to be elected, disapproves of the removal, the village administrator,
thereupon, shall be restored to office. Upon restoration, the village
administrator shall give a new bond and take a new oath of office. (2016 Code)
1-7A-7: ACTING VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR:
In the event the village administrator shall be incapacitated from performing
the duties of his or her position, a qualified person shall be appointed as
acting village administrator by the president, with the advice and consent of
the board of trustees, during such absence or incapacity, with all the powers
and duties of that office, who shall perform all the duties thereof without
furnishing any additional bond if such appointee shall already be under bond to
the village in any other capacity. If such appointment shall be a person not
already under bond to the village, such appointee shall furnish a bond in such
amount and with such surety as may be approved by the president and board of
trustees. The compensation to be paid the acting village administrator shall be
fixed by the president and board of trustees. (2016 Code)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE FINANCE DIRECTOR
SECTION:
1-7B-1: Office Created; Appointment And Term
1-7B-2: Powers And Duties
1-7B-3: Special Assessment Fund
1-7B-4: Drawing Warrants; Transfer Of Funds
1-7B-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
There is hereby created the office of finance director. The finance director
shall be appointed by the village president, with the advice and consent of the
board of trustees. The finance director shall have a term of office of one year
and until his successor has been chosen and has qualified. (2016 Code)
1-7B-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   In addition to the duties specifically delegated to the finance
director by this code, the finance director shall have all duties and powers
which are assigned by any statute of the state of Illinois or any code,
ordinance or resolution of the village to the office of village treasurer and
shall serve ex officio in such capacity concurrently with his employment as
finance director.
   B.   The finance director shall:
      1.   Perform such duties as may be prescribed for the village treasurer
by statute or ordinance.
      2.   Receive all monies paid into the village, whether directly from the
person paying the money or from the hands of such other officer or employee as
may receive it, and he shall pay out monies only on vouchers or orders properly
signed by the village president and clerk.
      3.   Review all claims for reimbursement against the village and submit a
list of all outstanding claims to the finance committee for their
consideration, together with his report as to the status of the claims.
      4.   Prepare and file all fiscal, financial, and tax reports, documents,
and materials as may be required of the village to be presented to public
agencies of the federal, state, and county governments, and to be presented to
such financial institutions as may be doing business with the village.
      5.   On or before June 15 of each year, submit to the board of trustees a
report of his estimate, as nearly as may be, of the money necessary to defray
the expenses of the village during the current fiscal year. For the purpose of
making this report, the finance director shall require all officers of the
village to submit statements of the condition and expenses of their offices or
departments; and any proposed improvements and the estimated expense thereof; a
statement of all unperformed contracts; and the amount of all unexpended
budgeted items of the preceding year. His report shall also:
         a.   Classify the objects and purposes of such estimated expenditures
and the amounts required for each;
         b.   Show the aggregate income of the preceding fiscal year, from all
sources;
         c.   Show the amount of liability on which interest is to be paid;
         d.   Show the bonds and debts due and payable and the dates when such
are due and payable; and
         e.   Give such other information regarding the financial situation of
the village as the board of trustees may require.
      6.   Deposit the village funds in such depositories as may be selected
from time to time as provided by law and keep the deposit of the village monies
separate and distinct from his own monies. The finance director shall not use
village monies for personal or private use.
      7.   Keep such books, accounts, and records as may be required by statute
or ordinance, and establish, supervise, and maintain the financial record
system of the village. The records, books, and accounts of the finance director
shall show, among other things, all monies received by him showing the source
from which received and the purpose for which paid. (2016 Code)
1-7B-3: SPECIAL ASSESSMENT FUND:
All monies received on any special assessment shall be held by the finance
director as a special fund to be applied only to the payment of the
improvement, or bonds and vouchers issued therefor, together with interest
thereon, for which the assessment was made, and such money shall be used for no
other purpose unless to reimburse the village for money expended for such
improvements. Payment on bonds or vouchers shall be made in accordance with the
statutes and the law, and the finance director shall keep his books and
accounts in such a manner so that proper prorations in payments of principal
and interest can be made and ascertained. (2016 Code)
1-7B-4: DRAWING WARRANTS; TRANSFER OF FUNDS:
   A.   All warrants drawn on the finance director must be signed by the
president and countersigned by the clerk, stating the particular fund or
appropriation to which the same is chargeable and the person to whom payable,
and no money shall be otherwise paid except as may be provided by statute.
   B.   Money shall not be transferred by the finance director from one fund to
another after it has been received by him, nor appropriated to any other
purpose than that for which is has been collected or paid, except as may be
ordered by the president and board of trustees in manner and form prescribed by
statute. (2016 Code)
ARTICLE C. VILLAGE ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-7C-1: Office Created; Qualifications
1-7C-2: Appointment; Legal Advisor
1-7C-3: Duties
1-7C-4: Compensation
1-7C-1: OFFICE CREATED; QUALIFICATIONS:
There is hereby created the office of village attorney, which office shall be
held by an attorney or firm of attorneys admitted to the bar and licensed to
practice law in the state. (2016 Code)
1-7C-2: APPOINTMENT; LEGAL ADVISOR:
The village president may appoint and retain the village attorney to act as
legal advisor to the village, and said village attorney shall render advice on
all legal questions affecting the village, as the board of trustees may request
from time to time. (2016 Code)
1-7C-3: DUTIES:
   A.   Prepare Documents: The village attorney shall prepare all ordinances
and resolutions required by the board of trustees, and shall draft and/or
supervise the content of any contracts, leases, or other documents and
instruments to which the village may be a party.
   B.   Attend Meetings: The village attorney shall attend all regular and
special meetings of the board of trustees and such meetings of boards and
commissions of the village or committees of the board of trustees as he shall
be directed by the board of trustees.
   C.   Suits And Actions: The village attorney shall defend any and all suits
or actions at law or equity to which the village may be a party, or in which it
may be interested, or which may be brought against or by any officer of the
village, or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the village. (2016
Code)
1-7C-4: COMPENSATION:
For such services, the village attorney shall be paid such salary and
compensation as shall be agreed upon by the village attorney and the board of
trustees at the time of appointment. (2016 Code)
ARTICLE D. VILLAGE PROSECUTOR
SECTION:
1-7D-1: Office Created; Qualifications
1-7D-2: Appointment; Duties
1-7D-3: Assisted By Village Attorney
1-7D-4: Compensation
1-7D-1: OFFICE CREATED; QUALIFICATIONS:
There is hereby created the office of village prosecutor, who shall be an
attorney licensed to practice in the state. (2016 Code)
1-7D-2: APPOINTMENT; DUTIES:
The village prosecutor shall be appointed by the village president and shall
prosecute all matters involving the violation of any ordinances of the village
or in which the village may be interested. (2016 Code)
1-7D-3: ASSISTED BY VILLAGE ATTORNEY:
The village attorney shall assist the village prosecutor at the request of the
board of trustees. The village prosecutor shall notify the village attorney of
any notice of appeal served in connection with the imposition of any fine or
other penalty for a violation of a village ordinance. The village prosecutor
shall report to the village attorney on the progress of any matters which have
been continued from time to time and their final disposition. (2016 Code)
1-7D-4: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the village prosecutor shall be as determined by the
village board of trustees. (2016 Code)
CHAPTER 8
CODE OF ETHICS
SECTION:
1-8-1: Statement Of Policy And Intent
1-8-2: Definitions

1-8-14: Provisions Are Additional
1-8-1: STATEMENT OF POLICY AND INTENT:
   A.   All village public officials and employees, paid or unpaid, hold their
positions for the benefit of the village. They are bound to uphold the
constitution of the United States and the constitution of the state of Illinois
and to carry out the laws of the nation, the state and the village. They are
obligated to faithfully discharge the duties of their office, acting
independently and impartially for the public interest. They are expected to
make and carry out decisions and policy within the proper channels of
government structure without prejudice or favoritism; the opportunity for
personal gain will not influence their actions or decisions. They are expected
to observe a high standard of conduct in the discharge of their official duties
and to avoid any actions that might, to a reasonable person, suggest the
appearance of impropriety.
   B.   This code of ethics, which defines the expectations of the community in
regard to the behavior of public officials and employees, is not intended to
work hardship on any individual dedicated to serving the public interest. It
should not exclude those who are best qualified to serve or work, nor violate
any individual's right to personal privacy. It is not intended to impair an
individual's ability to participate in functions associated with official
duties.
   C.   In recognition of these expectations, there is hereby established a
code of ethics for all public officials and employees. (2016 Code)
1-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
APPOINTED OFFICERS: Shall include any officer appointed by the village
president including, but not limited to, the village administrator, finance
director, police chief, fire chief and superintendent of public works.
CAMPAIGN FOR ELECTIVE OFFICE: Any activity in furtherance of an effort to
influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of any individual
to any federal, state or local public office or office in a political
organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice
presidential electors, but does not include activities:
   A.   Relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or
administrative action (as those terms are defined in section 2 of the lobbyist
registration act);
   B.   Relating to collective bargaining; or
   C.   That are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties.
CANDIDATE: A person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination
or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a vacancy
in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a
"regular election", as defined in section 1-3 of the election code 1 .
COLLECTIVE BARGAINING: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in section
3 of the Illinois public labor relations act 2 .
COMMISSION/COMMITTEE MEMBERS: Persons appointed by the village president who
serve on standing and ad hoc boards, committees and commissions including the
9-1-1 board, ALS ad hoc committee, code enforcement board of appeals, economic
development commission, fire and police commission and planning and zoning
commission.
COMPENSATED TIME: Means, with respect to an employee, any time worked by or
credited to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time requirement
imposed as a condition of his or her employment, but for purposes of this
chapter, does not include any designated holidays, vacation periods, personal
time, compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of
absence. With respect to officers or employees whose hours are not fixed,
"compensated time" includes any period of time when the officer is on premises
under the control of the employer and any other time when the covered
individual is executing his or her official duties, regardless of location.
COMPENSATORY TIME OFF: Authorized time off earned by or awarded to an employee
to compensate, in whole or in part, for time worked in excess of the minimum
work time required of that employee as a condition of his or her employment.
CONTRIBUTION: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 9-1.4 of
the election code 3 .
COVERED INDIVIDUAL: Village president, trustee, appointed officer, village
employee, commission member, and committee member.
ELECTED OFFICIALS: Shall include the village president, village clerk, and
village trustees.
EMPLOYEE: Any person employed by the village, but does not include independent
contractors, subcontractors, or elected public officials, or members of
commissions or committees.
EMPLOYER: The village of Berkeley.
GIFT: Any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or
other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not
limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements
related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of
a covered individual.
LEAVE OF ABSENCE: Any period during which an employee does not receive:
   A.   Compensation for employment;
   B.   Service credit toward pension benefits; and
   C.   Health insurance benefits paid for by the employer.
OFFICERS: Persons who hold an elected or appointed office pursuant to statute
or appointed to an office which is established and the qualifications and
duties of which are prescribed by statute, with or without compensation, to
discharge a public duty for the village including elected officials and
appointed officers.
POLITICAL ACTIVITY: Any activity in support of or in connection with any
campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not
include activities:
   A.   Relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or
administrative action;
   B.   Relating to collective bargaining; or
   C.   That are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties.
POLITICAL ORGANIZATION: A party, committee, association, fund, or other
organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement
of organization with the state board of elections or a county clerk under
section 9-3 of the election code 4 , but only with regard to those activities
that require filing with the state board of elections or county clerk.
PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITY: A. Preparing for, organizing, or participating
in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration, or other
political event.
   B.   Soliciting contributions including, but not limited to, the purchase
of, selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political
fundraiser, political meeting, or other political event.
   C.   Soliciting, planning the solicitation of, or preparing any document or
report regarding any thing of value intended as a campaign contribution.
   D.   Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in
connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political
organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question.
   E.   Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in
an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign
for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political
purposes or for or against any referendum question.
   F.   Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political
organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum
question.
   G.   Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a
political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in
an effort to get voters to the polls.
   H.   Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or
filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or
against any referendum question.
   I.   Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in
that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office.
   J.   Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires in
connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political
organization for political purposes.
   K.   Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign
literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any
candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question.
   L.   Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum
question.
   M.   Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against
any referendum question.
   N.   Serving as a delegate, alternate, or proxy to a political party
convention.
   O.   Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any
election.
PROHIBITED SOURCE: Any person or entity who:
   A.   Is seeking official action:
      1.   By an officer; or
      2.   By an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that
employee;
   B.   Does business or seeks to do business:
      1.   With the officer; or
      2.   With an employee, or with the officer or another employee directing
that employee;
   C.   Conducts activities regulated:
      1.   By the officer; or
      2.   By an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that
employee; or
   D.   Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or
nonperformance of the official duties of the covered individual.
   E.   Is an agent of a spouse, or an immediate family member who is a
"prohibited source". (2016 Code)

1 1. 10 ILCS 5/1-3.
2 2. 5 ILCS 315/3.
3 1. 10 ILCS 5/9-1.4.
4 1. 10 ILCS 5/9-3.
1-8-3: FINANCIAL INTEREST IN VILLAGE CONTRACTS OR PROPERTY:
   A.   Prohibited Interests:
      1.   No covered individual shall be interested, directly or indirectly,
in his or her own name or in the name of any other person, association, trust
or corporation, in any contract, work or business of the village, or in the
sale of any article, whenever the expense, price or consideration of the
contract, work, business or sale is paid either from the village treasury or by
any assessment levied by statute or village ordinance.
      2.   No covered individual shall be interested, directly or indirectly,
in the purchase of any property which:
         a.   Belongs to the village; or
         b.   Is sold for taxes or assessments; or
         c.   Is sold by virtue of legal process at the suit of the village.
   B.   Exemptions For Village President And Trustees: (The dollar amounts
included in the following paragraphs are those provided by state law.):
      1.   Less Than Seven And One-Half Percent Ownership Share: Any elected or
appointed village president or village trustee may provide materials,
merchandise, property, services or labor to the village if:
         a.   The contract is with a person, firm, partnership, corporation or
cooperative association in which such interested member of the governing body
of the village has less than a seven and one-half percent (71/2%) share in the
ownership; and
         b.   Such interested member publicly discloses the nature and extent
of his or her interest prior to or during deliberations concerning the proposed
award of the contract; and
         c.   Such interested member abstains from voting on the award of the
contract (though the member shall be considered present for the purpose of
establishing a quorum); and
         d.   Such contract is approved by a majority vote of those members
presently holding office; and
         e.   The contract is awarded after sealed bids to the lowest
responsible bidder if the amount of the contract exceeds one thousand five
hundred dollars ($1,500.00), but the contract may be awarded without bidding if
the amount is less than one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00); and
         f.   The award of the contract would not cause the aggregate amount of
such contracts so awarded to the same person, firm, association, partnership,
corporation, or cooperative association in the same fiscal year to exceed
twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00).
      2.   Contracts For Less Than Two Thousand Dollars: Any elected or
appointed village president or village trustee may provide materials,
merchandise, property, services or labor if:
         a.   The award of the contract is approved by a majority vote of the
governing body of the village; provided, that any such interested member shall
abstain from voting; and
         b.   The amount of the contract does not exceed two thousand dollars
($2,000.00); and
         c.   The award of the contract would not cause the aggregate amount of
all such contracts so awarded to the same person, firm, association,
partnership, corporation, or cooperative association in the same fiscal year to
exceed four thousand dollars ($4,000.00); and
         d.   Such interested member publicly discloses the nature and extent
of his or her interests prior to or during deliberations concerning the
proposed award of the contract.
         e.   The interested member abstains from voting on the contract
(though the member shall be considered present for the purpose of establishing
a quorum).
      3.   Public Utility Services: A contract for the procurement of public
utility services by the village with a public utility company is not barred by
this section by one or more members of the corporate authorities being a
covered individual of the public utility company or holding an ownership
interest of no more than seven and one-half percent (71/2%) in the public
utility company.
      4.   Financial Services With A Local Bank: Nothing contained in this
section shall preclude a contract of deposit of monies, loans or other
financial services by the village with a local bank or local savings and loan
association, regardless of whether the village president or a trustee is
interested in such bank or savings and loan association as a covered individual
or as a holder of less than seven and one-half percent (71/2%) of the total
ownership interest. Such interested member of the corporate authorities must
publicly state the nature and extent of his or her interest during
deliberations concerning the proposed award of such a contract, but shall not
participate in any further deliberations concerning the proposed award. A
member abstaining from participation in deliberations and voting under this
subsection may be considered present for purposes of establishing a quorum.
Such interested member or members shall not vote on such a proposed award. The
award of such a contract shall require approval by a majority vote of those
members presently holding office. Consideration and award of any such contract
in which a member or members are interested may only be made at a regularly
scheduled public meeting of the village board of trustees.
   C.   Exemptions For Employees Or Committee Or Commission Members: Any
employee or committee or commission member may provide materials, merchandise,
property, services or labor if:
      1.   Less Than Seven And One-Half Percent Ownership Share:
         a.   The contract is with a person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, or cooperative association in which such employee has less than a
seven and one-half percent (71/2%) share in the ownership; and
         b.   The contract is awarded after sealed bids to the lowest
responsible bidder if the amount of the contract exceeds one thousand five
hundred dollars ($1,500.00), or awarded without bidding if the amount of the
contract is less than one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00); and
         c.   The award of the contract would not cause the aggregate amount of
all such contracts so awarded to the same person, firm, association,
partnership, corporation or cooperative association in the same fiscal year to
exceed twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00).
      2.   Contracts For Less Than Two Thousand Dollars: In addition, any
employee or committee or commission member may provide materials, merchandise,
property, services or labor, regardless of the size of ownership interest the
employee or committee or commission member may have in the contracting entity,
if:
         a.   The amount of the contract does not exceed two thousand dollars
($2,000.00); and
         b.   The award of the contract would not cause the aggregate amount of
all such contracts so awarded to the same person, firm, association,
partnership, corporation, or cooperative association in the same fiscal year to
exceed four thousand dollars ($4,000.00).
      3.   Public Utility Contracts: A contract for the procurement of public
utility services by the village with a public utility company is not barred by
this section when an employee or committee or commission member is also a
covered individual of the public utility company, or when an employee or
committee or commission member holds an ownership interest of any size in the
public utility company.
      4.   Financial Services By A Local Bank: Nothing in this section shall
preclude a contract of deposit of monies, loans or other financial services by
the village with a local bank or local savings and loan association regardless
of whether a village employee or committee or commission member is interested
in such bank or savings and loan association as a covered individual or a
holder of an ownership interest of any size in such an institution.
      5.   Purchase Of Property At Auction: Nothing in this section shall
prohibit any employee or committee or commission member from bidding on and
purchasing property auctioned by the village at an auction open to all members
of the general public, whether the auction is sponsored by the village or by an
association of municipalities, such as the Northwest Municipal Conference.
(2016 Code)
1-8-4: DISCLOSURE OF ECONOMIC INTERESTS:
All elected officials, appointed officers, commissioners, committee members and
employees required to file economic disclosure statements with the county clerk
pursuant to article 4A of the Illinois governmental ethics act 1 , shall be in
violation of this code of ethics if they fail to comply with and fulfill the
requirements set forth in the state act. (2016 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 420/4A-101 et seq.
1-8-5: INCOMPATIBILITY OF OFFICE OR EMPLOYMENT:
No covered individual shall hold another office or position of employment where
the duties of either office or employment are such that the holder cannot, in
every instance, properly and faithfully perform all of the duties of the other
office or position of employment in accordance with federal and state laws.
This section is not intended to automatically exclude a village employee from
holding an appointed office or position with a local board, commission or
