including video gaming terminals authorized pursuant to the video gaming act 1
, and specifically excludes coin operated devices used for the laundering and
drying of clothes or the dispensing of vehicle fuel or use of air pumps or
vacuums at a fueling station.
LICENSE: The license required by this chapter for a coin operated device or
license for video gaming device(s) authorized pursuant to the video gaming act
and this code.
OPERATOR: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or association who sets up
for the operation by another or leases or distributes for the purpose of
operation by another, any device as herein defined, whether such setting up for
operation, leasing or distributing be for a fixed charge or rental, or on the
basis of a division of the income derived from such device, or otherwise.
PROPRIETOR: Any individual, firm, corporation or other business that owns the
establishment where the coin operated machine is located. (Ord. 15-10, 2-3-
2015, eff. 5-1-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.
4-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, firm, or corporation shall install, maintain, operate, use, or
permit to be used any coin operated device or video gaming terminal in the
village authorized pursuant to this chapter and the video gaming act 1  without
first having obtained a license. (Ord. 15-10, 2-3-2015, eff. 5-1-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.
4-4-3: LICENSE FEES:
   A.   Established: The various kinds of coin operated devices for which a
license shall be required, and the annual license fee for such devices, shall
be as established in the annual fee schedule.
   B.   Payment Of Fees: The license fee shall be payable annually in advance;
provided, that where the application is made after the expiration of any
portion of any license year, a license may be issued for the remainder thereof
upon payment of a proportionate part of the annual fee.
   C.   Exemptions From Fees: No license fee shall be charged to any
governmental entity that applies for a coin operated device license(s);
however, all other provisions relative to the licensing process as set forth in
this chapter shall be applicable to governmental entities. (Ord. 15-10, 2-3-
2015, eff. 5-1-2015; amd. 2016 Code; Ord. 20-50, 10-6-2020; Ord. 22-03, 2-1-
2022)
4-4-4: LICENSING PROCEDURE:
   A.   Application For License:
      1.   Application for a license hereunder shall be filed in writing with
the village clerk, on a form to be provided by the village, and shall specify:
         a.   The name and address of the applicant, and if a firm,
corporation, partnership or association, the principal officers thereof and
their addresses;
         b.   The address of the premises where the licensed device or devices
are to be operated, together with the character of the business as carried on
at such place;
         c.   The trade name and general description of the device or devices
to be licensed, the name of the manufacturer and the serial number and, if the
applicant is a proprietor, the number of devices to be licensed;
         d.   The name and address of the operator of the device or devices if
other than the proprietor.
      2.   The proper license fee and investigation fee shall accompany the
application.
      3.   Licenses are not transferable without an application and approval by
the village.
   B.   Investigations And Inspections:
      1.   Upon receipt of an application for a license, the village clerk
shall provide a copy of the application and refer the matter to the chief of
police for an investigation of the character of the individuals whose names and
addresses are required to be furnished by subsection A of this section.
      2.   The village clerk shall furnish a copy of the application and refer
the matter to the code enforcement officer to determine whether the proposed
business will violate any provision of the zoning code or the building code of
the village.
      3.   The chief of police and the code enforcement officer shall report
within two (2) weeks of receipt of a complete application.
      4.   The application, together with the report of the chief of police and
the report of the code enforcement officer, shall be delivered to the village
clerk for action.
   C.   Issuance Or Denial Of License: If it appears that the applicant
complies with all applicable laws and ordinances, the license application shall
be approved and the license shall be issued by the village clerk. If the
license is denied, the license fee shall be returned to the applicant.
   D.   Evidence Of Ownership: Evidence of ownership must be filed with the
village clerk. Any proprietor who owns such device or devices shall file with
the village clerk evidence of such ownership prior to the issuance of a
license, and any proprietor purchasing a device or devices shall file with the
village clerk evidence of ownership thereof before exhibiting or placing said
device or devices for use or play.
   E.   Expiration, Posting, Nontransferability Of License: All licenses under
this chapter shall expire on December 31 following their issuance. The license
shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the establishment of the licensee.
Such license shall be nonassignable and nontransferable and, in the case of a
proprietor, shall apply only to the premises for which such license is issued.
A licensee may apply for a transfer of a license for a replacement device if
the following conditions are met:
      1.   The original device is permanently removed from display for public
patronage and is made unavailable for operation by patrons; and (Ord. 15-10, 2-
3-2015, eff. 5-1-2015)
      2.   A transfer fee as established in the annual fee schedule is paid to
the village.
   F.   No Refunds Of Fees: Except as provided in subsection C of this section,
in no case shall any portion of said license fee be refunded to the licensee.
(Ord. 15-10, 2-3-2015, eff. 5-1-2015; amd. 2016 Code)
4-4-5: DISPLAY OF NOTICE:
Every coin operated device for which a license is issued pursuant to the terms
of this chapter shall bear and have attached thereto in a prominent place the
following notice:
This device is for amusement purposes only. The use of this device for gambling
purposes or other purposes which may be illegal shall be prosecuted to the full
extent of the law.
(Ord. 15-10, 2-3-2015, eff. 5-1-2015)
4-4-6: RESTRICTIONS ON LICENSE:
   A.   No license issued hereunder shall permit the operation of any coin
operated amusement device at any place or in any manner which will disturb the
peace or quiet of persons outside the licensed premises. It shall be unlawful
for a licensee to allow a degree of noise to develop which would cause a
disturbance to the adjacent or surrounding uses such that normal use of said
adjacent or surrounding uses would be damaged or unreasonably disturbed.
   B.   All coin operated devices must be kept in good repair and operating
condition.
   C.   No license issued hereunder shall permit the operation of any coin
operated amusement device unless the premises where the coin operated amusement
device(s) is located has a distinct and primary business use other than the
offering of coin operated amusement devices.
   D.   Any coin operated amusement device installed in the business
establishment for which a license is issued pursuant to the terms of this
chapter shall be located within the main business area of the establishment and
shall specifically not be located in any foyer, vestibule, entranceway or other
portion of the establishment appurtenant to the main business area. (Ord. 15-
10, 2-3-2015, eff. 5-1-2015)
4-4-7: INSPECTIONS:
Any person, firm, corporation or association who files an application for a
coin operated amusement device, or renewal thereof, agrees to an inspection of
the premises to ascertain whether or not the device is in compliance with this
code. (Ord. 15-10, 2-3-2015, eff. 5-1-2015)
4-4-8: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
   A.   Nuisance Declared: Any violation of this chapter is declared to be a
nuisance.
   B.   Suspension Or Revocation Of License: The village shall have the right
to suspend or revoke any license issued hereunder or take such appropriate and
necessary action pursuant to this code as may be warranted for the violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter or for any other ordinance or statutory
violations. Any licensee that has its license revoked or canceled under this
chapter shall not be eligible to apply for any other license under this chapter
for a period of one year. (Ord. 15-10, 2-3-2015, eff. 5-1-2015; amd. 2016 Code)
CHAPTER 5
CANVASSERS, PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Purpose
4-5-2: Definitions
4-5-3: License Required; Exemptions
4-5-4: License For Sponsoring Juvenile Peddlers
4-5-5: Application For License
4-5-6: License Fee
4-5-7: Review Of Application; Issuance Of License; Records Kept
4-5-8: Denial Of License
4-5-9: Expiration Of License
4-5-10: Identification Badges; License Exhibited
4-5-11: Nontransferability Of License
4-5-12: Uninvited Canvassing, Peddling Or Soliciting
4-5-13: Prohibited Hours
4-5-14: Street Solicitations
4-5-15: Revocation Or Suspension Of License
4-5-16: Appeals
4-5-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of this chapter to protect against criminal activity,
including fraud and burglary, minimize the unwelcome disturbance of residents
and the disruption of privacy, and to otherwise preserve the public health,
safety, and welfare by regulating, controlling, and licensing door to door
solicitors and peddlers. (2016 Code)
4-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms, and phrases and their derivations, when used in
this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except
where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
CANVASSER: Any person who goes from door to door to engage in purely expressive
speech, such as advocacy for a particular religion, philosophy, ideology,
political party, issue, candidate, or other cause.
CHARITABLE: Means and includes the words patriotic, philanthropic, social
service, health, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic, cultural, or
fraternal, either actual or purported.
CONTRIBUTIONS: Means and includes the words alms, money, subscription,
property, or any donations under the guise of loan or money or property.
PEDDLER: Any person who goes upon the premises of any private residence in the
village, not having been invited by the occupant thereof, carrying or
transporting goods, wares, merchandise, or personal property of any nature, and
offering the same for sale. This definition also includes any person who
solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as
part of the scheme to evade the provisions of this chapter. Peddler does not
include a person who distributes handbills or fliers for a commercial purpose,
advertising an event, activity, good, or service that is offered to a resident
for purchase at a location away from his/her residence or at a time different
from the time of the visit.
PEDDLING: Includes all activities ordinarily performed by a "peddler" as
defined in this section.
PERSON: A natural person or any firm, corporation, association, club, society,
or other organization.
SOLICITOR: Any person who goes upon the premises of any private residence in
the village, not having been invited by the occupant thereof, for the purpose
of taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, merchandise,
wares, or other personal property of any nature for future delivery, or for
services to be performed in the future. This definition also includes any
person who, without invitation, goes upon private property to request
contribution of funds or anything of value, or to sell goods or services for
political, charitable, religious, or other noncommercial purposes. (2016 Code;
amd. Ord. 19-16, 5-7-2019)
4-5-3: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person eighteen (18) years of age or older
to engage in peddling or solicitation activities within the village without
first obtaining a license issued by the village clerk; provided, however, that
the following are exempted from the provisions of this section:
      1.   Any solicitation made upon premises owned or occupied by an
organization upon whose behalf the solicitation is made;
      2.   Any communication by an organization soliciting contributions solely
from persons who are members of the organization at the time of such
solicitation;
      3.   Any solicitation in the form of a collection at a regular meeting,
assembly, or service of a charitable person;
      4.   Any solicitation for the relief of any individual specified by name
at the time of the solicitation where the solicitor represents in each case
that the entire amount collected shall be turned over to the named beneficiary;
or
      5.   A "canvasser".
   B.   Any person claiming to be legally exempt from the regulations set forth
in this chapter or from the payment of a license fee shall cite to the village
clerk the statute or other legal authority under which exemption is claimed and
shall present to the village clerk proof of qualification for such exemption.
(2016 Code; amd. Ord. 19-16, 5-7-2019)
4-5-4: LICENSE FOR SPONSORING JUVENILE PEDDLERS:
   A.   No person under the age of eighteen (18) shall be permitted to engage
in peddling except as provided in this section.
   B.   A license shall be obtained by a sponsoring person, company, or
organization for the conduct of any peddling or solicitation activities
involving, in whole or in part, a sales force of one or more persons under
eighteen (18) years of age.
   C.   The sponsor shall be responsible for supervising and controlling the
conduct of all persons, including juveniles, peddling under the sponsor's
license.
   D.   The sponsor shall provide to each individual in its sales force a badge
or other easily readable form of identification which identifies the name of
the sponsor and the name of the individual. The sponsor shall require all
individuals in its sales force to wear such identification so that it is
clearly visible at all times when the individuals are peddling or soliciting.
   E.   The sponsor shall comply with the requirements of the state of Illinois
child labor law 1 . (2016 Code; amd. Ord. 19-16, 5-7-2019)
 
Notes
1 1. 820 ILCS 205/1 et seq.
4-5-5: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Every person subject to the provisions of this chapter shall file with the
village clerk an application in writing on a form to be furnished by the
village, which shall provide the following information:
   A.   Proof of age, address, and identification of the applicant, to be
provided through the applicant's driver's license or state identification,
articles of incorporation (for sponsors), or another legally recognized form of
identification and make and license number of the applicant's motor vehicles
used during the peddling or solicitation activities;
   B.   A brief description of the business or activity to be conducted;
   C.   The dates, hours, and location for which the right to peddle or solicit
is desired;
   D.   If employed, the name, address, and telephone number of the employer;
or if acting as an agent, the name, address, and telephone number of the
principal who is being represented, with credentials in written form
establishing the relationship and the authority of the employee or agent to act
for the employer or principal, as the case may be;
   E.   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a
felony, misdemeanor, or ordinance violation (other than traffic violations),
the nature of the offense or violation, the penalty or punishment imposed, the
date when and place where such offense occurred, and other pertinent details
thereof; and
   F.   Proof of possession of any license or permit which, under federal,
state, or local laws or regulations, the applicant is required to have in order
to conduct the proposed businesses, or which, under any such law or regulation,
would exempt the applicant from the license requirements of this chapter. (2016
Code; amd. Ord. 19-16, 5-7-2019)
4-5-6: LICENSE FEE:
At the time the application is filed with the village clerk, the applicant
shall pay a fee to cover the cost to the village of processing the application
and investigating the facts stated therein. The license fee shall be as
provided in the annual fee schedule. (2016 Code; amd. Ord. 19-16, 5-7-2019)
4-5-7: REVIEW OF APPLICATION; ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; RECORDS KEPT:
   A.   Upon receipt of an application, the village clerk, or authorized
representative, shall review the application as deemed necessary to ensure the
protection of the public health, safety, and general welfare. A determination
shall be made within two (2) business days.
   B.   If the village clerk finds the application to be satisfactory, the
village clerk shall endorse his approval on the application and shall, upon
payment of the prescribed fee, deliver the required license to the applicant.
   C.    The license shall show the name of the applicant, the date of
issuance, and the length of time the license will be in effect. (2016 Code;
amd. Ord. 19-16, 5-7-2019))
4-5-8: DENIAL OF LICENSE:
   A.    Upon the village clerk's review of the application, the village clerk
may refuse to issue a license to the applicant under this chapter for any of
the following reasons:
      1.   Incomplete applications will not be reviewed;
      2.   An investigation reveals that the applicant falsified information on
the application;
      3.   The applicant has been convicted within the past five (5) years of a
felony or class A misdemeanor, the nature of which is related to the
applicant's fitness to engage in door to door activities under this chapter.
The applicant shall be of good character and reputation without a conviction
related to fraud, dishonesty, deceit, misrepresentation, sexual misconduct,
trafficking in controlled substances, violent acts against persons or property,
or offense involving moral turpitude.
      4.   In reviewing fitness under subsection A3 of this section, the
following shall be considered:
         a.   The extent and nature of the applicant's past criminal activity;
         b.   The age of the applicant at the time of the commission of the
crime;
         c.   The amount of time that has elapsed since the applicant's last
criminal activity;
         d.   The conduct and work activity of the applicant prior to and
following the criminal activity;
         e.   Evidence of the applicant's rehabilitation or rehabilitative
effort while incarcerated or following release; and
         f.   Other evidence of the applicant's present fitness;
      5.   There is no proof as to the authority of the applicant to serve as
an agent to the principal; or
      6.   The applicant has been denied a license under this chapter within
the immediate past year, unless the applicant can and does show to the
satisfaction of the village clerk that the reasons for such earlier denial no
longer exist.
   B.   The village clerk's disapproval and the reasons for disapproval shall
be noted on the application, and the applicant shall be notified that his
application is disapproved and that no license will be issued. Notice shall be
given to the applicant at the phone number or address shown on the application
form, or at the applicant's last known address. (2016 Code; amd. Ord. 19-16, 5-
7-2019)
4-5-9: EXPIRATION OF LICENSE:
All licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire thirty
(30) days from the date of issuance, unless an earlier or later expiration date
is noted on the license. (2016 Code; amd. Ord. 19-16, 5-7-2019)
4-5-10: IDENTIFICATION BADGES; LICENSE EXHIBITED:
   A.   Identification Badges:
      1.   At the same time the license is issued, the village clerk shall
issue to each licensee a badge, which shall be worn by the licensee in such a
way as to be conspicuous at all times while the licensee is soliciting or
peddling in the village.
      2.   A canvasser otherwise exempt from the provisions of this chapter may
request the issuance of an identification badge from the village for the
purpose of assuring village residents of the canvasser's identity.
   B.   License Exhibited: Every person required to obtain a license under the
provisions of this chapter shall exhibit the license when requested to do so by
any prospective customer or police department employee. (2016 Code; amd. Ord.
19-16, 5-7-2019)
4-5-11: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE:
It shall be unlawful for any person other than the licensee to use or wear any
license or badge issued under the provisions of this chapter. (2016 Code; amd.
Ord. 19-16, 5-7-2019)
4-5-12: UNINVITED CANVASSING, PEDDLING OR SOLICITING:
It shall be unlawful for any person, whether licensed or unlicensed, while
conducting the business of a canvasser, peddler, or solicitor, to enter upon
any residential premises in the village where the owner, occupant, or person
legally in charge of the premises has posted, at the entry to the premises, or
at the entry to the principal building on the premises, a sign bearing the
words "No Peddlers" or "No Solicitors" or words of similar import. (2016 Code;
amd. Ord. 19-16, 5-7-2019)
4-5-13: PROHIBITED HOURS:
No person, while conducting the activities of a peddler or solicitor, whether
licensed or unlicensed, shall enter upon any private property, knock on doors,
or otherwise disturb persons in their residences between the hours of eight
o'clock (8:00) P.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. the following day, Monday
through Saturday or at any time on Sunday or a state holiday. (2016 Code; amd.
Ord. 19-16, 5-7-2019)
4-5-14: STREET SOLICITATIONS:
   A.   Commercial Street Solicitations: It shall be unlawful to engage in
commercial solicitation on any street or highway right of way within the
village.
   B.   Charitable Street Solicitations: It shall be unlawful to engage in
charitable solicitation on street or highway rights of way within the village
before the hour of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. or later than six o'clock (6:00)
P.M. during the months of September through March or before the hour of six
o'clock (6:00) A.M. or after the hour of eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. during the
months of April through August.
   C.   Further Limitations On Charitable Street Solicitations:
      1.   The soliciting agency shall be registered with the attorney general
as a charitable organization as provided by the solicitation for charity act 1
and engaged in a statewide fundraising activity.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in charitable
solicitation on any street or highway within the village for more than a period
of two (2) consecutive days or more than two (2) such two (2) day periods a
year.
      3.   No vehicles of the solicitors or related to the solicitation shall
be permitted to be parked within the village rights of way.
      4.   The village reserves the right to impose any condition or
restriction on the solicitation to take into account the orderly flow of
traffic and prevent interference with official traffic control devices, as
determined by the chief of police or his designee, taking into account road
conditions, accident rates, traffic volumes, or other unsafe conditions.
      5.   A certificate of insurance shall also be provided from an insurance
company licensed to do business in Illinois, insuring the solicitors and
organizations for liability for damages causally related to an act of ordinary
negligence of the soliciting agent. The certificate must state that it shall
not be canceled during the period of solicitation and will provide at least the
following coverage:
         a.   Personal injury: Five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per
person; one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence.
         b.   Property damage: One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00).
      6.   It shall be unlawful to solicit on any highway or street within the
village except at intersections where all traffic is required to come to a full
stop.
      7.   It shall be unlawful for any individual to solicit on any highway,
street, or sidewalk within the village who is under sixteen (16) years of age
and who is not wearing a high visibility vest.
      8.   It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit on any highway or
street without a solicitation license. (2016 Code; amd. Ord. 19-16, 5-7-2019)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 460/0.01 et seq.
4-5-15: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
Any license issued under this chapter may be revoked or suspended, after notice
and hearing, for any of the following reasons:
   A.   Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the
application for a license;
   B.   Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement made by the licensee in
the course of conducting solicitation or peddling activities;
   C.   Conducting peddling or solicitation activities contrary to the
provisions contained in the license;
   D.   Conviction for any crime involving moral turpitude; or
   E.   Conducting peddling or solicitation activities in such a manner as to
create a public nuisance, constitute a breach of the peace, or endanger the
health, safety, or general welfare of the public. (2016 Code; amd. Ord. 19-16,
5-7-2019)
4-5-16: APPEALS:
   A.   Any person aggrieved by the action or decision of the village clerk to
deny, suspend, or revoke a license applied for under the provisions of this
chapter shall have the right to appeal such action or decision to the village
president within fifteen (15) days after the notice of the action or decision
has been mailed to the person's address as shown on the license application
form, or to his last known address.
   B.   An appeal shall be taken by filing with the village clerk a written
statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal.
   C.   The village clerk shall transmit the written statement to the village
president within ten (10) days of its receipt, and the village president shall
set a time and place for a hearing on the appeal as provided in this chapter.
   D.   A hearing shall be set not later than twenty (20) days from the date of
receipt of the appellant's written statement. (2016 Code; amd. Ord. 19-16, 5-7-
2019)
CHAPTER 6
TAXICABS; VEHICLES FOR HIRE
SECTION:
4-6-1: License Required
4-6-2: Ineligibility For License
4-6-3: Application For License; Investigation
4-6-4: License Fee
4-6-5: Bond Or Insurance Required
4-6-6: Register Kept
4-6-7: Vehicle Requirements
4-6-8: Meters And Fares
4-6-9: Operation Of Taxicab
4-6-10: Conduct Of Drivers
4-6-11: Use Of Stands Restricted
4-6-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful to conduct or operate the business of hackman, cabman, or to
conduct a taxicab business, or to operate a public passenger vehicle for hire
which does not follow a fixed route without having first obtained a license
therefor as provided in this chapter. (1976 Code § 5.90.010)
4-6-2: INELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE:
No such license shall be issued to any person who is not a person of good
character, or to any person who has been convicted of a felony. (1976 Code §
5.90.020)
4-6-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INVESTIGATION:
Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the clerk and shall
comply with the license provisions of chapter 1 of this title. Each application
shall state the name of the applicant, the number of vehicles to be operated,
the estimated number of drivers to be employed, and such other items as may be
required by the village board. Upon receiving such application, the clerk shall
cause an investigation to be made of the character of the applicant. (1976 Code
§ 5.90.020)
4-6-4: LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee for such licenses shall be as established in the annual fee
schedule. Whenever a licensee under this chapter adds to the number of vehicles
which he operates in the village, he shall notify the clerk of this fact, and
shall pay the fee for each additional vehicle. (1976 Code § 5.90.030; amd. 2016
Code)
4-6-5: BOND OR INSURANCE REQUIRED:
Each applicant for a license shall file either a bond, with sureties to be
approved by the village, conditioned that the licensee will pay all final
judgments recovered against him by reason of injury to any person from the
negligence of the licensee, or shall file a policy of insurance in a solvent
company authorized to do business in the state, which shall provide for the
payment and satisfaction of any final judgment rendered against the licensee
for any such negligence. (1976 Code § 5.90.040; amd. 2016 Code)
4-6-6: REGISTER KEPT:
Each licensee under the provisions of this chapter shall keep a register
showing the name of every driver in his employ and showing which vehicle was
operated by each driver. (1976 Code § 5.90.060)
4-6-7: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Sanitary Condition; Required Equipment: All vehicles used for taxicabs
or for the conveyance of passengers for hire must be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition, and must be properly equipped with brakes, lights, and
warning signals.
   B.   Identification:
      1.   The name of the owners of such vehicle shall be printed or painted
in a prominent place on the right hand side of the vehicle, in letters at least
two inches (2") high.
      2.   If any licensee operates more than one such vehicle, each vehicle
shall be numbered, with figures not less than two inches (2") high, but no two
(2) vehicles operated by the same licensee shall bear the same number.
      3.   The names and numbers shall be of such size and color as to be
readily visible from a distance of twenty five feet (25'). (1976 Code §
5.90.050)
4-6-8: METERS AND FARES:
   A.   Meters:
      1.   It is unlawful to operate any vehicle unless the same is equipped
with an accurate meter in good condition to register the distance covered and
the charge for each trip. (1976 Code § 5.90.080)
      2.   Meters shall be inspected by the police chief before being used on a
cab and at least once each six (6) months while in use. (1976 Code § 5.90.080;
amd. 2016 Code)
      3.   Meters shall be placed so as to be readily visible to passengers in
the cab, and shall show thereon the amount of the charge for each trip in such
a way that the passenger can see the same during and at the end of the trip.
(1976 Code § 5.90.100)
   B.   Advance Payment May Be Required: Every owner or driver shall have the
right to demand his fare from the person or persons so employing him on
entering his vehicle, and may refuse to convey any person who does not comply
with the demand. (1976 Code § 5.90.080)
   C.   Receipt For Fare: Any passenger paying a fare shall be entitled to a
receipt showing the amount paid. (1976 Code § 5.90.070)
4-6-9: OPERATION OF TAXICAB:
   A.   Parking On Streets:
      1.   No person in charge of any public taxi or vehicle carrying
passengers for hire shall permit the taxi, except when receiving or discharging
passengers or when instructed by their passengers to do so, to stand on any of
the streets, avenues, or alleys in the village for any period longer than five
(5) minutes except as otherwise provided in this chapter. (1976 Code §
5.90.120)
      2.   No motor vehicles or other vehicles licensed under this chapter
shall be permitted to use any of the public streets of the village as a station
or stand for the carrying on of such business except those portions of the
street designated as a taxi stand. Interurban autobuses may be parked at
reasonable places designated by the village board so as not to impede or block
traffic for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) minutes to receive and
discharge passengers. (1976 Code § 5.90.120; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Soliciting Business Prohibited: It is unlawful for the owner or driver
of any vehicle licensed under this chapter to solicit by word, gesture, or
otherwise the patronage of any person. (1976 Code § 5.90.130; amd. 2016 Code)
   C.   Refusal To Carry Passenger Prohibited: Except as provided in subsection
4-6-8B of this chapter, no owner or driver of any vehicle licensed under this
chapter shall refuse to convey in the village any person with or without
baggage as provided in this chapter, when applied to for that purpose or,
having undertaken to convey such person, omit or neglect to do so. (1976 Code §
5.90.090; amd. 2016 Code)
4-6-10: CONDUCT OF DRIVERS:
It is unlawful for any person driving a taxicab or public passenger vehicle to
conduct himself in other than a cordial manner at all times while so occupied
or while in charge of a vehicle. It is unlawful for any such driver to shout or
yell to prospective passengers or to drivers or operators of other vehicles, or
to use profane or boisterous language. (1976 Code § 5.90.140; amd. 2016 Code)
4-6-11: USE OF STANDS RESTRICTED:
No vehicle of any kind shall stand upon, be parked upon, or make use of any
public taxi or hack stand in the village unless the owner thereof has obtained
a license as provided for in this chapter. (1976 Code § 5.90.110)
CHAPTER 7
CONTRACTORS
SECTION:
4-7-1: Definition
4-7-2: Registration Requirements
4-7-3: Bond And Insurance Requirements
4-7-4: Registration Fee
4-7-5: Exemptions; Determination Of Applicability Of Provisions
4-7-1: DEFINITION:
A "contractor" is any person, firm, or corporation engaged in the construction,
repair or alteration of any building, structure, accessory object, site or
street or sidewalk pavement within the village. For purposes of this chapter,
contractors shall include, but not be limited to, companies engaged in the
business of asphalt, carpentry, concrete, drain laying, electrical, excavating,
fencing, fire control and suppression, general contracting, heating and air
conditioning, landscaping, lawn sprinklers, masonry, plumbing, roofing, sewers,
siding, signs, private alarm installation, water well and pump installation,
irrigation, tank installation and servicing, wrecking, and similar businesses.
Subcontractors shall be considered as contractors for the purpose of this
chapter. The term contractor does not include any architect or engineer acting
within the scope of his or her license. (2016 Code)
4-7-2: REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Generally: No contractor may undertake work within the village for
which a permit is required without first being registered with the village.
Registration shall be accomplished by providing the building official or his or
her designee the name of the business, the type of contracting activity, the
address of the business, evidence of relevant state of Illinois issued or
mandated license or registration, telephone number and name of principal. The
contractor shall also provide evidence of the surety bond and certificate of
insurance required under this chapter. Registration may be accomplished at the
time of application for permit.
   B.   Additional Requirements For Specific Contractors:
      1.   Plumbing Contractors:
         a.   Every contractor performing plumbing work within the village
shall submit a copy of its state of Illinois plumbing license showing an
expiration date not earlier than the application date for the permit for which
it is applying.
         b.   All work of plumbing within buildings in the village shall be
performed by a master plumber or a journeyman plumber under the direction of a
licensed master plumber.
         c.   All work of tile drain laying underground and the building of
masonry catch basins or cesspools shall be performed by a drain layer licensed
to engage in the business of drain laying.
         d.   All work of laying sanitary waste sewers and connecting to
sanitary sewer lines shall be performed by a person licensed and qualified to
engage in the business of laying sanitary sewer lines.
      2.   Electrical Contractors:
         a.   Every electrical contractor performing work within the village
shall submit a copy of his electrical license certified from an established
commission or a certifying municipality in the state of Illinois showing an
expiration date not earlier than the expiration date of the application date
for the permit for which it is applying.
         b.   All electrical work performed within buildings or other
structures in the village shall be performed by persons employed, supervised
and directed by a licensed electrical contractor.
      3.   Roofing Contractors: Every roofing contractor performing work within
the village shall submit to the building official or his designee a certified
copy of his state of Illinois roofing certificate showing an expiration date
not earlier than the expiration date of the application date for the permit for
which it is applying.
      4.   Irrigation Contractors: Irrigation contractors shall submit a copy
of their current state of Illinois department of public health certificate of
registration.
      5.   Sprinkler/Fire Suppression Contractors: Sprinkler/fire suppression
contractors shall submit a copy of their current state of Illinois fire
sprinkler contracting license.
      6.   Alarm Contractors: Alarm contractors shall submit a copy of their
current state of Illinois alarm contractor license. (2016 Code)
4-7-3: BOND AND INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Surety Bond: Each contractor performing work within the village must
provide a surety bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) at the
time of registration. The bond must be issued by a surety approved by the
village and authorized to do business in Illinois, conditioned to indemnify and
hold the village harmless from any loss, damage, claim or liability arising out
of or resulting from the doing or failure to do any act required by the
ordinances of the village, or from any other loss, damage or liability suffered
by the village resulting from the work performed by the contractor. Homeowners
acting as their own contractor will not be required to post a surety bond
unless the permit work has the potential to impact the public right of way or
public easement.
   B.   Insurance: Each contractor performing work within the village shall
submit a current certificate(s) of insurance evidencing the following coverage
in not less than the following amounts:
      1.   Commercial general liability insurance: Five hundred thousand
dollars ($500,000.00) per person and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per
occurrence covering liability arising from premises, operations, independent
contractors, products-completed operations, and personal injury and naming the
village as an additional insured.
      2.   Workers' compensation insurance: In the amounts and coverage
required under Illinois law. (2016 Code)
4-7-4: REGISTRATION FEE:
The registration fee shall be as established in the annual fee schedule based
on a calendar year. (2016 Code)
4-7-5: EXEMPTIONS; DETERMINATION OF APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not require a homeowner to be registered
as a contractor to rehabilitate, alter or repair his or her own home. If, upon
inspection, the village determines that the work is not progressing
satisfactorily in a workmanlike manner with the applicable codes as determined
solely by the village, the village may require that the homeowner immediately
hire a licensed contractor to complete the work in conformance with the
applicable codes. (2016 Code)
CHAPTER 8
OUTDOOR ADVERTISERS
SECTION:
4-8-1: Definition
4-8-2: License Required; Restrictions
4-8-3: Application For License
4-8-4: License Fee
4-8-5: Posting Advertisements; Consent Of Property Owner Required
4-8-6: Billboards
4-8-7: Advertiser Information Required
4-8-8: Maintenance Of Premises
4-8-9: Advertisements Near Highways And Freeways
4-8-10: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
4-8-11: Exemptions
4-8-1: DEFINITION:
The term "outdoor advertiser", as used in this chapter, means any person, firm,
or corporation engaged in the business of placing, posting, or painting any
advertisements, notices, or displays in or on any place for the purpose of
outdoor advertising so that the resultant display is visible from any street,
alley, sidewalk, or other public place in the village. (1976 Code § 5.78.010)
4-8-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; RESTRICTIONS:
It is unlawful for any outdoor advertiser to do business as such in the village
without having first secured a license therefor as required in this chapter. No
license issued under this chapter shall be construed so as to permit the use of
any structures, natural or artificial, which are located in any public street,
sidewalk, alley, or other public place for advertising purposes. (1976 Code §
5.78.020)
4-8-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applications for such licenses shall be accompanied by a list of all places,
including billboards or natural structures to be used, on which it is intended
to place signs or advertisements. This list shall be added to from time to time
by the licensee as the right to post or place advertisements or signs on
additional places is acquired. (1976 Code § 5.78.030)
4-8-4: LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee for such license shall be as established in the annual fee
schedule. (1976 Code § 5.78.040; amd. 2016 Code)
4-8-5: POSTING ADVERTISEMENTS; CONSENT OF PROPERTY OWNER REQUIRED:
It is unlawful to post any advertisement on any premises without the consent of
the owner or occupant of such premises. Such consents must be in writing and be
filed with the village clerk. (1976 Code § 5.78.060)
4-8-6: BILLBOARDS:
   A.   Compliance With Village Regulations: No person shall post or maintain
any advertisement or sign on any billboard or signboard which does not fully
conform to the ordinances of the village. (1976 Code § 5.78.050)
   B.   Annual Engineering Inspection Required: It shall be the duty and
obligation of owners of billboard advertising signs located within the village
to have completed, at the owner's sole expense, a structural engineering
inspection of any such sign owned by such owner within twelve (12) months of
the effective date hereof and then every three (3) years thereafter, and to
provide and furnish to the village within two (2) weeks after said inspection a
copy of the engineering report.
   C.   Village Inspections: The village reserves the right to, from time to
time, conduct its own inspection of billboard advertising signs and either
require the owner of a sign to provide supplemental structural engineering
inspections if the village inspection reasonably reveals the possibility of
some structural deficiency or for the village to hire its own structural
engineer for the purpose of inspecting a billboard advertising sign if the
village reasonably believes such a supplemental inspection is required.
   D.   Insurance Required: Any and all owners of billboard advertising signs
located within the village shall be required to furnish to the village,
annually, at the owner's sole expense, a certificate of general liability
insurance issued by a AAA rated insurance company licensed to do business
within the state of Illinois evidencing that the village is an additional
insured on said policy. (Ord. 00-11, 3-21-2000)
4-8-7: ADVERTISER INFORMATION REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any outdoor advertiser to carry on his business unless the
name of such advertiser is attached, displayed, or printed on all billboards or
signboards used by said advertiser, or in any notice, placard, or advertisement
posted by said advertiser, in such lettering as to be visible from a distance
of at least five feet (5') from the notice or advertisement. (1976 Code §
5.78.100)
4-8-8: MAINTENANCE OF PREMISES:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person engaged in the business of outdoor
advertising to permit any refuse resulting from this work to accumulate
anywhere in the village except by placing it in properly established refuse
receptacles. All refuse resulting from the operation of the business must be
carefully gathered up and properly disposed of.
   B.   It is unlawful to permit any loose or flapping combustible materials to
hang from or be attached to any billboard or signboard or other place used for
display or advertising purposes. (1976 Code § 5.78.070)
   C.   It shall be the duty of every outdoor advertiser to keep all grass and
weeds and other growths, except trees and ornamental shrubbery, cut down so
that the same shall not grow to a greater height than six inches (6") within
six feet (6') of any billboard or signboard used by said advertiser; provided,
that this obligation shall extend only to property controlled by the
advertiser. (1976 Code § 5.78.080; amd. 2016 Code)
4-8-9: ADVERTISEMENTS NEAR HIGHWAYS AND FREEWAYS:
   A.   No person, firm, or corporation shall erect, maintain, or permit to
remain upon any premises, site, or location within five hundred (500) yards
from the nearest boundary line of any through highway, speedway, or freeway
within the limits of the village any billboard, sign, pictorial, or other
display or other advertising device; provided, that this prohibition shall not
extend to or include official warning, direction, or informational signs
erected by municipal, county, township, state, or other governmental agencies,
nor to signs not exceeding four feet by four feet (4' x 4') in dimensions
advertising the sale of all or any part of the particular land on which they
are located or any product manufactured or sold upon the site upon which they
are located or to signs on village property. (1976 Code § 5.78.120; amd. 2016
Code)
   B.   For the purposes of this section, certain thoroughfares within the
village limits, commonly known and described as the Congress Street Highway and
Illinois State Toll Highway, are designated as through highways, speedways,
freeways, or parkways. (1976 Code § 5.78.130)
4-8-10: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Advertising Benches On Public Property: It is unlawful for any person,
firm or corporation to install outdoor benches on parkways, at bus stops, or on
other public property or to decorate, paint or otherwise prepare said outdoor
benches located on public property, whether or not for purposes of advertising,
within the village. (1976 Code § 5.16.010)
   B.   Unlawful Advertising:
      1.   It is unlawful for any outdoor advertiser to post or display any
advertisement of an obscene or immoral character, or any advertisement tending
to promote or cause a riot or breach of the peace, or any advertisement for an
unlawful gathering, or advertisements for unlawful sales. (1976 Code §
5.78.090)
      2.   It is unlawful to advertise any unlawful business or article in the
village.
   C.   Damage To Advertisements:
      1.   It is unlawful to injure or deface any lawful advertisement or
notice. (1976 Code § 5.78.140)
      2.   It is unlawful to mutilate or disfigure any lawful sign or
advertisement in the village. (1976 Code § 5.78.100)
4-8-11: EXEMPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed to apply to the posting
of signs or notices by order of any court or by any public officer in the
performance of his duties. (1976 Code § 5.78.110)
CHAPTER 9
AUCTIONS AND AUCTIONEERS
SECTION:
4-9-1: License Required
4-9-2: License Fees
4-9-3: Conduct Of Auctions
4-9-4: Fraudulent Statements Prohibited
4-9-5: Inspection Of Articles For Sale
4-9-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to engage in the business
of auctioneer or to hold an auction in the village without first having
obtained a license therefor. (1976 Code § 5.36.010)
4-9-2: LICENSE FEES:
The fee for engaging in the business of auctioneer and the fee for holding a
single auction by one who does not have an annual license shall be as
established in the annual fee schedule. (1976 Code § 5.36.020; amd. 2016 Code)
4-9-3: CONDUCT OF AUCTIONS:
All auctions shall be conducted in an orderly manner, and it is unlawful to
create or permit any disturbance or disorderly conduct at any auction. (1976
Code § 5.36.030)
4-9-4: FRAUDULENT STATEMENTS PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person selling goods at auction to make any fraudulent
or untrue statements concerning the goods or articles being sold. (1976 Code §
5.36.040)
4-9-5: INSPECTION OF ARTICLES FOR SALE:
Every article offered for sale at a public auction shall be open to the
inspection of any person wishing to purchase it at some time before or during
the bidding. (1976 Code § 5.36.050)
CHAPTER 10
FLEA MARKETS
SECTION:
4-10-1: Definitions
4-10-2: License Requirements
4-10-3: Records Kept
4-10-4: Construction And Location Standards; Parking And Access
4-10-5: Booth To Be Identified
4-10-6: Restroom Requirements
4-10-7: Trash And Refuse
4-10-8: Unlawful Transactions
4-10-9: Purchases From Minors
4-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings,
unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended:
FLEA MARKET: A market where new or used items are sold from individual
locations, with each location being operated independently from other
locations. Items sold include, but are not limited to, household items,
antiques, rare items, decorations, used books and used magazines.
FLEA MARKET OPERATOR: A person, firm or corporation principally operating a
flea market either as a flea market seller or a renter of space to flea market
sellers.
FLEA MARKET SELLER: A subtenant or renter of space from a flea market operator
for the conduct of flea market business including sales and resales of
described items.
MARKET: A place where goods are sold to the public. (Ord. 98-02, 1-6-1998)
4-10-2: LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Operator's License Required; Fee; Application:
      1.   No person, firm or corporation shall operate the business of renting
space or allocating space to flea market sellers without first obtaining a
license therefor. The cost of the business license, good for a twelve (12)
month period from the date of acquisition, shall be as established in the
annual fee schedule. Applications for licenses shall be made to the village
clerk, and forms shall be provided by the village clerk. (Ord. 98-02, 1-6-1998;
amd. 2016 Code)
      2.   Any person, firm or corporation renting or allocating space to
individual flea market sellers in more than one place of business shall be
required to obtain a license for each place of business including one license
for each location that may be on the same lot or adjacent lots.
   B.   Tax Identification Number For Operators And Sellers: Each and every
flea market operator and flea market seller must provide to the village at time
of an application for a license, a federal tax identification number for their
respective business. (Ord. 98-02, 1-6-1998)
   C.   Seller's Fee: The fee for each individual flea market seller shall be
as established in the annual fee schedule. (Ord. 98-02, 1-6-1998; amd. 2016
Code)
4-10-3: RECORDS KEPT:
Each person required by this chapter to obtain a license shall keep accurate
records of the names and addresses of each flea market seller, together with a
brief description of the type or types of merchandise offered for sale by that
seller. The village reserves the right to require and be shown by the flea
market operator or flea market seller proof of purchase or acquisition of the
particular sale items. (Ord. 98-02, 1-6-1998)
4-10-4: CONSTRUCTION AND LOCATION STANDARDS; PARKING AND ACCESS:
   A.   All individual selling areas (booths) shall be located on individual
stands. Each booth shall contain not more than one hundred (100) square feet of
area.
   B.   A flea market seller must provide adequate off street parking for use
by patrons of the flea market. Such areas shall be furnished at the rate of six
(6) spaces per one thousand (1,000) square feet of gross sales area.
   C.   All flea markets shall be provided with safe, convenient, all season,
dust free, pedestrian access of adequate width for intended use, durable and
convenient to maintain. Sudden changes in alignment and gradient shall be
avoided.
   D.   The floor pavement of the flea market shall be constructed of materials
which will provide an adequate foundation for the placement of flea market
booths, securing against uplift, sliding, rotation and overturning. The flea
market pavement or flooring shall be so constructed and maintained that it will
not heave, shift or settle unevenly under the weight of the flea market booth
or table due to inadequate drainage, vibration or other forces.
   E.   The operation of flea markets shall be restricted to manufacturing
districts as defined in the village zoning code. In the event that the flea
market is an outdoor operation, same is prohibited within one thousand feet
(1,000') of a residential zoned district or of a school or church facility.
(Ord. 98-02, 1-6-1998)
4-10-5: BOOTH TO BE IDENTIFIED:
Each booth or table shall be numbered. (Ord. 98-02, 1-6-1998)
4-10-6: RESTROOM REQUIREMENTS:
There shall be a minimum of one central restroom facility for men and one
central restroom facility for women located on the premises, both being
handicapped accessible. Further, hot and cold water shall be furnished to every
restroom which shall contain the minimum number of fixtures as required by the
village building code. (Ord. 98-02, 1-6-1998)
4-10-7: TRASH AND REFUSE:
There shall be enough trash cans, lined with plastic liners, to accommodate all
the trash thrown away on the premises. All trash shall be removed by a licensed
scavenger at least at the end of each day during which the flea market is open.
In addition, any flea market must comply with all sanitation requirements as
set forth by this code. (Ord. 98-02, 1-6-1998; amd. 2016 Code)
4-10-8: UNLAWFUL TRANSACTIONS:
No person shall sell or offer for sale at any flea market within the village
any goods known to such person to be stolen or illegally acquired. (Ord. 98-02,
1-6-1998)
4-10-9: PURCHASES FROM MINORS:
No flea market seller shall purchase any used household items, antiques or used
articles whatsoever from any person under the age of eighteen (18) years,
unless such person is accompanied by that person's parent or guardian. (Ord.
98-02, 1-6-1998)
CHAPTER 11
GARAGE SALES
SECTION:
4-11-1: Definition
4-11-2: Registration Requirements
4-11-3: Number Of Sales; Number Of Days For Sales
4-11-4: Signs
4-11-5: Outside Storage
4-11-6: Inspections
4-11-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, the term "garage sale" includes all general sales of
goods open to the public, conducted from a residential premises, including, but
not limited to, all sales entitled "garage", "lawn", "yard", "attic", "porch",
"room", "backyard", "patio", "flea market", "rummage", "estate", or "moving"
sale. (2016 Code)
4-11-2: REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS:
No person, firm, or corporation shall allow or conduct a "garage sale", as
defined in section
4-11-1 of this chapter, without registering his/its garage sale with the
village by filing an application with the dates, hours of operation and other
information required to show compliance with this code. The registration
placard issued by the village shall be posted on the property of the sale
visible from the village or state right of way. (2016 Code)
4-11-3: NUMBER OF SALES; NUMBER OF DAYS FOR SALES:
   A.   Not more than three (3) garage sales shall be allowed per calendar year
on any residentially zoned property.
   B.   A garage sale shall not be allowed for more than three (3) consecutive
calendar days. (2016 Code)
4-11-4: SIGNS:
   A.   Garage sale signs shall be considered temporary signs but not subject
to the regulations of subsection 12-13-11D or 12-13-12D of this code.
   B.   Garage sale signs shall not interfere with or obstruct the view of
authorized traffic or pedestrian signs, create a safety hazard nor be located
on governmental or utility signs, poles, trees, fences or other structures in
the public right of way.
   C.   The maximum height of a garage sale sign shall not exceed four feet
(4'), and the maximum sign area of a sign face shall not be more than six (6)
square feet.
   D.   No more than two (2) signs having two (2) sign faces shall be allowed
on the property where the sale is held.
   E.   No more than four (4) signs, each with two (2) sign faces, shall be
allowed on the village rights of way between the curb and sidewalk.
   F.   Garage sale signs shall be removed within twenty four (24) hours after
the end of the sale. (2016 Code)
4-11-5: OUTSIDE STORAGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person in conducting a garage or other occasional
sale on premises zoned or used for residential purposes to:
   A.   Display or store any goods or merchandise outside the dwelling in the
front, side, or corner side yard between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) P.M.
to seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
   B.   Display any goods or merchandise on any public sidewalk or right of
way. (2016 Code)
4-11-6: INSPECTIONS:
A village inspector shall be allowed to inspect the property on which the sale
is held during the days of the sale, and if the sale is not in compliance with
the regulations of this chapter, the inspector may terminate the registration
and close the sale. (2016 Code)
CHAPTER 12
SIDEWALK SALES
SECTION:
4-12-1: Definition
4-12-2: Permit Required; Exceptions
4-12-3: Minimum Requirements
4-12-1: DEFINITION:
The term "sidewalk sale", as used in this chapter, is the sale of goods,
materials and products which are normally sold by a commercial establishment.
(2016 Code)
4-12-2: PERMIT REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for a licensed commercial establishment to conduct a
sidewalk sale without first applying for, at least thirty (30) days in advance
of the sale, and thereafter obtaining a sidewalk sale permit as herein
provided. The outside sale and display along not more than fifty percent (50%)
of the store frontage of seasonal merchandise including, but not limited to,
salt, garden supplies and holiday decorations shall be allowed without a permit
but must comply with all other location requirements of subsection 4-12-3D of
this chapter. (2016 Code)
4-12-3: MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS:
The following regulations shall be the minimum requirements for the issuance
and maintenance of a sidewalk sale permit:
   A.   The applicant must have a valid license for the commercial
establishment, and the sidewalk sale shall be on the licensed property.
   B.   The location for the sale shall only be on the private sidewalks or
other areas of the property owned or controlled by the licensee excluding
required off street parking facilities.
   C.   The permit may be issued for up to five (5) consecutive days. A maximum
of two (2) permits may be issued per calendar year for each licensed commercial
establishment not within a shopping center. A maximum of five (5) permits may
be issued per calendar year for each shopping center, including all its
licensed commercial establishments.
   D.   The area permitted for the sidewalk sale shall:
      1.   Not occupy more than one-half (1/2) of the available width of the
sidewalk.
      2.   Not impede access to the entrance of any building.
      3.   Not be located within ten feet (10') of a fire hydrant or fire
escape.
      4.   Have adequate refuse containers and be maintained in a clean and
sanitary manner.
   E.   The hours of operation shall not be allowed to begin before eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M. or extended after ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. on the same day
unless approved by the village board. (2016 Code)
CHAPTER 13
SELF-SERVICE LAUNDRIES
SECTION:
4-13-1: Definitions
4-13-2: License Required; Application
4-13-3: Hours Of Operation; Attendant Required
4-13-4: Installation Of Equipment
4-13-5: Enforcement Officials
4-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
The term "self-service laundries" or "laundromat", as used in this chapter,
shall be used synonymously and shall mean any establishment in which coin
operated facilities are available for washing clothes or for drying clothes, or
both, and which is open and available to the general public for use. (Ord. 98-
04, 2-3-1998)
4-13-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
It shall be unlawful to establish or operate any self-service (laundromat)
laundries in the village without first having secured a license therefor as
otherwise provided for herein. Applications for such licenses shall comply with
the general provisions relating to applications for business licenses and
permits. (Ord. 98-04, 2-3-1998)
4-13-3: HOURS OF OPERATION; ATTENDANT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to keep any such establishment open for business between
the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and
shall be further unlawful to keep such establishment open for business between
the hours of four o'clock (4:00) P.M. and twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight
unless there is an adult attendant in charge of the premises at all times
during such hours. (Ord. 98-04, 2-3-1998)
4-13-4: INSTALLATION OF EQUIPMENT:
Installation of all equipment in such establishment shall be in conformity with
any and all ordinances and regulations of the village relating to such
installations. (Ord. 98-04, 2-3-1998)
4-13-5: ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS:
It shall be the duty of the village clerk to issue licenses for self-service
(laundromat) laundries and of the village police department to see to the
enforcement of this chapter and to cause such inspection to be made of the
premises as may be necessary for that purpose. (Ord. 98-04, 2-3-1998; amd. 2016
Code)
CHAPTER 14
TOBACCO PRODUCTS SALES
SECTION:
4-14-1: Findings
4-14-2: Scope
4-14-3: Definitions
4-14-4: License Required
4-14-5: Application For License; Fee
4-14-6: Minors
4-14-7: Location
4-14-8: Certain Free Distributions Prohibited
4-14-9: Vending Machines
4-14-10: Responsibility Of Licensee For Agents And Employees
4-14-11: Use Of Premises After Revocation
4-14-1: FINDINGS:
The president and board of trustees expressly find and declare that:
   A.   Cigarette smoking is dangerous to human health;
   B.   There exists substantial scientific evidence that the use of tobacco
products causes cancer, heart disease and various other medical disorders;
   C.   The surgeon general of the United States has declared that nicotine
addiction from tobacco is similar to addiction to cocaine, and is the most
widespread example of drug dependence in this country;
   D.   The director of the National Institute On Drug Abuse concluded that the
majority of the three hundred twenty thousand (320,000) Americans who die each
year from cigarette smoking became addicted to nicotine as adolescents before
the age of legal consent;
   E.   The National Institute On Drug Abuse found that cigarette smoking
precedes and may be predictive of adolescent illicit drug use; and
   F.   The present legislative scheme of prohibiting sales of tobacco products
to persons under the age of eighteen (18) has proven ineffective in preventing
such persons from using tobacco products. (Ord. 98-37, 12-15-1998, eff. 2-1-
1999)
4-14-2: SCOPE:
The enactment of this chapter directly pertains to and is in furtherance of the
health, welfare and safety of the residents of the village, particularly those
residents under twenty one (21) years of age. (Ord. 98-37, 12-15-1998, eff. 2-
1-1999; amd. Ord. 19-30, 7-2-2019)
4-14-3: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them:
TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not
limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco or dipping
tobacco, and any product or device not consisting of or containing tobacco that
provides for the ingestion into the body of nicotine, whether by chewing,
smoking, absorbing, dissolving, inhaling, snorting, sniffing, or any other
means, including, but not way of limitation, what is commonly referred to as e-
cigarettes or vaping.
VENDING MACHINES: Any mechanical, electric or electronic, self-service device
which, upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of payment, dispenses
tobacco products. (Ord. 98-37, 12-15-1998, eff. 2-1-1999; amd. Ord. 19-30, 7-2-
2019)
4-14-4: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail, to give away, deliver
or to keep with the intention of selling at retail, giving away or delivering
tobacco products within the village without having first obtained a tobacco
dealer's license therefor pursuant to this chapter. Such license shall be in
addition to any other license required by this code. (Ord. 98-37, 12-15-1998,
eff. 2-1-1999)
4-14-5: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
Application for a license hereunder shall be made in writing to the village
clerk and shall be processed in accordance with the provisions of chapter 1 of
this title. The license fee for a tobacco dealer's license shall be as set
forth in the annual fee schedule. (Ord. 98-37, 12-15-1998, eff. 2-1-1999; amd.
2016 Code)
4-14-6: MINORS:
   A.   Sales And Delivery To Prohibited; Sign Posted: It shall be unlawful for
any person, including any licensee, to sell, offer for sale, give away or
deliver tobacco products to any person under the age of twenty one (21) years.
Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided for herein shall be
posted by every licensee at or near every display of tobacco products and on or
upon every vending machine which offers tobacco products for sale. Each such
sign shall be plainly visible and shall state:
THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS TO PERSONS UNDER TWENTY-ONE YEARS OF AGE IS
PROHIBITED BY LAW
   B.   Purchase By Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person under the
age of twenty one (21) years to purchase tobacco products, or to misrepresent
his identity or age, or to use any false or altered identification for the
purpose of purchasing tobacco products.
   C.   Possession By Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person under the
age of twenty one (21) years to possess any tobacco products; provided, that
the possession by a person under the age of twenty one (21) years under the
direct supervision of the parent or legal guardian of such person in the
privacy of the parent's or guardian's home shall not be prohibited.
   D.   Employment: It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any officer,
associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to
engage, employ or permit any person under sixteen (16) years of age to sell
tobacco products in any licensed premises. (Ord. 98-37, 12-15-1998, eff. 2-1-
1999; amd. Ord. 19-30, 7-2-2019)
4-14-7: LOCATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away or
deliver tobacco products within one hundred feet (100') of any school,
childcare facility or other building used for education or recreational
programs for persons under the age of twenty one (21) years. (Ord. 98-37, 12-
15-1998, eff. 2-1-1999; amd. Ord. 19-30, 7-2-2019)
4-14-8: CERTAIN FREE DISTRIBUTIONS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any person in the business of selling
or otherwise distributing, promoting or advertising tobacco products, or any
employee or agent of any such licensee or person, in the course of such
licensee's or person's business, to distribute, give away or deliver tobacco
products free of charge to any person on any right of way, park, playground or
other property owned by the village, any school district, any park district or
any public library. (Ord. 98-37, 12-15-1998, eff. 2-1-1999)
4-14-9: VENDING MACHINES:
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or offer for sale, give away or
deliver or to keep with the intention of selling, giving away or delivering
tobacco products by use of a vending machine, unless such vending machine is
equipped with a manual, electric or electronic locking device controlled by the
licensee so as to prevent its operation by persons under the age of twenty one
(21) years. Any premises where access by persons under the age of twenty one
(21) years is prohibited by law, or premises where the public is generally not
permitted and where vending machines are strictly for the use of employees of
the business located at such premises, shall be exempt from the requirements of
this section. (Ord. 98-37, 12-15-1998, eff. 2-1-1999; amd. Ord. 19-30, 7-2-
2019)
4-14-10: RESPONSIBILITY OF LICENSEE FOR AGENTS AND EMPLOYEES:
Every act or omission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of any of
the provisions of this chapter by any officer, director, manager or other agent
or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such
licensee, and such licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such
act or omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally. (Ord. 98-
37, 12-15-1998, eff. 2-1-1999)
4-14-11: USE OF PREMISES AFTER REVOCATION:
When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be
granted to said licensee for the period of six (6) months thereafter for the
conduct of the business of selling "tobacco products", as defined in section
4-14-3 of this chapter, in the premises described in such revoked license.
(Ord. 98-37, 12-15-1998, eff. 2-1-1999)
CHAPTER 15
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
4-15-1: Definitions
4-15-2: Licenses Required; Exemptions
4-15-3: Establishment Licensing Provisions
4-15-4: Posting Licenses
4-15-5: Employment Of Massage Therapists
4-15-6: Facilities Necessary
4-15-7: Operating Requirements
4-15-8: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
4-15-9: Sale, Transfer Or Relocation Of Establishments
4-15-10: Inspections
4-15-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
following meanings ascribed to them respectively:
APPROVED MASSAGE SCHOOL: A facility as defined in section 10 of the massage
licensing act 1 .
EMPLOYEE: Any person over eighteen (18) years of age, other than a massagist,
who renders any service in connection with the operation of a massage business
and receives compensation from the operator of the business or patrons.
LICENSEE: The person to whom a license has been issued to own or operate a
massage establishment.
MASSAGE: Massage or massage therapy as defined in section 10 of the massage
licensing act 2 .
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT: Any establishment having a source of income or
compensation derived from the practice of "massage" as defined in this section
and which has a fixed place of business where any person, firm, association or
corporation engages in or carries on any of the activities as defined in this
section.
MASSAGE THERAPIST: A person as defined in section 10 of the massage licensing
act 3  and may be described in this chapter as massagist, masseur or masseuse.
PATRON: Any person who receives a massage under such circumstances that it is
reasonably expected that he or she will pay money or give any other
consideration therefor.
SEXUAL OR GENITAL AREA: Genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus, or perineum of
any person, or the vulva or breasts of a female. (2016 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 57/10.
2 2. 225 ILCS 57/10.
3 3. 225 ILCS 57/10.
4-15-2: LICENSES REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   Licenses Required:
      1.   Business License: No person shall engage in or carry out the
business of massage for compensation unless he/she has a valid massage
establishment business license issued by the village for each and every
separate office or place of business conducted by such person.
      2.   Massage Therapist License: No person shall engage in massage for
compensation unless he/she has a valid license issued by the massage licensing
board of the state department of financial and professional regulation.
   B.   Exemptions:
      1.   The licensing requirements of this chapter shall not be applicable
to:
         a.   Hospitals, nursing homes and persons holding an unrevoked
certificate to practice the healing arts under the laws of the Illinois
department of financial and professional regulation including, but not limited
to, chiropractors, naprapaths, nurses, occupational therapists, physical
therapists and physicians.
         b.   Any barber, cosmetologist or nail technician lawfully carrying on
their respective business to the extent authorized under a valid unrevoked
license or certificate of registration issued by the state. Provided, this
exemption is only intended to permit normal and customary barber, cosmetologist
or nail technician services which involve incidental physical contact, such as
scalp rubs and facials, which otherwise qualify as massage activities. This
exemption is not intended to include, and does not permit, general massage
activities as part of any barber, cosmetologist or nail technician business
beyond that authorized by the state license or certification.
         c.   Any state registered athletic trainer who administers such
athletic related massage in the normal course of training duties.
      2.   A business which employs or includes not more than one massage
therapist shall not be required to apply for or obtain a massage establishment
license. Such exempt business must be located in a structure which contains no
more than one room where massage activities are performed. Except for
businesses which operate separate and distinct hours of operation, such exempt
businesses must also be the sole massage activity within such structure. Under
no circumstances shall more than two (2) exempt businesses be permitted in any
structure. Provided further, a state massage therapist's license shall be
required for the individual massage therapist performing massage activities in
such exempted business.
      3.   Where massage services are actually performed at the patron's
premises, including the patron's place of business or residence, a massage
therapy clinic license shall not be required for such patron's premises.
However, a state massage therapist's license shall be required for the massage
therapist performing massage activities in such patron's premises. (2016 Code)
4-15-3: ESTABLISHMENT LICENSING PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application For License:
      1.   An application for a license required by this chapter shall be made
in writing under oath to the village clerk on a form prescribed by the village
clerk. All references to the village clerk in this chapter shall be deemed to
include the village clerk or his or her authorized designee. Each application
shall include, but not be limited to, the following information:
         a.   The name of the individual, partnership, corporation or
association applying for a license.
         b.   The residence, phone number, date of birth and driver's license
number of the applicant or partners; or if a corporation or association, the
residence, phone number and driver's license number of the officers and all
shareholders owning more than five percent (5%) of the outstanding shares of
stock.
         c.   The location for which the license is requested.
         d.   Whether the applicant, its partners, officers or listed
shareholders, have been convicted of any criminal offense or ordinance
violation (other than traffic or parking offenses) in any jurisdiction and, if
so, a list of such convictions, with date and prosecuting jurisdiction.
         e.   Such information as required by the chief of police in order to
conduct a criminal history background investigation on the applicant and its
partners, officers or listed shareholders owning more than five percent (5%) of
the outstanding shares of stock.
         f.   Whether the applicant, its partners, officers or listed
shareholders, have held a license or had an interest in a license issued by the
village or any other jurisdiction regulating the purchase or sale of used
property revoked for cause and, if so, list the date of revocation and
jurisdiction.
         g.   A statement whether the applicant has made application for a
similar or other license on premises other than described in the application,
and the disposition of such application.
      2.   The applicant for a massage establishment license required by this
chapter shall pay the village clerk at the time of filing an application a
license fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per calendar year. If at the time
application is made for a license and less than six (6) months of the current
license year shall have expired, the full license fee shall be charged. If more
than six (6) months of such current year shall have expired, a license fee of
one-half (1/2) the full fee shall be charged.
      3.   Each applicant shall be required to submit to fingerprinting by the
police department in connection with the application for a license. The
applicant shall pay the fee as set by the Illinois state police for fingerprint
submissions.
      4.   Upon receipt of an application for a license under this chapter, the
village clerk shall cause a copy thereof to be sent to the chief of police and
the building commissioner both of whom shall report back to the village clerk
in thirty (30) days whether the applicant is in accordance with applicable
village regulations. The investigation by the chief of police shall include,
but not be limited to, conducting a criminal history background investigation
on the applicant and its partners, officers or listed shareholders owning more
than five percent (5%) of the outstanding shares of stock.
   B.   Issuance Of License: Upon approval of the chief of police and building
commissioner, the village clerk shall issue a license for a massage
establishment if all requirements for a massage establishment described in this
chapter are met unless it finds:
      1.   The correct license fees have not been tendered to the village and,
in the case of a check or bank draft, honored with payment upon presentation.
      2.   The operation, as proposed by the applicant, if licensed, would not
comply with all applicable laws, including, but not limited to, the village
building, zoning, and health regulations.
      3.   a. The applicant, if an individual, or any of the stockholders
holding more than five percent (5%) of the stock of the corporation, any of the
officers and directors, or any of the partners, including limited partners, if
the applicant is a partnership, and the manager or other person principally in
charge of the operation of the business, have been convicted of any of the
following offenses or convicted of an offense outside the state that would have
constituted any of the following offenses if committed within the state:
            (1)   An offense involving the use of force and violence upon the
person of another that amounts to a felony.
            (2)   An offense involving sexual misconduct.
            (3)   An offense involving narcotics, dangerous drugs, or dangerous
weapons that amounts to a felony.
         b.   The village may issue a license to any person convicted of any of
the crimes described in subsection B3a of this section if it finds that such
conviction occurred at least five (5) years prior to the date of the
application and the applicant has had no subsequent felony convictions of any
nature and no subsequent misdemeanor or convictions for crimes mentioned in
this subsection B3.
      4.   The applicant has knowingly made any false, misleading, or
fraudulent statement of fact in the license application or in any document
required by the village.
      5.   The applicant has had a massage business, masseur, or other similar
permit or license denied, revoked, or suspended by the village or any other
state or local agency within five (5) years prior to the date of the
application.
      6.   The applicant, if an individual; or any of the officers and
directors if the applicant is a corporation; or any of the partners, including
limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership; and the manager or other
person principally in charge of the operation of the business is not over the
age of eighteen (18) years.
   C.   Time For Approval Or Denial Of Application: The village shall act to
approve or deny an application for the license under this chapter within a
