reasonable period of time and in no event shall the village act to approve or
deny the license later than ninety (90) days from the date that the application
was filed with the village clerk.
   D.   Transfer Of License: No license shall be transferable except with the
consent of the village. An application for such transfer shall be in writing
and shall be accompanied by the fee prescribed in subsection A2 of this
section. The written application for transfer shall contain the same
information as requested for initial application for the license. (2016 Code)
4-15-4: POSTING LICENSES:
   A.   Every massage therapist shall post his or her state license in his/her
work area.
   B.   Every person, corporation, partnership, or association licensed under
this chapter shall display such license in a prominent place. (2016 Code)
4-15-5: EMPLOYMENT OF MASSAGE THERAPISTS:
   A.   No person shall employ as a massage therapist any person unless the
employee has obtained and has in effect a license issued by the massage
licensing board of the department of financial and professional regulation.
   B.   The licensee or person designated by the licensee of a massage
establishment shall maintain a register of all persons employed at any time as
massage therapists and their state licenses. The register shall be available at
the massage establishment to representatives of the village during regular
business hours. (2016 Code)
4-15-6: FACILITIES NECESSARY:
No license to conduct a massage establishment shall be issued unless an
inspection by the village reveals that the establishment complies with each of
the following minimum requirements:
   A.   Construction of rooms used for toilets, tubs, steam baths, and showers
shall be made waterproof and shall be installed in accordance with the village
building code. Plumbing fixtures shall be installed in accordance with the
village plumbing code.
   B.   Floors of wet and dry heat rooms shall be adequately pitched to one or
more floor drains properly connected to the sewer. Dry heat rooms with wooden
floors need not be provided with pitched floors and floor drains.
   C.   A source of hot water must be available within the immediate vicinity
of dry and wet heat rooms to facilitate cleaning.
   D.   The premises shall have adequate equipment for disinfecting and
sterilizing nondisposable instruments and materials used in administering
massages. These nondisposable instruments and materials shall be disinfected
after use on each patron.
   E.   Closed cabinets shall be provided and used for the storage of clean
linens, towels and other materials used in connection with administering
massages. All soiled linens, towels, and other materials shall be kept in
properly covered containers or cabinets, which containers or cabinets shall be
kept separate from the clean storage areas.
   F.   All plumbing shall meet the requirements set forth in the Illinois
state plumbing code.
   G.   Lavatories or washbasins provided with both hot and cold running water
shall be installed in either the toilet room or a vestibule. Lavatories or
washbasins shall be provided with soap and a dispenser and with sanitary
towels.
   H.   All electrical equipment shall be installed in accordance with the
requirements of the village electrical code. (2016 Code)
4-15-7: OPERATING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Every portion of the massage establishment, including appliances and
apparatus, shall be kept clean and operated in a sanitary condition.
   B.   Price rates for all services shall be prominently posted in the
reception area in a location available to all prospective customers.
   C.   All employees, including masseurs and masseuses, shall be clean and
wear clean, nontransparent outer garments covering the sexual and genital
areas. These garments shall be restricted to the massage establishment. A
separate dressing room for each sex must be available on the premises with
individual lockers for each employee. Doors to such dressing rooms shall open
inward and shall be self-closing.
   D.   All massage establishments shall be provided with clean, laundered
sheets and towels in sufficient quantity and shall be laundered after each use
and stored in a sanitary manner.
   E.   No massage establishment granted a license under the provisions of this
chapter shall place, publish, or distribute any advertisement, picture, or
statement which is known or, through the exercise of reasonable care, should be
known to be false, deceptive, or misleading in order to induce any person to
purchase or utilize any professional massage services. (2016 Code)
4-15-8: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   No person granted a license pursuant to this chapter shall operate the
massage establishment under a name not specified in his/her license, nor shall
he/she conduct business under any designation or location not specified in his/
her license.
   B.   No person shall sell, give, dispense, provide, or keep any alcoholic
beverage on the premises of any massage business.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person in a massage parlor to place his or
her hand or hands on, to touch with any part of his or her body, to fondle in
any manner, or massage a sexual or genital part of another person.
   D.   It shall be unlawful for any person in a massage parlor to expose his
or her sexual or genital parts, or portion thereof, to any other person. It
shall also be unlawful for any person in a massage parlor to expose the sexual
or genital parts, or any portions thereof, of any other person.
   E.   It shall be unlawful for any person, while in the presence of any other
person in a massage parlor, to fail to conceal, with a fully opaque covering,
the sexual or genital parts of his or her body.
   F.   It shall be unlawful for any person owning, operating or managing a
massage parlor to knowingly cause, allow, or permit, in or about the massage
parlor, any agent, employee, or any other person under his or her control or
supervision to perform such acts prohibited in this section. (2016 Code)
4-15-9: SALE, TRANSFER OR RELOCATION OF ESTABLISHMENTS:
Upon sale, transfer, or relocation of a massage establishment, the license
shall be null and void unless approved as provided in subsection 4-15-3C of
this chapter; provided, that upon the death or incapacity of the licensee or
any co-licensee of the massage establishment, any heir or devisee of a deceased
licensee, or any guardian of an heir or devisee of a deceased licensee may
continue the business of the massage establishment for a reasonable period of
time not to exceed sixty (60) days to allow for an orderly transfer of the
license. (2016 Code)
4-15-10: INSPECTIONS:
The chief of police or his authorized representatives shall, from time to time,
make inspection of each massage establishment for the purposes of determining
that there is full compliance with the provisions of this chapter. It shall be
unlawful for any permittee to fail to allow the inspection officer access to
the premises or hinder the officer in any manner. (2016 Code)
TITLE 5
HEALTH, SANITATION AND ENVIRONMENT
CHAPTER 1
FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS
ARTICLE A. FOOD STORES
SECTION:
5-1A-1: License And Compliance Required
5-1A-2: State Regulations Adopted
5-1A-3: Unwholesome Food, Unsanitary Conditions Prohibited
5-1A-4: Existing Stores
5-1A-5: New And Reconstructed Stores
5-1A-6: Food From Establishments In Other Jurisdictions
5-1A-1: LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful to operate a food store in the village without first having
obtained a license therefor or without full compliance with the provisions of
this article. (2016 Code)
5-1A-2: STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The latest edition of the food service sanitation code, as published by the
Illinois department of public health (part 750 of 77 Ill. adm. code), together
with all appendices thereto and all subsequent editions or amendments, is
adopted as the regulations governing the sanitation procedures and controls for
the storage, preparation and display of food sold within the village with such
amendments as are hereinafter set forth in this article. (2016 Code)
5-1A-3: UNWHOLESOME FOOD, UNSANITARY CONDITIONS PROHIBITED:
No food store licensee shall offer for sale, or keep for the purpose of selling
or offering for sale, any food of any kind intended for human consumption which
is spoiled, tainted or unwholesome and unfit for human consumption for any
reason, or violate any rule or regulation as provided in the retail food store
sanitation code as adopted in section
5-1A-2 of this article. (2016 Code)
5-1A-4: EXISTING STORES:
No existing food store shall be operated within the village unless it is in
conformance with the requirements of this article; provided, that equipment and
facilities installed in a food store prior to the effective date hereof which
do not fully meet all of the design and construction requirements of this
article shall be deemed acceptable in that establishment if they are in good
repair, capable of being maintained in a sanitary condition, and the food
contact surfaces are nontoxic. (2016 Code)
5-1A-5: NEW AND RECONSTRUCTED STORES:
   A.   All food stores which are hereafter constructed, reconstructed or
extensively altered shall be in conformance in such construction with the
requirements of this article. New and replacement equipment shall meet the
requirements of this article as to construction and installation.
   B.   Properly prepared plans, including equipment specifications and
installation layouts, shall be submitted to the building commissioner for
review and approval before work is begun on the construction of new food stores
or the reconstruction or extensive alteration of existing ones. (2016 Code)
5-1A-6: FOOD FROM ESTABLISHMENTS IN OTHER JURISDICTIONS:
Food from food service establishments or food stores outside the jurisdiction
of the village may be sold within the village if such food service
establishments or food stores are in conformance with the provisions of this
article or with substantially equivalent provisions. To determine the extent of
compliance with such provisions, the building commissioner may accept reports
from the responsible authority in other jurisdictions where such food stores or
food service establishments are located. (2016 Code)
ARTICLE B. FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
5-1B-1: License And Compliance Required
5-1B-2: State Regulations Adopted
5-1B-3: Definition
5-1B-4: Unwholesome Food Prohibited
5-1B-5: Existing Establishments
5-1B-6: New Or Reconstructed Establishments
5-1B-7: Food From Establishments In Other Jurisdictions
5-1B-1: LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful to operate a food service establishment in the village without
first having obtained a license therefor or without full compliance with the
provisions of this article. (2016 Code)
5-1B-2: STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The latest edition of the food service sanitation code (part 750 of 77 Ill.
adm. code), as published by the Illinois department of public health, together
with all appendices thereto and all subsequent editions or amendments, is
adopted as the regulations governing the sanitation procedures and control for
the storage, preparation and serving of food within the village with such
amendments as hereinafter set forth in this article. (2016 Code)
5-1B-3: DEFINITION:
Food service establishments, as defined in the regulations adopted in section
5-1B-2 of this article, shall be amended to include daycare centers, nursing
homes, schools, rehabilitation centers, hospitals and retirement centers. (2016
Code)
5-1B-4: UNWHOLESOME FOOD PROHIBITED:
No food service establishment shall offer for sale, or keep for the purpose of
selling or offering for sale, any food of any kind intended for human
consumption which is spoiled, tainted or unwholesome and unfit for human
consumption for any reason or violate any rule or regulation as provided in the
food service sanitation code as adopted in section
5-1B-2 of this article. (2016 Code)
5-1B-5: EXISTING ESTABLISHMENTS:
No existing food service establishment shall operate within the village unless
it is in conformance with the requirements of this article; provided, that
equipment and facilities installed in a food service establishment prior to the
effective date hereof which do not fully meet all the design and construction
requirements of this article shall be deemed acceptable in that establishment
if they are in good repair, capable of being maintained in a sanitary
condition, and food contact surfaces are nontoxic. (2016 Code)
5-1B-6: NEW OR RECONSTRUCTED ESTABLISHMENTS:
   A.   All food service establishments which are hereafter established,
constructed, reconstructed or substantially altered shall conform in such
construction to the requirements of this article. New and replacement equipment
shall meet the requirements of this article as to design, construction and
installation.
   B.   Complete plans, including equipment specifications and installation
layouts, shall be submitted to the building commissioner for review and
approval before work is begun on the construction of new food service
establishments or the reconstruction or extensive alteration of existing ones.
   C.   The construction, enlargement, alteration or conversion of a building
for use as a food service establishment shall comply with the requirements of
the 2008 edition of the food service design and construction handbook published
in pamphlet form by the DuPage County health department, division of
environmental health. (2016 Code)
5-1B-7: FOOD FROM ESTABLISHMENTS IN OTHER JURISDICTIONS:
Food from food service establishments or food stores located outside the
jurisdiction of the village may be sold within the village if such food service
establishments or food stores are in conformance with the provisions of this
article or with substantially equivalent provisions. To determine the extent of
compliance with such provisions, the building commissioner may accept reports
from the responsible authority in other jurisdictions where such food service
establishments are located. (2016 Code)
ARTICLE C. FOOD DELIVERY VEHICLES
SECTION:
5-1C-1: License Required; Exceptions
5-1C-2: Regulations
5-1C-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to use any vehicle, except vehicles licensed as food or
beverage vending vehicles, for the delivery or sale of food including
nonalcoholic beverages and milk intended for human consumption in the village
without first having secured a license therefor. No license or license fee
shall be required for any vehicle used to deliver foodstuffs from any
establishment which is licensed and inspected as a food store or food service
establishment in the village or licensed by another municipality, but there
shall be compliance with all provisions of this chapter in connection with such
vehicles. (2016 Code)
5-1C-2: REGULATIONS:
   A.   Clean, Sanitary Conditions: All vehicles delivering foodstuffs shall be
kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be thoroughly cleaned each day
after their use.
   B.   Waste Accumulations Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to permit stale
food, decaying matter or any other waste material or product to accumulate in
or on any such vehicle.
   C.   Carrying Unwrapped Foodstuffs: If unwrapped foodstuffs are transported
in any such vehicle, such goods shall be carried in a portion or compartment of
the vehicle which is screened and protected against dust and insects. (2016
Code)
ARTICLE D. AUTOMATIC FOOD VENDING MACHINES
SECTION:
5-1D-1: License Required
5-1D-2: Regulations Adopted
5-1D-3: Maintenance Information Posted
5-1D-4: Unwholesome Food, Violations Of Rules Prohibited
5-1D-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall install, keep or maintain an automatic food vending machine in
the village, or permit the installation, keeping, maintenance or use upon his
premises of an automatic food vending machine, without first having obtained a
license therefor. (2016 Code)
5-1D-2: REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The greater standards (most restrictive standards) of the latest edition of the
rules and regulations pertaining to sanitary vending of food and beverages, as
published by the Illinois department of public health (part 743 of 77 Ill. adm.
code), published in pamphlet form, together with the following sections of the
U.S. food and drug administration, 2005 food code, with such subsequent
editions or amendments to either, are adopted as the regulations governing the
sanitation procedures and controls for the storage, preparation and display of
food sold within vending machines and food or beverage vending vehicles as the
regulations of the village. The sections of the U.S. food and drug
administration, 2005 food code, referenced above are as follows:
      (1)   Potentially Hazardous Food. Potentially hazardous food dispensed
through a vending machine shall be in the package in which it was placed at the
food establishment or food processing plant at which it was prepared.
Refrigerated, ready to eat, potentially hazardous food prepared in a food
establishment and dispensed through a vending machine with an automatic shutoff
control shall be discarded if it exceeds a temperature and time combination as
specified in the food code.
      (2)   Condiments. Condiments at a vending machine location shall be in
individual packages or provided in dispensers that are filled at an approved
location, such as the food establishment that provides food to the vending
machine location, a food processing plant that is regulated by the agency that
has jurisdiction over the operation, or a properly equipped facility that is
located on the site of the vending machine location.
      (3)   Vending Machine, Vending Stage Closure. The dispensing compartment
of a vending machine including a machine that is designed to vend prepackaged
snack food that is not potentially hazardous such as chips, party mixes, and
pretzels shall be equipped with a self-closing door or cover if the machine is:
         a.   Located in an outside area that does not otherwise afford the
protection of an enclosure against the rain, windblown debris, insects,
rodents, and other contaminants that are present in the environment; or
         b.   Available for self-service during hours when it is not under the
full-time supervision of a food employee.
            (4)   Can Openers On Vending Machines. Cutting or piercing parts of
can openers on vending machines shall be protected from manual contact, dust,
insects, rodents, and other contamination.
            (5)   Vending Machines, Automatic Shut-Off.
         a.   A machine vending potentially hazardous food shall have an
automatic control that prevents the machine from vending food:
            1.    If there is a power failure, mechanical failure, or other
condition that results in an internal machine temperature that cannot maintain
food temperature as specified in the food code.
            2.   If a condition specified under subsection (5)a.1. of this
section occurs, until the machine is serviced and restocked with food that has
been maintained at temperatures in the food code.
         b.    When the automatic shut off within a machine vending potentially
hazardous food is activated:
            1.   In a refrigerated vending machine, the ambient temperature may
not exceed any time/temperature as specified in the food code.
            2.   In a hot holding vending machine, the ambient temperature may
not be less than 135 degrees F for more than 120 minutes immediately after the
machine is filled, serviced, or restocked.
      (6)   Vending Machines, Liquid Waste Products.
         a.   Vending machines designed to store beverages that are packaged in
containers made from paper products shall be equipped with diversion devices
and retention pans or drains for container leakage.
         b.   Vending machines that dispense liquid food in bulk shall be:
            1.   Provided with an internally mounted waste receptacle for the
collection of drip, spillage, overflow, or other internal wastes; and
            2.   Equipped with an automatic shutoff device that will place the
machine out of operation before the waste receptacle overflows.
         c.   Shutoff devices specified under subsection (6)b.2. of this
section shall prevent water or liquid food from continuously running if there
is a failure of a flow control device in the water or liquid food system or
waste accumulation that could lead to overflow of the waste receptacle.
      (7)   Vending Machine Doors And Openings.
         a.   Vending machine doors and access opening covers to food and
container storage spaces shall be tight-fitting.
         b.   Vending machine service connection openings through an exterior
wall of a machine shall be closed by sealants, clamps, or grommets so that the
openings are no larger than 1/16 of an inch.
      (8)   Outdoor Food Vending Areas, Overhead Protection. Except for
machines that vend canned beverages, if located outside, a machine used to vend
food shall be provided with overhead protection.
(2016 Code)
5-1D-3: MAINTENANCE INFORMATION POSTED:
There shall be posted in a conspicuous place on each machine the name, address
and telephone number of the person responsible for the maintenance of such
machine. (2016 Code)
5-1D-4: UNWHOLESOME FOOD, VIOLATIONS OF RULES PROHIBITED:
No licensee shall offer for sale, or keep for the purpose of selling or
offering for sale, any food of any kind intended for human consumption which is
spoiled, tainted or unwholesome and unfit for human consumption for any reason,
or shall violate any rule or regulation as provided in the sanitary vending of
food and beverages rules and regulations as adopted in section
5-1D-2 of this article. (2016 Code)
ARTICLE E. FOOD OR BEVERAGE VENDING VEHICLES
SECTION:
5-1E-1: Definitions
5-1E-2: Insurance Requirements
5-1E-3: Vehicle Equipment
5-1E-4: Restrictions
5-1E-5: Disease Carrying Vendors Prohibited
5-1E-1: DEFINITIONS:
FOOD OR BEVERAGE VENDING VEHICLE: A vehicle from which the retail sale of food
or beverage for human consumption is conducted on private property.
OWNER: The titleholder of a food or beverage vending vehicle.
RETAIL SALE: The sale of food or beverage to the consumer thereof.
VEHICLE: Every motor vehicle which is mechanically propelled and designed to
transport one or more persons.
VENDING: The act of selling, or offering to sell, any food or beverage for
human consumption from a food or beverage vending vehicle on private property.
VENDOR: Any person who physically operates a food or beverage vending vehicle
or any person who physically conducts vending from such a vehicle. (2016 Code)
5-1E-2: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   All food or beverage vendors shall furnish a certificate to the village
clerk showing that the vendor is carrying the following minimum amounts of
insurance: public liability insurance in an amount of not less than five
hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for injuries, including those resulting
in death, resulting from any one occurrence and on account of any one accident;
property damage insurance in an amount of not less than five hundred thousand
dollars ($500,000.00) for damages on account of any one accident or occurrence.
   B.   Certificates shall contain an agreement signed by the insurance company
that prior to modification, cancellation or termination of the subject policy,
written notice shall be sent to the village clerk by said insurance company.
(2016 Code)
5-1E-3: VEHICLE EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Required Equipment:
      1.   All food or vending vehicles shall have the following equipment:
         a.   A litter or trash container, visible and available to customers
of the vending vehicle. In addition thereto, each licensee shall clean up any
debris or litter which may occur as a result of the vendor's business prior to
leaving any given area of sale.
         b.   Equipment that will keep all potentially hazardous food on the
vehicle at a temperature below forty one degrees Fahrenheit (41°F).
         c.   If providing hot potentially hazardous foods, equipment that will
keep all such foods at one hundred thirty five degrees Fahrenheit (135°F) or
above.
      2.   In addition to other equipment required by law, every food or
beverage vending vehicle shall be equipped with:
         a.   Signal lamps mounted at the same level and as high and as widely
spaced laterally as practicable. These lamps shall be five inches (5") to seven
inches (7") in diameter and shall display two (2) alternately flashing red
lights on the front of the vehicle and two (2) alternately flashing red lights
on the rear of the vehicle, both lights visible at five hundred feet (500') in
normal sunlight upon a straight level street.
         b.   A stop signal arm that can be extended horizontally from the left
side of the truck duplicating the design and size of a standard thirty inch
(30") octagonal stop sign as set forth in the state "Manual Of Uniform Traffic
Control Devices". This arm shall be red and white in color and contain two (2)
alternately flashing lights three inches (3") to five inches (5") in diameter
at the top and bottom thereof, visible at three hundred feet (300') to the
front and rear in normal sunlight upon a straight level street. The color of
the two (2) lights facing to the front shall be red, and the two (2) lights
facing to the rear shall be red. The bottom of the signal arm shall be forty
two inches (42") above the highway.
         c.   A convex mirror mounted on the front so the driver in his normal
seating position can see the area in front of the truck by the hood.
   B.   Use Of Equipment: The driver of a food or beverage vending vehicle
stopped on the streets for the purpose of vending shall actuate the special
flashing lights and extend the stop signal arm required by subsection A2 of
this section. These lights and the stop signal arm shall not be used when the
truck is in motion nor at any time the truck is stopped for a purpose other
than vending. (2016 Code)
5-1E-4: RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   A person shall vend only when the food or beverage vending vehicle is
lawfully stopped.
   B.   A person shall vend only from the side of the vehicle away from moving
traffic and as near as possible to the curb or side of the street.
   C.   A person shall not vend to a person standing in the roadway.
   D.   A person shall not stop on the left side of a one-way street to vend.
   E.   The following shall not be performed from a vending vehicle:
      1.   Emitting any noise intended to advertise the presence of the
vehicle, while it is moving.
      2.   Vending before ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. or after sunset on any day.
   F.   No vehicle shall be backed up to make or attempt to make a sale. (2016
Code)
5-1E-5: DISEASE CARRYING VENDORS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or who is the carrier
of any infections or contagious disease to conduct vending. (2016 Code)
CHAPTER 2
NUISANCES
SECTION:
5-2-1: Nuisances Enumerated
5-2-2: Nuisances Prohibited
5-2-3: Abatement Procedures
5-2-1: NUISANCES ENUMERATED:
   A.   Obstructing Watercourses: It is unlawful and a nuisance for any person,
firm, or corporation to obstruct or pollute any watercourse or source of water
supply in the village. (1976 Code § 8.12.010)
   B.   Stagnant Water: Any stagnant pool of water in the village is declared
to be a nuisance. It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to permit
any such nuisance to remain or exist on any property under his or its control.
(1976 Code § 8.12.020)
   C.   Refuse And Animal Carcass Deposits: It is unlawful for any person,
firm, or corporation to deposit anywhere in the village any uncovered pile of
refuse, garbage, offal, or carcasses of dead animals. Such refuse must be
properly stored in a garbage receptacle and promptly disposed of in a state
approved landfill, recycling center, or waste incinerator. Any uncovered pile
of refuse is declared to be a nuisance. (1976 Code § 8.12.030; amd. 2016 Code)
   D.   Privies: It is unlawful to maintain or permit the maintenance of any
privy vault on any premises in the village. (1976 Code § 8.12.040)
   E.   Unsafe Buildings: It is unlawful to permit any building, structure, or
place to remain in such a condition as to be dangerous to the public health in
any way. Any such structure, building, or place is declared to be a nuisance.
(1976 Code § 8.12.050)
   F.   Acts Endangering Public Health: It is unlawful to commit or do any act
which endangers the public health or results in annoyance or discomfort to the
public. (1976 Code § 8.12.060)
   G.   Noisy Animals: It is unlawful to harbor or keep any animal which
disturbs the peace by loud noises at any time of the day or night. (1976 Code §
8.12.070)
5-2-2: NUISANCES PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful to permit or maintain the existence of any nuisance on any
premises controlled or occupied by any person, firm, or corporation in the
village. (1976 Code § 8.12.080)
5-2-3: ABATEMENT PROCEDURES:
The village is authorized to abate any nuisance existing in the village,
whether such nuisance is one specifically recognized as such by ordinance or
not, in the following manner:
   A.   Inspection: A member of the police department or the building official
may inspect or cause to be inspected any premises upon which it is believed
that a public nuisance exists, and a written report shall be made of the
inspection.
   B.   Emergency Abatement: If a public nuisance on private property
constitutes immediate danger to public health, safety, peace, morals or
decency, the police chief shall serve a notice on the owner or, if the owner
cannot be found, on the occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining
the nuisance, and shall post a copy of the notice on the premises. Such notice
shall direct the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining
the nuisance to abate or remove the nuisance within twenty four (24) hours. The
notice shall also state that if the nuisance is not abated within twenty four
(24) hours, the village may cause the nuisance to be abated and will charge the
costs of such abatement to the person to whom the notice was sent. The village
may employ such village resources as are necessary to abate or remove the
nuisance.
   C.   Court Ordered Abatement: If a public nuisance on private property does
not constitute an immediate danger to public health, peace, morals or decency,
the police chief may cause an action to abate such nuisance to be commenced in
any administrative adjudication hearing or court of proper jurisdiction in the
name of the village.
   D.   Cost Of Abatement: In addition to any other penalty or fee imposed by
this code for the erection, contrivance, creation, maintenance or continuance
of a public nuisance, the cost of abating a public nuisance by the village
shall be collected as a debt from the owner, occupant or person causing,
permitting or maintaining the nuisance.
   E.   Special Lien Authorization: The costs and expenses incurred by the
village to abate any public nuisance may be made a lien on the property on
which any such public nuisance is located pursuant to, and to the fullest
extent provided by, Illinois law. (2016 Code)
ARTICLE A. NUISANCE PROPERTIES AND AGGRAVATED NUISANCE PROPERTIES
SECTION:
5-2A-1: Definitions
5-2A-2: Violations
5-2A-3: Procedures
5-2A-4: Abatement Of Nuisance
5-2A-5: Burden Of Proof; Relief; Fines; Attorney Fees
5-2A-6: Other Remedies
5-2A-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the following words or terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
AGGRAVATED NUISANCE PROPERTY: A lot of record or parcel of real property upon
which two (2) or more of the nuisance activities listed below have occurred
within a six (6) month period:
   A.   Homicide.
   B.   Kidnapping.
   C.   Criminal housing management.
   D.   Possession of explosives or incendiary devices.
   E.   Any offense involving unlawful use of weapons.
   F.   Mob action.
   G.   Child pornography.
   H.   Any controlled substance violation.
   I.   Felony production, sale, distribution or possession of cannabis.
   J.   Gang activity violations as described in the streetgang terrorism
omnibus prevention act.
   K.   Unlawful contact with a gang member.
   L.   Violation of the methamphetamine control and community protection act.
CHIEF OF POLICE: The chief of police of the village of Berkeley or the chief of
police's designee.
CONTROL: The right to permit or deny entry onto property, the right to direct a
person to leave property or the right to govern conduct that occurs on
property.
NUISANCE PROPERTY: A lot of record or parcel of real property upon which three
(3) or more of the nuisance activities listed below occurred within a six (6)
month period:
   A.   Unlawful assembly.
   B.   Assault.
   C.   Battery.
   D.   Unlawful use of weapons or firearms.
   E.   Unlawful discharge of a firearm.
   F.   Prostitution.
   G.   Soliciting or patronizing a prostitute.
   H.   Keeping a house of prostitution.
   I.   Pandering.
   J.   Obscenity.
   K.   Sexual assault and sexual abuse.
   L.   Public indecency.
   M.   Disorderly conduct.
   N.   Unlawful production, sale, distribution, possession, or use of
cannabis.
   O.   Illegal gambling.
   P.   Keeping or maintaining a place of illegal gambling.
   Q.   Unlawful possession of gambling devices.
   R.   Arson.
   S.   Criminal damage to property.
   T.   Illegal consumption, sale or possession of alcohol.
   U.   Theft.
   V.   Interference with a public/peace officer.
   W.   Harassment.
   X.   Indecent exposure.
   Y.   Zoning violations.
   Z.   Loitering.
   AA.   Unlawful possession, sale, distribution, or use of fireworks.
   BB.   Aiding and abetting.
   CC.   Conspiracy.
   DD.   Trespass.
   EE.   Drug paraphernalia.
   FF.   Violation of noise ordinance.
   GG.   Parking on the lawn.
   HH.   Junk vehicles.
   II.   Unlicensed vehicles.
   JJ.   Occupancy violations.
   KK.   Garbage, junk or trash violations.
   LL.   Vandalism, graffiti.
   MM.   Violations of any animal regulations.
   NN.   Any misdemeanor or felony violation of the Illinois criminal code of
2012 1 , as amended.
   OO.   Illegal dumping, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/47-10 and 5/47-15.
PERMIT: To allow, consent to, acquiesce by failure to prevent, suffer or
expressly assent or agree to the doing of the act.
PERSON: Any entity capable of holding a legal or equitable interest in real
property.
PERSON IN CHARGE: Any person in, or with the right of, actual or constructive
possession of real property with the right to permit or deny entry thereon, the
right to direct a person to leave the property or the right to govern conduct
that occurs in the property. Property may have more than one person in charge
at any given time.
PROPERTY: Real property including, but not limited to, any lot, parcel,
condominium unit or other tract of land.
PROPERTY OWNER: Any person holding a legal or equitable interest in real
property. "Property owner" includes, but is not limited to:
   A.   A mortgagee in possession in whom is vested:
      1.   All or part of the legal title of the property; or
      2.   All or part of the beneficial ownership and the right to the present
use and enjoyment of the premises; or
   B.   An occupant in control of property. (Ord. 12-12, 5-15-2012; amd. 2016
Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.
5-2A-2: VIOLATIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any real property to be a nuisance property or
an aggravated nuisance property.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person in charge to permit real property
under his or her control to be a nuisance property or an aggravated nuisance
property. A person in charge does not have to be present at the real property
during the nuisance activities to be in violation of this subsection. (Ord. 12-
12, 5-15-2012; amd. Ord. 19-25, 6-18-2019)
5-2A-3: PROCEDURES:
When the chief of police receives one or more police reports documenting the
occurrence of nuisance activity on a property as described in section
5-2A-1 of this article, definition of "aggravated nuisance property", or two
(2) or more police reports documenting the occurrence of nuisance activity on
or within a property as described in section
5-2A-1 of this article, definition of "nuisance property", the chief of police
shall examine such reports to determine whether there is a rational basis to
believe that such nuisance activity, if it recurs, may unreasonably interfere
with the use and enjoyment of the property by the residents thereof or the use
and enjoyment of adjoining or nearby properties. Upon such a finding, the chief
shall:
   A.   Notify the person in charge in writing that the property is in danger
of becoming either a nuisance property or aggravated nuisance property. The
notice shall contain the following information:
      1.   The street address or a legal description sufficient for
identification of the property.
      2.   A statement that the chief of police has information that the
property may be an aggravated nuisance property or a nuisance property, with a
concise description of the nuisance activities that may exist or that have
occurred. The chief of police shall offer the person in charge an opportunity
to propose a course of action that the chief of police agrees will abate the
nuisance activities giving rise to the violation.
      3.   Demand that the person in charge respond to the chief of police
within five (5) business days to discuss the nuisance activities.
   B.   1. After complying with the notification procedures described herein,
if the chief of police receives a police report documenting the occurrence of
additional nuisance activity on or within a property and determines that the
property has become an "aggravated nuisance property" or a "nuisance property",
as defined in section
5-2A-1 of this article, he shall:
         a.   Notify the person in charge in writing that the property has
become a nuisance property or an aggravated nuisance property. The notice shall
contain the following information:
            (1)   The street address or a legal description sufficient for
identification of the property.
            (2)   A statement that the chief of police has determined the
property to be an aggravated nuisance property or a nuisance property with a
concise description of the nuisance activities leading to the finding
supporting the determination.
            (3)   Demand that the person in charge respond to the chief of
police within five (5) business days and propose a course of action to abate
the nuisance activities.
         b.   Service shall be made either personally or by first class mail
addressed to the person in charge at the address of the property believed to be
an aggravated nuisance property or nuisance property, or such other place which
is likely to give the person in charge notice of the determination by the chief
of police. (Ord. 12-12, 5-15-2012)
         c.   A copy of the notice shall be served on the taxpayer of record at
such address as shown on the tax rolls of Cook County and/or the occupant, at
the address of the property, if these persons are different from the person in
charge, and shall be made either personally or by first class mail, postage
prepaid. (Ord. 12-12, 5-15-2012; amd. 2016 Code)
         d.   A copy of the notice shall also be posted at the property after
five (5) days has elapsed from the service or mailing of the notice to the
person in charge and the person in charge has not contacted the chief of
police.
         e.   The failure of any person to receive notice that the property may
be an aggravated nuisance property or nuisance property shall not invalidate or
otherwise affect the proceedings under this article.
      2.   If, after notification, but prior to the commencement of legal
proceedings by the village pursuant to this section, a person in charge
stipulates with the chief of police that the person in charge will pursue a
course of action that the parties agree is reasonably calculated to abate the
nuisance activities, the chief of police may agree to defer to other
enforcement measures for a reasonable period of time. If the agreed course of
action does not result in the abatement of the nuisance activity or if no
agreement concerning abatement is reached, the chief of police shall order a
local ordinance citation be issued to the person in charge and/or shall request
that the village attorney commence a legal action to abate the nuisance.
      3.   The chief of police shall send copies of the notice and citation
required by this section to the village administrator.
   C.   Statements made by the person in charge to the chief of police
regarding the nuisance activities shall not constitute an admission that
nuisance activities have occurred or are occurring. This subsection does not
require the exclusion of any evidence which is otherwise admissible or offered
for any other purpose. (Ord. 12-12, 5-15-2012)
5-2A-4: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE:
The village attorney, at the direction of the village administrator or the
chief of police, at any time may commence any appropriate action at law, in
equity, or in the village’s administrative adjudication system to abate an
aggravated nuisance property or a nuisance property or for violations of this
article. (Ord. 12-12, 5-15-2012; amd. Ord. 19-25, 6-18-2019)
5-2A-5: BURDEN OF PROOF; RELIEF; FINES; ATTORNEY FEES:
   A.   In any action seeking the abatement of an aggravated nuisance property
or nuisance property, the village shall establish by a preponderance of the
evidence that the property is an aggravated nuisance property or a nuisance
property. As used in this section, “court” shall refer to either a circuit
court judge or an administrative hearing officer, as applicable.
   B.   In the event that the court finds the property constitutes a nuisance
property or an aggravated nuisance property, the court may order such relief as
it deems appropriate. In addition, in the event that it also finds a person in
charge had knowledge of activities or conditions of the property constituting
or violating this article and permitted the activities to occur, the court may
assess a fine. Each incident that the property constitutes a nuisance property
or an aggravated nuisance property shall constitute a separate offense.
   C.   In determining what remedies to grant, the court may, in its
discretion, consider evidence of other conduct which has occurred on the
property including, but not limited to:
      1.   The disturbance of neighbors.
      2.   The recurrence of loud and obnoxious noises.
      3.   The actions or lack of actions taken by the person in charge to
mitigate or correct the problem at the property.
      4.   Whether the problem at the property was repeated or continuous.
      5.   The magnitude or gravity of the problem.
      6.   The cost of the village investigating and correcting or attempting
to correct the condition.
   D.   The court may also require the owner to physically secure the property
against use or occupancy. In the event the owner fails to do so within the time
specified by the court, the court may authorize the village to physically
secure the property against use or occupancy. In the event that the village is
authorized to secure the property, all costs reasonably incurred by the village
to secure the property shall be made and assessed as a lien against the
property and/or as a judgment against the owner. As used herein, "costs" mean
those costs actually incurred by the village for the physical securing of the
property.
   E.   Any person who is assessed the cost of closure or is fined by the court
shall be personally liable for the payment thereof to the village.
   F.   In the event that the village prevails in any action to enforce this
article, it shall be awarded reasonable attorney fees. (Ord. 12-12, 5-15-2012;
amd. 2016 Code; Ord. 19-25, 6-18-2019)
5-2A-6: OTHER REMEDIES:
   A.   The procedures, rights and remedies set forth herein are in addition to
any other right, remedy or claim the village may have and are not intended to
waive or limit the availability of any common law or statutory cause of action.
   B.   In addition to any other remedy the village may have, in the event that
it is determined that the property is an unreasonable threat to the public
safety and welfare, the village may apply to the court for such interim relief
as is deemed appropriate. (Ord. 12-12, 5-15-2012)
CHAPTER 3
WEEDS, GRASS AND PLANTS
SECTION:
5-3-1: Definitions
5-3-2: Height Limit
5-3-3: Notice To Remove
5-3-4: Failure To Remove; Abatement By Village; Costs
5-3-5: Lien Provisions
5-3-5-1: Priority Liens On Abandoned Property
5-3-6: Liability Of Owner
5-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
OWNER, OWNERS, OWNER'S: A sole owner, any part owner, any joint owner, any
tenant in common, any joint tenant, any tenant by entirety, any contract
purchaser or any lessee or tenant or occupant of the whole or of any part of
any land or real estate located within the corporate limits of the village of
Berkeley.
PLANTS: Shall not include trees, bushes, flowers or other ornamental plants.
PROPERTY: The land or real estate owned, leased, occupied or being purchased by
the "owner" (as defined in this section).
RIGHT OF WAY OR BOULEVARD: The space between any sidewalk adjacent to the
owner's property and the adjacent street pavement, and shall include the space
between the owner's property line and the adjacent street pavement if there is
no sidewalk adjacent to the owner's property line.
WEEDS: Shall include, but not be limited to, the following: burdock, ragweed
(giant), ragweed (common), thistle, cocklebur, jimson, blue vervain, common
milkweed, wild carrot, poison ivy, wild mustard, rough pigweed, lamb's quarter,
wild lettuce, curled dock, smartweeds (all varieties), poison hemlock, wild
hemp and Johnson grass and all other noxious weeds as defined by the statutes
of the state of Illinois; and the word "weeds" shall also include any grass of
any variety exceeding six inches (6") in height. (2016 Code)
5-3-2: HEIGHT LIMIT:
It shall be unlawful for any owner to permit any weeds, grass or plants to grow
to a height exceeding six inches (6") upon any property or upon any right of
way or boulevard within the corporate limits of the village. Any such weeds,
grass or plants exceeding such height are hereby declared to be a nuisance.
(2016 Code)
5-3-3: NOTICE TO REMOVE:
The police department, building commissioner or any other person so designated
by the village board, may issue a written notice for removal of weeds, grass,
or plants. Such weeds, grass, or plants shall be cut, mowed and trimmed by the
owner to a height not to exceed six inches (6") within five (5) days after such
notice has been duly served. Service of the notice provided for herein may be
effected by handing the same to any owner or to any member of his or her
household of the age of fifteen (15) years or older found on the premises, or
by mailing such notice to the last known residence address of the owner;
provided, that if the premises is unoccupied and the owner's address cannot be
obtained, then the notice may be served by posting the same upon the premises.
(2016 Code)
5-3-4: FAILURE TO REMOVE; ABATEMENT BY VILLAGE; COSTS:
If the person so served does not abate the nuisance within five (5) days, the
village may proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping an account of the expense
of the abatement, and such expense shall be charged to and paid by the owner.
(2016 Code)
5-3-5: LIEN PROVISIONS:
   A.   Abatement Costs A Lien:
      1.   Charges for weed, grass or plant removal, destruction or abatement
shall be a lien upon the premises. A bill representing the cost and expense
incurred or payable for the service shall be presented to the owner. If this
bill is not paid within sixty (60) days of submission of the bill, a notice of
lien of the cost and expense thereof incurred by the village shall be recorded
in the following manner:
         a.   A description of the real estate sufficient for identification
thereof.
         b.   The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or
payable for the service.
         c.   The date or dates when said cost and expense was incurred by the
village.
      2.   The notice of lien shall be filed in the county recorder's office
within sixty (60) days after such cost and expense is incurred.
   B.   Notice Of Lien; Payment Of Costs; Release Of Lien: The cost of the
cutting of weeds shall not be lien on the real estate affected unless a notice
is personally served on, or sent by certified mail to, the person to whom was
sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the last preceding
year. The notice shall be delivered or sent after the cutting of weeds on the
property. The notice shall state the substance of this section and shall
identify the property, by common description, and the location of the weeds to
be cut. Upon payment of the cost and expense after the notice of lien has been
filed, the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the
lien has been filed, and the release may be filed of record in the same manner
as filing notice of the lien. All lien and release filing fees shall be paid by
the owner of the property.
   C.   Foreclosure Of Lien: Property subject to a lien for unpaid weed, grass
or plant cutting charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the
proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the charges after deducting
costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure
shall be in the name of the village after the lien is in effect for sixty (60)
days. (2016 Code)
5-3-5-1: PRIORITY LIENS ON ABANDONED PROPERTY:
   A.   From and after March 1, 2010, any action taken by the village under
this chapter on property that is abandoned shall be subject to the priority
lien provisions set forth in this section.
   B.   The village must file a lien within one year of the date for actions
taken under this chapter for any abandoned property, which lien shall include a
sworn statement that specifically sets forth the following:
      1.   A description of the abandoned property.
      2.   Cost and expense incurred by the village taking action under this
chapter.
      3.   Date or dates of action taken under this chapter.
      4.   Reference that the actions taken under this chapter were done
pursuant to authority granted in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-7.
   C.   In furtherance of its authority under this section, the village clerk
will maintain a record for each property for which a lien has been filed under
this section that will include the following:
      1.   Dated statement of a finding that the property was abandoned.
      2.   Date when the property was first observed to be vacant.
      3.   Description of the actions taken by the village to contact the legal
owner of the property and a statement that no contacts were made with the legal
owner.
      4.   Dated certification by a municipal official of the necessity and
specific nature of the work performed.
      5.   Copy of the agreement with the person or company performing the work
including the rates and estimated cost of the work.
      6.   Detailed invoices and payment vouchers for the work.
      7.   A statement as to whether the work was competitively bid and, if so,
a copy of all proposals submitted by the bidders. (2016 Code)
5-3-6: LIABILITY OF OWNER:
The liability of the owner as set forth in this chapter shall be joint and
several, and the village may proceed against any one or all owners, but the
village shall not be required to proceed against more than one owner. (2016
Code)
CHAPTER 4
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
SECTION:
5-4-1: Receptacles
5-4-2: Deposit In Streets
5-4-3: Collection Charge
5-4-4: Accumulation Of Garbage And Refuse Prohibited; Removal Required; Lien
Provisions
5-4-1: RECEPTACLES:
   A.   Receptacle Required: It shall be the duty of every owner or occupant of
any house, building, flat or apartment located within the village where people
reside, board or lodge, or where animal or vegetable matter is prepared or
served, to maintain in good order and repair, at all times, one or more cans or
containers designed as receptacles for discarded garbage, bottles, cans and
similar refuse. (1976 Code § 8.08.010)
   B.   Specifications: Any can in which garbage is deposited shall be
watertight and shall be fitted with a closefitting cover. All cans for garbage
and refuse shall have a capacity of not more than one hundred five (105)
gallons and shall be provided with suitable handles. (1976 Code § 8.08.020;
amd. 2016 Code)
   C.   Placement For Pick Up; Removal: No cans, sealed trash bags or other
trash containers shall be placed in any street right of way prior to six
o'clock (6:00) P.M. of the day before the scheduled pick up day for that
particular area. All cans shall be removed before eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. on
the day following the scheduled pick up. (1976 Code § 8.08.040)
5-4-2: DEPOSIT IN STREETS:
No garbage or refuse of any kind shall be deposited in any street right of way
except within cans or containers designed as receptacles therefor and in such a
manner as would reasonably assure that the garbage and refuse would not be
blown about or be scattered by the wind, animals or vandals.
(1976 Code § 8.08.040)
5-4-3: COLLECTION CHARGE:
   A.   Established: There is established a monthly service charge for the
collection and disposal of garbage within the corporate limits of the village.
   B.   Amount Of Charge: The charge for solid waste, recycling and yard waste
collection in the village, per residential household, shall be as established
by the village board of trustees
   C.   Bills For Service: Such service charge shall become due and payable
every month of the year and shall be billed as a separate item on the water
bill received by such owner or occupant.
(1976 Code §§ 8.08.050, 8.08.070; amd. Ord. 06-23, 6-20-2006; 2016 Code; Ord.
20-25, 5-5-2020; Ord. 21-35, 5-18-2021; Ord. 22-31, 6-21-2022; Ord. 24-26, 5-7-
2024)
5-4-4: ACCUMULATION OF GARBAGE AND REFUSE PROHIBITED; REMOVAL REQUIRED; LIEN
PROVISIONS:
   A.   Accumulation Prohibited: It is illegal for the owners of real estate to
accumulate garbage and debris except in receptacles as provided in this
chapter. (1976 Code § 8.08.080)
   B.   Removal Required: Upon receipt of notice in writing from the building
official, the owner of the premises specified in such notice shall take
immediate measures for the removal of garbage and debris from the premises, and
unless said work is completed in the time specified in the notice, in no event
to be less than fifteen (15) days, or any written extension thereof that may be
granted by the village, the owner, agent, or occupant in charge of said
building, structure or premises is guilty of a violation of this section.
   C.   Removal By Village; Costs A Lien: Whenever the owner of the premises,
after being served with notice as provided in this section, refuses or
neglects, within the time fixed in the notice, to perform all work necessary
for the removal of garbage and debris from the premises as described in said
notice, the building official or person duly authorized thereby may go on the
premises and do such work as is necessary to free said premises from garbage
and debris. The cost and expense incurred for all work and materials may be
collected from the owner of said premises, and the village or persons
performing such work or furnishing such materials therefor shall have a lien on
said premises and may enforce the same as provided by statute. (1976 Code §
8.08.090; amd. 2016 Code)
   D.   Recording Lien:
      1.   A notice of lien of the cost and expense thereof incurred by the
village or person authorized shall be recorded in the following manner: The
village, or the person performing the service by authority of the village, in
its or his own name, may file notice of lien in the office of the recorder of
deeds in the county. The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement
setting out: (1976 Code § 8.08.100; amd. 2016 Code)
         a.   A description of the real estate sufficient for identification
thereof;
         b.   The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or
payable for the service; and
         c.   The date or dates when said cost and expense was incurred by the
village.
      2.   The notice shall be filed within sixty (60) days after the cost and
expense is incurred. (1976 Code § 8.08.100)
   E.   Release Of Lien: Upon payment of the cost and expense after notice of
lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village or person in
whose name the lien has been filed, and the release shall be filed of record in
the same manner as filing notice of said lien. (1976 Code § 8.08.110)
ARTICLE A. GRASS CLIPPINGS AND LEAVES
SECTION:
5-4A-1: Definition
5-4A-2: Containment Method
5-4A-3: Insert Prohibited In Containers
5-4A-4: Prohibited Contents
5-4A-5: Multi-Family, Commercial And Industrial Properties
5-4A-6: Collection Regulations
5-4A-1: DEFINITION:
"Biodegradable paper bag" means a paper bag capable of disintegrating by
naturally occurring biological or physical processes in the environment within
a period of two (2) years after disposal, or into particles of a molecular
weight that is low when compared to the molecular weight of the original
material. (1976 Code § 8.18.020)
5-4A-2: CONTAINMENT METHOD:
Effective May 1, 1990, grass clippings and leaves, for disposal by residents,
must be contained in biodegradable paper bags or sealable containers not
exceeding fifty (50) pounds bearing the notation "Village of Berkeley Leaves
and Grass Clippings Only". (1976 Code § 8.18.010; amd. 2016 Code)
5-4A-3: INSERT PROHIBITED IN CONTAINERS:
Containers may be used for the containment of grass clippings and leaves so
long as no bag or other insert is contained within the container. (1976 Code §
8.18.040; amd. 2016 Code)
5-4A-4: PROHIBITED CONTENTS:
The biodegradable paper bags or other containers may not contain any substance
to be disposed of other than grass clippings and leaves. (1976 Code § 8.18.050;
amd. 2016 Code)
5-4A-5: MULTI-FAMILY, COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL PROPERTIES:
The owners and/or occupiers of multi-family, commercial or industrial
properties located within the industrial properties located within the village,
through their respective disposal contractors, shall comply with sections
5-4A-2 and
5-4A-3 of this article. (1976 Code § 8.18.060)
5-4A-6: COLLECTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   All refuse, garbage, debris, and leaves and grass clippings shall be
picked up and accumulated by the village as otherwise provided by the village
board in the contract with the village's selected scavenger. (1976 Code §
8.18.070; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Residential pick up of grass clippings and leaves by the village or the
agent of the village shall be accomplished on the regular day for collection in
April and ending on the last regular day for collection in November, except if
a collection date coincides with the date of a holiday. (1976 Code § 8.18.080;
amd. 2016 Code)
ARTICLE B. COMPOST BINS
SECTION:
5-4B-1: Definition
5-4B-2: Size And Location
5-4B-3: Nuisance Conditions Prohibited
5-4B-1: DEFINITION:
For purposes of this article, a "compost bin" means and is defined as an
outdoor area framed in wood, wire, concrete block, or any other material for
the purpose of storing grass, bush, tree or other biological growth material.
(1976 Code § 8.30.010)
5-4B-2: SIZE AND LOCATION:
A compost bin, as allowed by this article, shall not be larger than four feet
by four feet (4' x 4') in dimensions and shall be located in the rear yard area
of a given residence or residential building, but in any event not less than
twenty five feet (25') from the nearest residential building. (1976 Code §
8.30.020)
5-4B-3: NUISANCE CONDITIONS PROHIBITED:
Nothing contained in this article shall grant or permit the creation of an
odor, sight or health nuisance by the owner of the compost bin by virtue of the
creation of a compost bin. (1976 Code § 8.30.030; amd. 2016 Code)
ARTICLE C. COLLECTION FROM MULTI-FAMILY STRUCTURES
SECTION:
5-4C-1: Definitions
5-4C-2: On Site Multi-Family Structure Recycling Program
5-4C-3: Private Scavengers
5-4C-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions pertain to the management of solid waste:
MULTI-FAMILY PROPERTY: A property consisting of one or more multi-family
structures.
MULTI-FAMILY STRUCTURE: A building with more than two (2) residential living
units which is not included in the village of Berkeley curbside refuse,
recyclables and landscape waste collection and disposal service.
OWNER: Any person, corporation, partnership, or entity such as a condominium or
homeowners' association, jointly or severally having an ownership interest in a
multi-family property or otherwise being responsible for solid waste
collection.
PRIVATE SCAVENGER: Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the removal of
solid waste, compostable material and/or recyclable material from any location
within the village of Berkeley not covered by either an exclusive collection
contract between the village of Berkeley and a contracted hauler, or a
franchise agreement between the village of Berkeley and a franchised hauler.
RECYCLABLE MATERIAL: A material which would otherwise be abandoned or discarded
but which can be utilized in the secondary material market.
RECYCLING: The process by which materials that would otherwise be disposed of
or discarded are collected, separated or processed and returned to the economic
mainstream in the form of raw materials or products.
SOURCE SEPARATION: A process that separates recyclable material from other
refuse prior to collection for the purpose of recycling such materials. (Ord.
95-01, 2-7-1995)
5-4C-2: ON SITE MULTI-FAMILY STRUCTURE RECYCLING PROGRAM:
   A.   Program Requirements:
      1.   All multi-family properties, as defined in section
5-4C-1 of this article, shall be required to institute an on site recycling
program, with collection of recyclable materials to be no less than one pick up
per week.
      2.   Said program shall be instituted by a multi-family property at the
earliest of the following two (2) occurrences:
         a.   Upon the expiration date of its current refuse collection
contract; or
         b.   By January 1, 1996.
      3.   Multi-family property owners may contract for recycling and refuse
services with a private scavenger, duly licensed by the village. Multi-family
property owners shall be billed for recycling and refuse services directly by
the private scavenger.
      4.   An acceptable recycling program shall include, but is not limited
to, the following components:
         a.   Siting and design of common area collection areas for recyclable
materials;
         b.   Recyclable materials collection;
         c.   Provision of common area recycling containers;
         d.   Data collection and reporting;
         e.   Educational campaign and materials; and
         f.   Recycling program administration and maintenance.
   B.   Specific Requirements:
      1.   Recycling Areas:
         a.   Recycling collection areas for residents shall be conveniently
located and maintained within common areas in or near the buildings, and
consist of separate containers for the purposes of temporary storage of
recyclables. Whenever possible, recycling containers should be placed adjacent
to common area solid waste collection containers.
         b.   Indoor common area collection/storage areas shall be established
in accordance with appropriate village fire and/or safety codes.
         c.   Exterior recyclables storage areas shall be established in
accordance with village requirements for solid waste enclosures.
         d.   The multi-family property owner shall maintain all recycling
areas, including the containers, in a clean, sanitary, and litter free manner.
      2.   Authorized Materials: On site multi-family structure recycling
programs are required to offer collection of a minimum of five (5) of the
following types of recyclable materials:
         Aluminum, steel, tin and bimetal cans.
         Chipboard.
         Corrugated cardboard.
         Glass bottles (3 colors).
         High grade paper.
         Junk mail.
         Magazines and catalogs.
         Miscellaneous ferrous and nonferrous scrap metals.
         Newspapers.
         PETE (#1) and HDPE (#2) plastic bottles.
         Telephone books.
      3.   Separation From Solid Waste Required: Recyclable materials must be
source separated from other solid waste prior to collection for the purpose of
recycling such materials. Separate collection containers and collection
vehicles shall be employed.
      4.   Minimum Container Capacity:
         a.   The minimum gallon amount of recycling container capacity (total
weekly base recycling container capacity) an owner shall provide weekly for
each structure shall be based on the following formula:
            7 gallons x number of studio and 1 bedroom units +
            8 gallons x number of 2 bedroom units +
            9 gallons x number of 3 bedroom or more units
            = total base weekly recycling container capacity
         b.   The weekly base recycling container capacity may be met by a
combination of container sizes and number of pick ups, such as containers
totaling half the base capacity picked up twice a week. Capacity per structure
may be shifted within the multi- family property if necessary, so long as the
total required capacity is met.
      5.   Scavenger Responsibility: The contracted private scavenger providing
the on site recycling collection service shall be responsible for furnishing,
maintaining and replacing all common area recycling containers and collection
vehicles which are deemed necessary in the recycling program. The private
scavenger shall be responsible for the collection, intermediate storage or
transfer, transportation, and sale of recyclable materials to a processor,
broker, or market desired for reuse of materials.
      6.   Notice To Residents Of Recycling Services: Multi-family property
owners shall notify residents of the availability of recycling services through
a formal and ongoing educational campaign, and shall use their best efforts to
gain and maintain participation in the program.
      7.   Unauthorized Removal Or Damage Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for
any unauthorized persons to remove or damage any recyclable materials placed in
designated containers, or the containers themselves. Title to recyclable
material shall pass to the private scavenger when the materials are placed into
the collection vehicle.
   C.   Implementation And Continuation Of Program Required: Implementation of
on site multi-family structure recycling programs shall be required as stated
in subsection A2 of this section. Such recycling programs shall be maintained
in effect regardless of any change of building ownership or private scavenger
service. Multi-family property owners shall be required to notify the village
in writing within thirty (30) days after a change in their choice of private
scavenger. (Ord. 95-01, 2-7-1995)
5-4C-3: PRIVATE SCAVENGERS:
   A.   Requirements To Obtain License: All private scavengers desiring to
receive a scavenger license to collect solid waste, compostable material and/or
recyclable material from multi-family properties in the village must comply
with all applicable federal, state, county and local laws, ordinances, rules
and regulations. As a condition of receiving, renewing and maintaining a
scavenger license to collect solid waste, compostable material and/or
recyclable material from multi-family properties within the village, each
licensee or applicant for such license shall:
      1.   Obtain all permits and licenses required by federal, state and
county laws, ordinances, rules and regulations and maintain the same in full
force and effect.
      2.   Submit to the village a list of the multi-family properties it
serves within the jurisdiction of the village.
      3.   Provide collection and recycling services for any multi-family
property owner that requests such services in accordance with the on site
multi-family structure recycling program requirements set forth in this
article.
      4.   Failure to comply with this subsection A shall result in a denial of
receiving, renewing or maintaining a scavenger license until such time as the
applicant complies with all provisions set forth in this subsection A.
   B.   Reporting Requirements:
      1.   Each licensed private scavenger, exclusive contractor or franchised
hauler shall submit a quarterly report to both the multi-family property owner
(s) or their designee and the village and/or its designee that contains the
following information:
         a.   Total weight or volume of refuse collected from multi-family
properties it serves within the village.
         b.   Total weight or volume of yard waste collected from multi- family
properties it serves within the village.
         c.   Total weight or volume of recyclable materials collected from
multi-family properties it serves within the village.
         d.   A summary of recycling services provided to each multi-family
property, to be submitted only on an annual basis with the fourth quarter
report.
      2.   Quarterly reports submitted to the multi-family property by the
licensed private scavenger shall only pertain to that property's activity.
      3.   Quarterly reports submitted to the village shall contain aggregate
totals concerning the information listed in subsections B1 and B2 of this
section for all multi-family properties the licensed private scavenger serves
within the jurisdiction of the village.
      4.   Reports shall be due no later than fifteen (15) days after the close
of each quarter and shall follow the format prescribed by the village. Quarters
are defined as follows:
         First quarter: January 1 through March 31
         Second quarter: April 1 through June 30
         Third quarter: July 1 through September 30
         Fourth quarter: October 1 through December 31
      5.   The information shall be considered exempt from the Illinois freedom
of information act 1  and disclosure by the village or its designee upon
assertion as to its proprietary nature by the licensed private scavenger. The
village or its designee shall only report the information in the form of
statistics and/or volume totals for all multi-family properties in the village.
No specific information on individual licenses shall be divulged.
      6.   The village and/or its designee shall have the right to inspect and
examine the licensed private scavenger's records pertaining to the collection
and disposal or processing of refuse and recyclables upon request and with
reasonable notice. The village or its designee shall further have the right to
require the reporting of other data or information relative to the recycling
program from time to time.
      7.   All such reports, data, and information, once received by the
village or its designee, shall become the property of the village to be used as
it shall determine without obligation to any person, firm or corporation.
      8.   Failure to submit any required report to the village or its designee
shall be grounds for revocation of the business license and/or franchise
agreement until such time as the licensed private scavenger or franchised
hauler complies with the requirements set forth in this subsection B. (Ord. 95-
01, 2-7-1995)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.
ARTICLE D. SCAVENGERS
SECTION:
5-4D-1: Business License Requirements
5-4D-2: License To Remove
5-4D-3: Vehicle Requirements
5-4D-4: Disposal And Storage Restrictions
5-4D-1: BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   License Required; Fee: It is unlawful for any person, firm, or
corporation to engage in the business of scavenger, or the disposal of animal,
human, or vegetable refuse, or offal, without having first secured a license
therefor. The annual fee for such license shall be as established in the annual
fee schedule. (1976 Code § 5.87.010; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Application For License: Applications for such licenses shall be made
to the village clerk, and shall be referred by him to the board of trustees. No
such license shall be issued except on order of the board of trustees. (1976
Code § 5.87.020; amd. 2016 Code)
5-4D-2: LICENSE TO REMOVE:
It shall be illegal for any person to remove all or any portion of any garbage,
refuse, recyclables or trash placed in any street or right of way for pick up
by the company or firm licensed by the village for the collection of same
without first having obtained a license for that purpose. (Ord. 95-19, 9-19-
1995; amd. 2016 Code)
5-4D-3: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
Any vehicle used by a scavenger in his business shall be watertight and
equipped with airtight covers for such portions as are used for the
transportation of refuse. (1976 Code § 5.87.030)
5-4D-4: DISPOSAL AND STORAGE RESTRICTIONS:
It is unlawful for any scavenger to dispose of or store any refuse in any place
within the village limits or within one mile therefrom, except with the
permission of the board of trustees. (1976 Code § 5.87.030)
CHAPTER 5
LITTER CONTROL
SECTION:
5-5-1: Definition
5-5-2: Public Property
5-5-3: Trucks
5-5-4: Private Property
5-5-5: Littering From Vehicles
5-5-1: DEFINITION:
For the purpose of this chapter, "litter" includes, but is not limited to,
putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking, and consumption of food; other putrescible waste,
including dead animals, yard clippings, and leaves; nonputrescible solid waste
(except body waste), including rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, abandoned
automobiles, solid market and industrial wastes, paper, wrappings, cigarettes,
cardboard, tin cans, glass, bedding, crockery, and similar materials; and all
other waste materials which, if thrown or deposited as prohibited in this
chapter, shall be deemed to create a danger to public health, safety, and
welfare. (1976 Code § 9.24.010)
5-5-2: PUBLIC PROPERTY:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to throw or deposit
litter in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place within the
village, except in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles.
(1976 Code § 9.24.020; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   No person, firm, or corporation shall sweep into or deposit in any
gutter, street, alley, or other public place in the village, the accumulation
of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk and
driveway.
   C.   Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk and
parkway in front of their premises free from litter. (1976 Code § 9.24.020)
5-5-3: TRUCKS:
   A.   Loads Secured: No person, firm, or corporation shall drive or cause to
be driven any truck or other vehicle within the village upon any public street
or way unless such vehicle is so constructed, loaded, or covered as to prevent
any load, contents, or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street,
alley, or other public place.
   B.   Wheels And Tires Free Of Mud And Debris: No person shall drive or move
any vehicle or truck within the village, the wheels or tires of which carry
onto or deposit in any street, alley, or other public place any mud, dirt,
sticky substances, litter, or foreign matter of any kind. (1976 Code §
9.24.030)
5-5-4: PRIVATE PROPERTY:
   A.   No person shall throw or deposit litter on any private property within
the village, whether owned by such person or not; except, that the owner or
person in control of private property may maintain private receptacles for
collection in such a manner that litter may be prevented from being carried or
deposited by the elements upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public
place or upon any private property.
   B.   The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all
times maintain the premises free of litter; provided, that this subsection
shall not prohibit the storage of litter in private receptacles for collection,
which receptacles shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and
shall be so constructed as to prevent the litter deposited therein from being
carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or other
public place or upon any private property. (1976 Code § 9.24.040)
5-5-5: LITTERING FROM VEHICLES:
No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit
litter upon any street, alley, or other public place within the village or upon
private property. (1976 Code § 9.24.020)
CHAPTER 6
HAZARDOUS MATERIAL REMOVAL AND ABATEMENT
SECTION:
5-6-1: Definitions
5-6-2: Authority To Remove Or Abate
5-6-3: Supervision Or Verification By Fire Chief
5-6-4: Costs
5-6-5: Nonexclusive Remedies
5-6-6: Burden Of Liability
5-6-7: Exceptions
5-6-8: Penalty
5-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the terms used herein are defined as follows:
HAZARDOUS MATERIAL: A. Hazardous substance or hazardous waste, as defined in
the environmental protection act 1 , as amended; or
   B.   Any substance listed in the list of toxic pollutants found in 40 CFR
401.15, as amended; or
   C.   Any of the following: explosives, pyrotechnics, flammable gas,
flammable compressed gas, nonflammable compressed gas, flammable liquid,
oxidizing material, any flammable material, poisonous gas, poisonous liquid,
irritating material, material that causes diseases in humans, gas under such
pressure that an explosion hazard exists, radioactive material, corrosive
material, or liquefied petroleum gas, including any substance, material, waste
or mixture designated as a hazardous material, waste or substance according to
49 CFR including:
      1.   Compressed Gas: Any substance regulated as a compressed gas by the
United States department of transportation by regulations found in 49 CFR
173.300;
      2.   Explosive: Any substance regulated as a class A or class B explosive
by the United States department of transportation by regulations found in 49
CFR 173.53 and 173.88;
      3.   Flammable Liquid: Any substance regulated as a flammable liquid by
the United States department of transportation by regulations found in 49 CFR
173.115;
      4.   Flammable Solid: Any substance regulated as a flammable solid by the
United States department of transportation by regulations found in 49 CFR
173.150;
      5.   Oxidizer: Any substance regulated as an oxidizer by the United
States department of transportation by regulations found in 49 CFR 173.151;
      6.   Poison: Any liquid or gas that is life threatening when mixed with
air in small amounts and shall also include all those substances regulated as
poison A by the United States department of transportation by regulations found
in 49 CFR 173.326;
      7.   Radioactive Material: Any substance required by the United States
department of transportation to have type A packaging or other special
protection or closed transport vehicles under regulations found in 49 CFR
173.425;
   D.   Any material which is classified by the National Fire Protection
Association (NFPA) as either a flammable liquid, a class II combustible liquid
or a class IIIA combustible liquid; or
   E.   Any material which has been determined to be, by the party storing it
or having control of it, through testing or other objective means, likely to
create a significant potential or actual hazard to public health, safety or
welfare or to the environment. This definition shall not establish a
