   B.   Record Of Tenants: The owner of a rental residential property shall
maintain a record for each property with the full legal names and dates of
birth of every tenant in each dwelling unit. The owner of a rental residential
property shall make available to the code official, upon request, the occupant
records required to be maintained under this section.
   C.   Emergency Contact Person: The owner or property agent of a rental
residential property shall provide each tenant with the name and telephone
number of a responsible person who, in emergency situations, will be available
on a twenty four (24) hour basis and who has the authority to make repairs as
needed. The owner shall also cause said information to be posted and maintained
within the main entryway of every rental residential structure.
   D.   Notice Of Maximum Occupancy: The owner of a rental residential property
shall inform each tenant in writing, prior to occupancy, of the maximum number
of persons allowable by the occupancy standards of the village property
maintenance code as determined by the code official or the lease, whichever is
less.
   E.   Educational Programs: All owners and managers are encouraged to attend
landlord training programs which include such issues as property maintenance,
applicant screening, rental agreements, ongoing management, and community
building.
   F.   Tenant Applications: All owners and managers are required to have all
prospective tenants complete a written application that encourages self-
screening and uncovers past behavior to determine if the applicant meets the
written tenant criteria.
   G.   Leases: All owners and managers are required to lease rental
residential dwelling units only pursuant to a written lease containing their
rules and regulations. (2016 Code)
10-18-8: ACCESS FOR INSPECTIONS:
If any owner, property agent, occupant or other person in control of a rental
residential property or a dwelling unit contained therein fails or refuses to
consent to free access and entry to the property or dwelling unit under his
control for any inspection pursuant to this chapter, the code official or his
designee shall apply to the circuit court for an administrative search warrant
or other appropriate court order authorizing such inspections. (2016 Code)
10-18-9: VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Owner Violations: The following shall constitute violations of this
chapter:
      1.   Failure of the owner of a rental residential building to license
such building with the code official.
      2.   Failure of the owner of a rental residential building to vacate all
tenants from said building within forty five (45) days after the license has
been revoked.
      3.   Failure of the owner of the rental property to maintain the
structure and premises in compliance with applicable building, property
maintenance and zoning ordinances in this code.
   B.   Other Violations: The following shall constitute violations of this
chapter:
      1.   Failure of the occupants of the rental residential property to
vacate such property within forty five (45) days after receiving notice from
the code official that such property is not properly licensed or that the
license has been revoked.
      2.   Any person other than an inspector from the village who removes or
defaces any notices which have been posted pursuant to this chapter without the
approval of the code official shall be liable for the penalties provided by
this chapter.
      3.   It shall be unlawful for any person to consume an alcoholic beverage
or possess alcoholic liquor except in the original container with the seal
unbroken on the common area of a multiple-unit building, including all yards
outside of a rental residential dwelling, except in areas designated by the
owner of the rental residential dwelling, having advised the police department
in writing. This subsection shall not be effective until the owner of the
rental residential building posts signs providing reasonable notice hereof to
persons entering the property. (2016 Code)
10-18-10: NOTICE OF VIOLATION; LICENSE SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION:
   A.   When a licensing or other inspection of a licensed rental residential
property reveals any violations of applicable codes, a compliance time frame
will be set by the code official. In establishing a compliance time frame, the
code official shall determine the reasonable minimal time necessary to correct
the violations based upon the number and severity of the violations. The code
official shall serve or send notice to the property owner or the listed
property agent by regular U.S. mail at the last address provided on the most
recent license application. Said notice shall include the following:
      1.   Description of the property sufficient for identification;
      2.   A statement listing the violations of applicable codes;
      3.   A statement of the date upon which a reinspection will occur; and
      4.   An explanation that if, upon completion of the reinspection, the
requirements of applicable village codes have not been met, the license for the
rental residential property will be denied or suspended and/or a complaint
filed against the owner in the circuit court.
   B.   A reinspection will be conducted at the end of the compliance time
frame.
      1.   If any violation is not corrected, the code official may issue a
written notice extending the time to correct the violations if there has been a
good faith effort to correct the violations and the failure to do so was due to
factors beyond the control of the owner.
      2.   If the code official finds that the requirements of applicable
village codes have not been met upon the completion of such reinspection, the
license for the rental residential property shall be suspended.
      3.   A license may also be suspended when any information provided in the
license application is determined by the code official to be false or when the
licensee is convicted by a court of a violation of any property maintenance
regulations.
      4.   In the alternative, the code official may request the village
attorney to file a complaint against the owner in the circuit court.
   C.   When a license is suspended, the code official shall personally serve
or send notice to the property or the listed property agent at the last address
provided on the most recent license application. Said notice shall be sent by
certified mail, return receipt requested. The notice shall include the
following:
      1.   Description of the property sufficient for identification.
      2.   A statement of the reasons for suspension.
      3.   An explanation of the property owner's right to reinspection prior
to revocation.
If the property owner changes his address or changes property agents and fails
to notify the code official, such notice shall be sufficient if sent by
certified mail to the owner or his property agent's last address provided on
the last license application.
   D.   A property owner whose license has been suspended may request a
reinspection prior to revocation. If, upon reinspection, the code official
finds that the licensed property in connection with which the notice was issued
is now in compliance with this chapter, including the payment of all
outstanding fees, the code official may reinstate the license. The request for
a reinspection shall not stay the revocation of the license unless the code
official grants such request pursuant to a showing of good cause by the
property owner.
   E.   A license may also be revoked when, in the opinion of the code
official, emergency conditions exist in a rental residential property that
require the immediate vacating of a structure as specified in the village's
property maintenance code.
   F.   A license which has been properly revoked as herein provided shall not
be reinstated. The property owner may, however, obtain a new license after all
violations have been corrected and by following the procedures for obtaining a
new license as set forth in this chapter.
   G.   Whenever a license is revoked, the code official shall send notice to
the property owner or the listed property agent at the last address provided on
the most recent license application. Said notice shall be sent by registered
mail, return receipt requested. The code official shall also notify all tenants
of the rental residential property by posting a notice on all entrances to the
rental residential structure. The notice to the tenants shall include the
following:
      1.   You are hereby notified that the license for this structure has been
revoked pursuant to Title 10, Chapter 18 of the Berkeley Village Code.
      2.   You must vacate this structure within 45 days of the date of this
notice.
      3.   If you fail to vacate this structure, you will be in violation of
the Berkeley Village Code and subject to penalties of fines with a minimum of
$100.00 and a maximum of $1,000.00 for each day you are in violation.
   H.   Whenever an owner or property agent of a rental property fails to
license said property, the code official shall notify all tenants of the rental
property by posting a notice on all entrances to the rental property indicating
the following:
      1.   You are hereby notified that the owner or agent of this rental
structure has failed to license this rental property in violation of the
Berkeley Village Code.
      2.   You must vacate this structure within 45 days of this notice.
      3.   If you fail to vacate this structure, you will be subject to the
penalties and fines with a minimum of $100.00 and a maximum of $1,000.00 for
each day you are in violation.
(2016 Code)
10-18-11: CRIME FREE HOUSING:
   A.   Any owner of property, which property is being rented out as a rental
residential dwelling unit, must attend and complete a village crime free multi-
housing program seminar ("seminar"). The owner, agent or designee of a new
rental unit must attend the seminar prior to obtaining or being issued a new
village rental residential license.
   B.   A property manager shall be considered an agent of the owner. If a new
property manager is hired, notification of the change will be made to the code
official within seven (7) days of the change and the new property manager shall
have three (3) months after hiring to attend the seminar.
   C.   Any owner, agent or designee shall attend the seminar once every four
(4) years and be compliant with this chapter prior to the expiration of a
license for that particular year.
   D.   The crime free multi-housing coordinator, as designated by the chief of
police, shall provide the village clerk's office and/or finance department with
a list of owners, agents and/or designees who have attended the seminar, with
verification that the owner, agent or designee has complied with this section
and is eligible to obtain, maintain or renew the operating license.
   E.   Any owner, agent or designee of residential rental property shall
utilize a crime free lease addendum or have a clause in the lease similar to a
crime free lease addendum for any leases executed. A copy of the crime free
lease addendum shall be provided to the crime free multi-housing coordinator
prior to expiration of the rental permit for renewals and within sixty (60)
days of initial application for new applicants. At the seminar, the crime free
multi-housing coordinator shall provide, at no cost, samples of the crime free
lease addendum and shall review any clauses within actual leases with the
village's legal department to determine if the clause is similar to the crime
free lease addendum. The crime free housing addendum or equivalent lease clause
must make a conviction for a qualifying offense by a tenant or member of the
household a lease violation, subject to the limitations in this section
including, without limitation, in subsections H, I, and J below. The landlord
shall have authority under the crime free lease addendum or equivalent lease
clause to initiate an eviction proceeding as specified in the Illinois Compiled
Statutes forcible entry and detainer statutes, when appropriate in the
landlord's discretion, upon a conviction for a qualifying offense by a tenant
or member of the household.
   F.   It is hereby declared an aggravated nuisance for any property owner,
agent, or manager to allow or permit nuisance activities constituting either a
nuisance property or aggravated nuisance property as defined under section
5-2A-1 of this code. The owner, agent, or manager shall be subject to all the
applicable provisions and penalties of Article 5-2A of this code.
   G.   The village may seek to enforce this section by seeking any and all
remedies under this chapter, including the imposition of fines. In addition,
the village administrator may suspend and/or recommend revocation of any
license issued hereunder if it appears to his/her satisfaction from the report
of any village officer or village employee or any other available information
that the licensee is violating and/or is in violation of the provisions set
forth in Article 5-2A of this code. Any suspension or revocation of a license
shall be pursuant to the provisions set forth in title 4, chapter 1 of this
code and the penalties as set forth in section
1-4-1 of this code.
   H.   A tenant who is an innocent party or the victim of a crime, including
but not limited to actual or threatened domestic violence or sexual violence
will not be in violation of this Section. Nothing in this Section prohibits the
eviction of the perpetrator of the domestic violence, sexual violence, or other
criminal activity. A tenant is encouraged to report crimes without fear of
their status as a tenant.
   I.   A tenant will not be in violation of this Section, and a nuisance
property or aggravated nuisance property cannot be established in any way,
based on:
      1.   Contact made to the police or seeking other emergency services, if
(i) the contact was made with the intent to prevent or respond to domestic
violence or sexual violence; (ii) the intervention or emergency assistance was
needed to respond to or prevent domestic violence or sexual violence; or (iii)
the contact was made by, on behalf of, or otherwise concerns an individual with
a disability and the purpose of the contact was related to that individual's
disability;
      2.   An incident or incidents of actual or threatened domestic violence
or sexual violence against the tenant, household member, or guest occurring in
the rental unit or on the premises; or
      3.   Criminal activity or a local ordinance violation occurring in the
rental unit or on the premises that is directly relating to domestic violence
or sexual violence, engaged in by a tenant, member of a tenant's household,
guest, or other party, and against a tenant, household member, guest or other
party.
   J.   A violation of this Section, a crime free lease addendum, or an
equivalent lease clause required herein may constitute good cause for immediate
termination of the lease; provided, however, that a violation shall not be good
cause to terminate the tenancy if the immediate termination of the lease would
violate Section 1-2-1.5 of the Illinois Municipal Code, as amended (65 ILCS 5/
1-2-1.5). (2016 Code; amd. Ord. 23-49, 10-3-2023)
10-18-12: PENALTIES:
   A.   Any owner, property agent, occupant or person who fails to comply with
any section of this chapter applicable thereto, and continues in this failure
after due notice and opportunity to correct, given pursuant to this chapter,
upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine of not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for
each day each section of this code is violated after expiration of the time for
correction of the violations.
   B.   Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the village from taking any other
legal or equitable remedies available to the village, including any emergency
action permitted by law when any portion of the rental residential building is
a danger to persons or property. (2016 Code)
CHAPTER 19
STRUCTURES FOR PUBLIC GATHERINGS
SECTION:
10-19-1: Permitted Structures; Compliance With Building Regulations
10-19-2: Requirements For Other Structures
10-19-3: Additional Building Requirements
10-19-1: PERMITTED STRUCTURES; COMPLIANCE WITH BUILDING REGULATIONS:
It shall be unlawful to hold, manage or conduct any meeting or entertainment of
any kind in the village in any premises other than a building constructed in
full compliance with the ordinances and laws pertaining thereto for auditorium,
theater or lodge room purposes, except in compliance with the provisions of
this chapter. (2016 Code)
10-19-2: REQUIREMENTS FOR OTHER STRUCTURES:
   A.   Inspections:
      1.   No gathering or entertainment of any kind shall be held or presented
in any premises other than a building as described in section
10-19-1 of this chapter unless such premises has been examined by the building
official not more than three (3) days before the date of such gathering and
found to be free from any fire hazard and found to be suitable for the purpose.
      2.   No structure enclosed by a roof shall be used for such purpose
unless the same is constructed of nonflammable materials.
      3.   Tents or structures covered by canvas or other materials may be so
used if such canvas or other material has been properly treated so as to be
rendered fire resistant.
   B.   Village Notified Of Event Inspections: It shall be the duty of any
person conducting, calling for or managing any gathering in any premises other
than a theater, lodge room or auditorium building constructed as provided in
section
10-19-1 of this chapter, to notify the village clerk of the date of such
intended use at least ten (10) days before such meeting is to take place. Upon
such notice, the building official shall inspect the premises to determine
whether or not it complies with the provisions hereof. Any permit issued for
any such gathering shall be subject to the condition that there shall be full
compliance with this chapter, whether or not such condition is embodied in the
permit. (2016 Code)
10-19-3: ADDITIONAL BUILDING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Exits:
      1.   Adequate unobstructed exits shall be provided in all premises used
for purposes of a meeting or entertainment of any kind in the village to permit
rapid egress of all persons attending, and there shall be at least two (2)
separate exits located at least thirty feet (30') from each other. There shall
be two (2) linear feet of doorway or exit space for each one hundred (100)
people accommodated.
      2.   All doors or gates or exits from premises used for purposes of a
meeting or entertainment of any kind in the village shall open outward, and no
such exit shall be so constructed or locked that egress from inside the
premises is blocked.
   B.   Seating:
      1.   Any stand or rows of seats used in premises used for any meeting or
entertainment of any kind in the village shall be so constructed as to be safe
for the use designed and shall be sufficiently strong to carry the same weight
and stress as is required for the construction of the auditorium floors of
theater buildings, not less than one hundred (100) pounds per square foot.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to admit to any such premises a number of
persons in excess of the number of actual seats maintained for their
accommodation. (2016 Code)
CHAPTER 20
PRESALE INSPECTION OF PROPERTIES
SECTION:
10-20-1: Purpose
10-20-2: Presale Inspections
10-20-3: Code Compliance Stamp
10-20-4: Recordation Prohibited Without Code Compliance Stamp
10-20-5: Title Notification
10-20-6: Exemptions
10-20-7: Minimum Standards
10-20-8: Inspection Procedures; Appeal
10-20-9: Follow Up Repairs; Reinspection
10-20-10: Conditional Certificate Of Compliance; Procedures
10-20-11: Payment Of Current Water Bills And Debts Due Village
10-20-12: Disclaimer Of Liability
10-20-1: PURPOSE:
It is the intent and purpose of this chapter to require a presale inspection of
residential, commercial or industrial buildings or structures in the Village
for compliance with the Village's Property Maintenance Codes prior to the
issuance of a Code compliance stamp on the deed for the sale or transfer of the
real property on which that building or structure is located. (Ord. 16-23, 5-
17-2016; amd. Ord. 18-42, 8-7-2018)
10-20-2: PRESALE INSPECTIONS:
   A.   No real property within the Village shall be sold, transferred or
retitled unless the seller obtains a presale inspection by the building
official or his or her designee. The inspection report shall state that the
building complies with all applicable building and zoning regulations of the
Village that were inspected, or in the alternative lists the building and
zoning violations.
   B.   The request for a presale inspection should be made at least thirty
(30) days prior to the scheduled date of the closing. A sale for purposes of
this section includes contract sales, exchanges, conversions to condominiums
and transfers of any legal or beneficial interest of the real estate. If the
request is not filed, the required fees are not paid, or a person participates
in such a sale in violation of this section either as a seller or by receipt of
a sales commission in connection therewith, that person shall be in violation
of this chapter and be subject to the penalties as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. Any contract executed in violation of this chapter shall be
voidable by the buyer.
   C.   The building official shall supply a form for the requested presale
inspection which shall specify the address of the real property being sold or
transferred, the improvements located thereon, the type of construction of such
improvements, and the number of apartments contained therein. If such real
property is commercial or industrial property, the number of square feet of
space shall be specified. Upon receipt of the form and payment of the
inspection fee(s) as provided in the annual fee ordinance, the building
official shall cause such buildings or structures on the real property to be
inspected. Inspections shall include all of the building or structure when all
utilities are connected and servicing the building and structure.
   D.   The inspection report will be valid provided the real property is
transferred within one hundred eighty (180) days of the date such application
is submitted and the appropriate inspection fee paid to the Village. Any real
property to be transferred more than one hundred eighty (180) days following
such date is subject to reapplication, reinspection and the repayment of fees
in accordance with this chapter as if no previous inspection report had been
issued.
   E.   If the Village's inspector is unable to inspect any portion of the
property or equipment in or on the property for any reason including but not
limited to the termination of electric, gas or water service at the time of
inspection, the Village shall require the establishment of an escrow amount
with the buyer’s attorney in an amount as determined by the Village building
official and/or his/her designee of the estimated cost to bring any uninspected
portion of the property or equipment in the building into Code compliance and
if related to those terminated utilities in an amount of not less than five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for each utility that has been terminated.
   F.   A Village of Berkeley compliance agreement shall be completed by the
party posting the escrow. If there are any violations or fees related to the
escrow or building during the escrow period and any fines, penalties, judgments
or other costs authorized by this Code are accessed; those fines, penalties,
judgments or other costs shall be deducted from the escrow prior to its
release, and, after all deductions are made, any escrow remaining will be
refunded upon compliance within thirty (30) days. (Ord. 16-23, 5-17-2016; amd.
Ord. 17-44, 7-18-2017; Ord. 17-55, 9-5-2017; Ord. 18-42, 8-7-2018)
10-20-3: CODE COMPLIANCE STAMP:
The Village Administrator, or his or her designee, shall affix the Village Code
compliance stamp to a deed only after all violations have been fully corrected
to the satisfaction of the building official who has issued a certificate of
Code compliance. In addition, no Village Code compliance stamp shall be affixed
to a deed or other document of conveyance unless and until all outstanding
fees, charges, fines, and penalties due and owing to the Village under any
rule, regulation, code or ordinance have been paid in full. Any such
outstanding fee, charge, fine, or penalty must be paid in full in cash or by
certified check. (Ord. 16-23, 5-17-2016; amd. Ord. 18-42, 8-7-2018)
10-20-4: RECORDATION PROHIBITED WITHOUT CODE COMPLIANCE STAMP:
No recordation of any title conveying or purporting to convey title to property
shall be valid unless such documentation is affixed with a stamp from the
Village. (Ord. 16-23, 5-17-2016; amd. Ord. 18-42, 8-7-2018)
10-20-5: TITLE NOTIFICATION:
The Village stamp shall be reflected on the schedule B of any title insurance
commitments or report prepared by any title company. (Ord. 16-23, 5-17-2016;
amd. Ord. 18-42, 8-7-2018)
10-20-6: EXEMPTIONS:
The following sales and transfers are exempt from the provisions of this
chapter, provided the sale and transfer in each case is accompanied by
documents and information setting forth the facts or such other record as the
Village Administrator may require. An exempt sale or transfer shall not relieve
compliance under this chapter for subsequent non-exempt sales and non-exempt
transfers of the property in question.
   A.   Transfers involving real property acquired by or from any governmental
body.
   B.   Transfers in which the deed, assignment, or other instrument of
transfer secures debt or other obligations, and no new or additional parties
take possession of the property.
   C.   Transfers in which the deed, assignment, or other instrument of
transfer, without additional consideration, confirms, corrects, modifies, or
supplements a deed, assignment, or other instrument of transfer previously
recorded or delivered.
   D.   Transfers in which the deed is a tax deed.
   E.   Transfers in which the deed, assignment, or other instrument of
transfer releases property which secures debt or other obligations.
   F.   Transfers between a subsidiary corporation and its parent or between
subsidiary corporations of a common parent either pursuant to a plan of merger
or consolidation or pursuant to a plan of reorganization providing for the sale
of substantially all of the seller's assets.
   G.   Transfers from a subsidiary corporation to its parent for no
consideration other than the cancellation or surrender of the subsidiary's
stock and transfers from a parent corporation to its subsidiary for no
consideration other than the issuance or delivery to the parent of the
subsidiary's stock.
   H.   Transfers made pursuant to a confirmed plan of reorganization as
provided under section 1146(c) of chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy
Code of 1978, as amended.
   I.   Transfers in which the deed or other instrument of transfer is issued
to the mortgagee or secured creditor pursuant to a mortgage or security
interest foreclosure proceeding or sale or pursuant to a transfer in lieu of
foreclosure.
   J.   Transfers in which an additional party is added to title and the
existing or prior titleholder remains in title and continues to reside at the
property.
   K.   Transfers by an executor or administrator to a legatee, heir, or
distributee where the transfer is being made pursuant to will or by intestacy.
   L.   Transfers from a decedent to an executor or administrator.
   M.   Transfers from an incompetent to a conservator or similar legal
representative or from a conservator or similar legal representative to a
former incompetent upon removal of disability.
   N.   Transfers from a bankrupt or person in receivership due to insolvency
to the trustee in bankruptcy or receiver, from such receiver to such trustee,
or from such trustee to such receiver or upon redelivery or retransfer by any
such transferee or successor thereto.
   O.   Transfers from a trustee to surviving, substitute, succeeding, or
additional trustees of the same trust.
   P.   Transfers upon the death of a joint tenant or tenant by the entirety to
the survivor.
   Q.   Transfers into or out of a land trust for no additional consideration
and where the titleholder or beneficial owner retains possession and continues
to reside at the property.
   R.   Vacant land. (Ord. 16-23, 5-17-2016; amd. Ord. 18-42, 8-7-2018)
10-20-7: MINIMUM STANDARDS:
The minimum construction and maintenance requirements for buildings and
structures shall be those in the Village's Property Maintenance Code as adopted
in chapter 8 of this title and those regulations that apply to existing
buildings and structures adopted in this Code. (Ord. 16-23, 5-17-2016; amd.
Ord. 18-42, 8-7-2018)
10-20-8: INSPECTION PROCEDURES; APPEAL:
   A.   Within three (3) business days after the presale inspection the Village
shall issue a written notice of violations and repairs, if any, and actions
necessary to bring the property into compliance with the regulations in this
chapter. In the event the inspection reveals a building which has been
illegally converted, the Village shall issue a notice of deconversion,
specifying the measures which must be taken in order to bring the illegally
converted structure into compliance with applicable zoning regulations.
   B.   In the event the owner disputes the determination of violations and
repairs, the owner may file a request for administrative review on a form
provided by the Village. An independent administrative adjudication Hearing
Officer appointed by the Village shall hear such appeal at the next
administrative adjudicative hearing. Upon completion of the hearing, the
Hearing Officer will issue a final determination of violation and repairs.
   C.   In the event an owner disagrees with an administrative issuance of a
notice of deconversion, the owner may appeal to the Planning and Zoning
Commission in accordance with subsection 12-3A-5A of this Code. (Ord. 16-23, 5-
17-2016; amd. Ord. 18-42, 8-7-2018)
10-20-9: FOLLOW UP REPAIRS; REINSPECTION:
A person issued a notice of violations and repairs shall proceed to make the
repairs. When all repairs are reported to the Village as being completed, the
building official shall reinspect the property for compliance. If any
violations remain, a one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) reinspection fee shall
be charged for each additional reinspection. (Ord. 16-23, 5-17-2016; amd. Ord.
18-42, 8-7-2018)
10-20-10: CONDITIONAL CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE; PROCEDURES:
An owner who is unable to complete the repairs identified through the
inspection may nevertheless sell or transfer ownership of property if:
   A.   The grantee, transferee or buyer of the real property has entered into
a compliance agreement with the Village whereby the buyer indicates receipt of
the inspection report, agrees to accept the real property subject to the
existing violations, and agrees to bring the building or structure into
compliance with this chapter within the time period determined by the building
official not to exceed one hundred eighty (180) calendar days after the
transfer of the property. The Village may deny the entering into a compliance
agreement for such violations that are determined by the building official to
be an immediate threat to the public health, safety or welfare of persons who
may enter or occupy the building. (Ord. 17-55, 9-5-2017)
   B.   No occupancy of the building shall be allowed until a reinspection is
performed by the building official and it is determined that the property is in
compliance.
   C.   In the event the buyer fails to complete the required repairs, and have
the repairs verified on reinspection, the Village shall pursue enforcement
proceedings through the Berkeley administrative adjudication process, or
through the Circuit Court of Cook County. The buyer hereby agrees to submit to
the jurisdiction and venue of the Berkeley administrative adjudication process
and the Circuit Court of Cook County and to waive service of summons subject
only to the notice requirement as required by law in order to enable the
Village to expeditiously obtain an order of compliance with this chapter and
any applicable administrative or judicial remedies to bring the structure and
property into compliance with applicable codes and regulations. (Ord. 16-23, 5-
17-2016; amd. Ord. 18-42, 8-7-2018)
10-20-11: PAYMENT OF CURRENT WATER BILLS AND DEBTS DUE VILLAGE:
The seller must pay the current water bill and other fees owed by the seller to
the Village prior to the Village affixing any stamp to the deed. In the event
the owner disputes any such obligation (or any portion thereof), the Village
Administrator or designee shall promptly provide the owner with a
predeprivation due process hearing within five (5) business days of the
request. If the owner disputes the Village's determination as to liability, the
seller may pay the bill under protest, and may pursue any remedies available to
the seller to recover the claimed overcharge. (Ord. 16-23, 5-17-2016; amd. Ord.
18-42, 8-7-2018)
10-20-12: DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY:
In issuing a certificate of or conditional certificate of compliance, the
Village and its agents do not make any warranty, representation or statement
nor does it intend to insure or guarantee to either buyer or seller of the
property subject to the point of sale inspection or any of their designees,
agents, representatives, heirs, or assigns or any other interested party,
including mortgage companies, insurance companies, banks or any other party
which may have any interest in the property subject to a compliance inspection,
nor does the Village affirm that there are no additional unnoted violations
relative to any other provision of any of the ordinances of the Village, or
relevant statutes, ordinances, rules and regulations of the County of Cook, the
State of Illinois or the United States of America. (Ord. 16-23, 5-17-2016; amd.
Ord. 18-42, 8-7-2018)
TITLE 11
SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL SUBDIVISION PROVISIONS
SECTION:
11-1-1: Purpose
11-1-2: Definitions
11-1-3: Suitability Of Land For Subdividing
11-1-4: Plat Approval Required; Division Without Platting Prohibited
11-1-5: Buildings Within Major Street Extensions
11-1-6: Variations
11-1-7: Enforcing Officer
11-1-1: PURPOSE:
For the purpose of the present and future development of the village, and for
the promotion of the public health, and the safety, comfort, morals and welfare
of persons living within the territory governed, the provisions and regulations
of this title which shall govern the subdividing and platting of lands lying
within the corporate limits of the village as now or hereafter existing and as
now or hereafter established under provisions of the statutes of the state of
Illinois, are hereby adopted as part of the official plan of the village. (Ord.
60-13, 7-13-1960)
11-1-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this title, the following words and terms shall be defined
as follows:
SUBDIVISION: A. Any change, rearrangement or resubdivision in the boundary or
divisional lines of any parcel or parcels of real estate or of any public
thoroughfares; or
   B.   The platting of a parcel or tract of land into a single numbered lot
without alteration of its boundaries; or
   C.   A planned development or planned unit development as now or hereafter
defined in this title, the village zoning ordinance, or the zoning ordinance of
Cook County, as the case may be; or
   D.   A development as now or hereafter defined in this title.
SUBDIVISION, MINOR: A subdivision of land into three (3) or fewer lots;
provided, that such subdivision does not involve any street or utility
extensions, or require any other public improvements, and does not require any
exception or departure from the regulations of this title. (Ord. 06-03, 1-17-
2006)
11-1-3: SUITABILITY OF LAND FOR SUBDIVIDING:
   A.   Lands subject to flooding and land deemed to be topographically
unsuitable should not be subdivided for residential purposes, nor for such
other uses as may increase danger to health, life or property, or aggravate
erosion or flood hazard.
   B.   The board of trustees shall not approve the subdivision of land if,
upon adequate investigation conducted by and in the opinion of the village
engineer, it has been determined that, in the best interest of the public, the
site is not suitable for subdivision and development of the kind proposed.
(Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960)
11-1-4: PLAT APPROVAL REQUIRED; DIVISION WITHOUT PLATTING PROHIBITED:
   A.   From and after the effective date hereof, no plat of any subdivision
shall be valid nor entitled to record unless and until the same has been
approved by the village board of trustees in accordance with the procedure
provided in this title, and no plat of subdivision shall be approved without
compliance with the standards of design and improvements required in this
title. (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960)
   B.   From and after the effective date hereof, no lot or tract of land
located within the village, or within the area of jurisdiction of the Berkeley
planning and zoning commission, and which contains an area of more than one-
half (1/2) acre, shall be divided or redivided in any manner into two (2) or
more lesser tracts for building site purposes without subdividing or
resubdividing and platting such tract in the manner provided by this title.
(Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960; amd. 2016 Code)
11-1-5: BUILDINGS WITHIN MAJOR STREET EXTENSIONS:
After the effective date hereof, no permanent building or structure shall be
erected within the extended street lines of proposed extensions of major
streets shown on the major street plan adopted as part of the official plan of
the village. (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960)
11-1-6: VARIATIONS:
The village board of trustees may, by ordinance, approve variations from the
requirements of this title in specific cases where such variations do not
affect the general plan or spirit of this title. (Ord. 65-9, 8-6-1965)
11-1-7: ENFORCING OFFICER:
The village administrator shall be the enforcing officer of this title, and it
shall be his/her duty to enforce the provisions hereof. The enforcing officer
may call upon any department or official of the village to furnish him/her with
such information and assistance as he/she may deem necessary for the observance
or enforcement of this title, and it shall be the duty of such department or
officer to furnish such information and assistance whenever required. (Ord. 60-
13, 7-13-1960; amd. 2016 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SUBDIVISION PLATS AND PROCEDURE
SECTION:
11-2-1: Procedure Adopted
11-2-2: Informal Meeting
11-2-3: Preliminary Plat
11-2-4: Final Plat
11-2-5: Minor Subdivisions; Final Plat
11-2-6: Subdivision And Development Agreement
11-2-1: PROCEDURE ADOPTED:
The steps and proceedings hereinafter set forth are hereby adopted as the
procedure to be followed for the approval of a subdivision of lands. (Ord. 60-
13, 7-13-1960)
11-2-2: INFORMAL MEETING:
Before preparing a preliminary plat, the subdivider should meet and consult
informally with the village administrator for the purpose of ascertaining the
locations of proposed major streets, parks, playgrounds, school sites and other
planned projects which may affect the property being considered for
subdivision. At the same meeting, the subdivider should review the minimum
standards of subdivision design set forth in this title. This informal review
should prevent unnecessary and costly revisions in the layout and development
of the subdivision. Formal application or filing of a plat is not required for
this informal advisory meeting. (Ord. 05-02, 1-18-2005; amd. 2016 Code)
11-2-3: PRELIMINARY PLAT:
   A.   After meeting informally with the village administrator, the subdivider
shall cause to be prepared a preliminary plat prior to the making of any street
improvements or the installation of any utilities. The preliminary plat shall
meet the standards of design as set forth in this title, and shall show the
following information: (Ord. 05-02, 1-18-2005; amd. 2016 Code)
      1.   Scale of one hundred feet to one inch (100' = 1") or larger.
      2.   Name of subdivision, names and addresses of the owners, the engineer
or surveyor, and the owners of the adjacent property.
      3.   Location of subdivision by section, township, range or other legal
description, together with small scale sketch showing location within the
section.
      4.   Date, approximate north point and graphic scale.
      5.   Acreage of land to be subdivided.
      6.   Zoning classification of lands to be subdivided and all adjacent
lands.
      7.   Contours at an interval of not greater than two feet (2') or at
lesser intervals if deemed necessary by the planning and zoning commission.
      8.   Boundary lines of area to be subdivided and their bearings and
distances.
      9.   Existing and proposed easements and their locations, widths and
distances, and identification of all village easements for water mains,
sanitary sewers, storm sewers, and/or overland storm drainage routes as well as
for all utility easements for gas, electric, telephone and cable television.
      10.   Streets on and adjacent to the tract and their names, widths,
approximate grades and other dimensions as may be required.
      11.   Utilities on and adjacent to the tract showing proposed conditions
to existing utility systems. Rear easements for utility poles and wires shall
be provided wherever possible.
      12.   Lot lines and lot numbers.
      13.   Sites and their acreages, if any, to be reserved or dedicated for
parks, playgrounds, schools or other public grounds; sites, if any, for
semipublic, commercial or multi-family uses.
      14.   Minimum building setback lines.
      15.   Location of railroads, drainage courses, permanent buildings or
other structures and wooded areas.
      16.   Other reasonable information, such as soil tests, if so requested
by the commission in order to make a proper review of the site.
      17.   Copies of proposed deed restrictions, if any, shall be attached to
the preliminary plat.
   B.   1. A subdivider shall present twenty (20) copies of a preliminary plat
and supplementary material to the village engineer, along with a written
application for conditional approval of same. Simultaneously, the subdivider
shall file copies of same with any or all of the following, as appropriate:
         a.   The Illinois department of transportation with respect to roadway
access where such access is a state highway;
         b.   The relevant local highway authority with respect to all other
roadway access; or
         c.   The county health department with respect to sewage disposal
systems if any part of the platted land will not be served by a public sewer
system. (Ord. 05-02, 1-18-2005)
      2.   The subdivider shall request that each department or authority
listed above review the application based solely upon safety or access control
standards and shall request that the department or authority provide written
approval or disapproval, and if disapproval, the reasons therefor along with
improvements that would remove the disapproval, to the planning and zoning
commission and village board of trustees not later than ninety (90) days from
the date the application is received.
   C.   The preliminary plat shall not be forwarded to the planning and zoning
commission until it receives approval by the village engineer.
   D.   The village administrator shall submit a copy of the preliminary plat
to the following: (Ord. 05-02, 1-18-2005; amd. 2016 Code)
      1.   Proviso Township supervisor;
      2.   School district 87, school district 93, and school district 209;
      3.   Berkeley park district and/or other appropriate park districts; and
      4.   Appropriate agencies providing sewer and water services, if other
than the village. (Ord. 05-02, 1-18-2005)
   E.   The village administrator, when submitting the copy of a preliminary
plat to the above, shall request that each return a copy of the preliminary
plat, along with notations and recommendations, within fourteen (14) days of
receipt of said preliminary plat.
   F.   The planning and zoning commission shall approve, disapprove or approve
subject to modification the said preliminary plat within ninety (90) days from
the date of the application or the date of filing by the applicant of the last
item of required supporting data, whichever date is later, unless such time is
extended by mutual consent.
   G.   If a preliminary plat is disapproved, then, within said ninety (90)
days, the planning and zoning commission shall furnish to the applicant a
written statement setting forth the reasons for such disapproval.
   H.   If a preliminary plat is approved subject to modifications, then,
within said ninety (90) days, the planning and zoning commission shall furnish
to the applicant a written statement specifying the nature of the required
modifications.
   I.   If a preliminary plat is approved by the planning and zoning
commission, the original plat and two (2) prints or copies of the preliminary
plat shall be endorsed by the planning and zoning commission as follows:
   VILLAGE OF BERKELEY
   PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION CERTIFICATE
   STATE OF ILLINOIS )
          ) ss
COUNTY OF COOK )
THE PROPOSED PLAN OF SUBDIVISION AS SHOWN ON THIS PRELIMINARY PLAT AND
ACCOMPANYING DOCUMENTS, HAS RECEIVED PRELIMINARY APPROVAL BY THE PLANNING AND
ZONING COMMISSION OF THE VILLAGE OF BERKELEY, AND SAID PLANNING AND ZONING
COMMISSION IS NOW READY TO RECEIVE THE FINAL PLAT FOR CONSIDERATION.
APPROVED THIS            DAY OF                , 2    , BY THE PLANNING AND
ZONING COMMISSION OF THE VILLAGE OF BERKELEY, ILLINOIS
      BY:
                                                                      
       CHAIR OF PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
   J.   The action of the planning and zoning commission shall be noted on
three (3) copies of the preliminary plat with any notations made at the time of
approval or disapproval of the specific changes required. The original of the
preliminary plat, so endorsed, shall remain on file with the planning and
zoning commission. One copy, so endorsed, shall be returned to the subdivider,
and one copy, so endorsed, shall be forwarded to the village administrator.
   K.   If a preliminary plat is approved by the planning and zoning
commission, the board of trustees shall accept or reject said plat, by
resolution duly adopted, within thirty (30) days after its next regularly
scheduled meeting following the action of the planning and zoning commission.
   L.   The village clerk shall attach a certified copy of the resolution of
approval or disapproval to a copy of the preliminary plat. If the preliminary
plat is disapproved, the resolution shall state the reasons for the
disapproval. A copy of the resolution shall be filed in the office of the
village clerk.
   M.   Approval of the preliminary plat shall not constitute acceptance of the
final plat and shall not qualify a plat for recording. The approval of the
preliminary plat shall lapse unless a final plat based thereon is submitted to
the village within one year from the date of such approval in the manner
specified in this chapter.
   N.   A charge shall be made for the examination and approval or disapproval
of every preliminary plat reviewed by the planning and zoning commission. At
the time a preliminary plat is submitted for approval, the subdivider shall
also submit a check payable to the village of Berkeley according to the annual
fee ordinance. The subdivider submitting a preliminary plat shall be
responsible for all fees incurred by the village pertaining to legal,
engineering and land planning expenses incurred by the village as a result of
the submission of said preliminary plat. (Ord. 05-02, 1-18-2005; amd. 2016
Code)
11-2-4: FINAL PLAT:
   A.   A final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as
approved, and it may constitute only a portion of the preliminary plat which
the subdivider proposes to record and develop.
   B.   As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision, each
subdivider may be required to dedicate land for park and recreational purposes
and for school sites, pursuant to and in accordance with this title, to serve
the immediate and future needs of the residents of the subdivision. Where the
comprehensive plan or the standards of the village call for a larger amount of
park and recreational land or school sites in a particular subdivision or
planned unit development than the developer is required to dedicate, the land
needed beyond the developer's contribution shall be reserved for subsequent
purchase by the village or other public body designated by the village;
provided, that such acquisition is made within two (2) years from the date of
approval of the final plat. (Ord. 05-02, 1-18-2005; amd. 2016 Code)
   C.   The slope, topography and geology of the dedicated site, as well as its
surroundings, must be suitable for its intended purposes. Grading on sites
dedicated for park and recreational uses shall not differ greatly from
surrounding land.
   D.   The final plat shall, in connection with and in addition to the
requirements for plats set forth in the Illinois plat act, 765 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 205/0.01 et seq., as amended from time to time, give the
following information:
      1.   The plat shall be at a scale of one hundred feet to one inch (100' =
1") or larger.
      2.   Date, title, name and location of subdivision, graphic scale and
true north point.
      3.   All dimensions, angles, bearings and similar data on the plat shall
be tied to primary control points. Locations and descriptions of said control
points shall be given. Except where deemed clearly unreasonable or infeasible
by the planning and zoning commission, these control points shall be the
located section corners of the state.
      4.   Name and right of way width of each street, easement, or other
rights of way. Each street name shall be subject to approval or modification by
the board of trustees.
      5.   Lot numbers, lot lines and frontage dimensions.
      6.   Purpose of which sites, other than residential lots, are dedicated
or reserved.
      7.   Minimum building setback lines.
      8.   Location and description of monuments.
      9.   Names and location of adjoining subdivision and streets, the
location of adjoining unplatted properties, and the names and addresses of the
owners of adjoining unplatted properties.
      10.   Certification on plat of title showing that the applicant is the
owner and a statement by such owner dedicating streets, rights of way and any
other sites for public use.
      11.   Certification on plat by surveyor or engineers as to the accuracy
of survey and plat.
      12.   Certification by the county health department when individual
sewage disposal or water systems are to be installed. (Ord. 05-02, 1-18-2005)
      13.   Certification that the subdivider has posted a duly executed
performance guarantee, pursuant to and in accordance with this title. (Ord. 05-
02, 1-18-2005; amd. 2016 Code)
      14.   Cross sections, profiles and grades of streets, curbs, gutters and
sidewalks showing locations of in-street utilities, and drawn to standard
scales and elevations shall be attached to the final plat.
      15.   Protective covenants shall either be placed directly on the final
plat or attached thereto in form for recording.
      16.   Certification on the plat by the planning and zoning commission
that the plat has been approved for recording in the office of the county
recorder of deeds.
      17.   A notarized statement indicating, to the best of the owner's
knowledge, the school district in which each tract, parcel, lot or block lies.
(Ord. 05-02, 1-18-2005)
   E.   Application for final approval of a plat shall be made no later than
one year after preliminary approval has been granted. Further, the steps for
approval of a preliminary and final plat may be combined if a petitioner wishes
to proceed directly to final plat approval. (Ord. 05-02, 1-18-2005; amd. 2016
Code)
   F.   The person requesting a subdivision or resubdivision shall present
twenty (20) copies of the final plat with any street profiles or plans required
by the village engineer. Within three (3) business days after the plat is
submitted to the village for approval, the village shall notify the
superintendent of the school board of each school district in which the
proposed subdivided land is located that the plat has been submitted for
approval and is available for inspection. Said notice shall contain the date,
time and place of the hearing to approve or disapprove the plat, and shall be
served by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal delivery.
   G.   The village engineer shall check to determine that the plat, and other
required submittals, have been prepared and made in satisfactory compliance
with this section. If found satisfactory, the village engineer shall return the
one copy of the final plat to the planning and zoning commission with his
approval certified thereon within ten (10) days of receipt thereof.
   H.   One copy shall be transmitted to the county health department when
individual sewerage disposal or water supply systems are to be installed. If
the plat meets the approval of the county health department, it shall return
the copy with its approval certified thereon within ten (10) days of receipt
thereof.
   I.   If a final plan is approved by the planning and zoning commission, the
original plat and two (2) prints or copies of the final plat shall be endorsed
by the planning and zoning commission as follows:
   VILLAGE OF BERKELEY
   PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION CERTIFICATE
STATE OF ILLINOIS )
          ) ss
COUNTY OF COOK )
THE PROPOSED PLAN OF SUBDIVISION AS SHOWN ON THIS FINAL PLAT AND ACCOMPANYING
DOCUMENTS, HAS RECEIVED FINAL APPROVAL BY THE VILLAGE OF BERKELEY PLANNING AND
ZONING COMMISSION.
APPROVED THIS            DAY OF                , 20   , BY THE PLANNING AND
ZONING COMMISSION OF THE VILLAGE OF BERKELEY, ILLINOIS
      BY:
                                                                       
       CHAIR OF PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
   J.   When all required drawings, maps, and other documents have been
submitted and if all such material meets the requirements herein, the village
board of trustees shall approve or disapprove the final plat, by resolution
duly adopted, within sixty (60) days from the date of filing the last required
document or from the date of filing the application for final approval,
whichever date is later. The sixty (60) day period may be extended by mutual
consent of the parties.
   K.   If the proposed plat is disapproved, the village clerk shall attach a
certified copy of the resolution disapproving same to a copy of the final plat.
This resolution shall state the reasons for the disapproval. A copy of the
resolution shall be filed in the office of the village clerk.
   L.   If the plat is approved, the village clerk shall attach a certified
copy of the resolution to a copy of the plat. A copy of the resolution, the
final plat, and all supporting documentation shall be filed in the office of
the village clerk.
   M.   The village clerk shall record, or cause to be recorded, a copy of the
final plat in the office of the county recorder of deeds. The subdivider shall
be fully responsible for the costs of such recordation. (Ord. 05-02, 1-18-2005)
11-2-5: MINOR SUBDIVISIONS; FINAL PLAT:
   A.   Application For Minor Subdivision; Fee: Applications for minor
subdivision approval shall be submitted on an application form approved by the
planning and zoning commission, and accompanied by an application fee as set
forth in the annual fee ordinance. The applicant shall furnish at least five
(5) copies of the application and proposed final plat for the minor
subdivision, which plat shall conform to the requirements of subsection F of
this section. (Ord. 06-03, 1-17-2006; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Village Administrator Review And Approval:
      1.   The village administrator, or his/her designee, shall conduct an
initial review of the application and proposed final plat of the minor
subdivision for general completeness. Within ten (10) business days of the
application filing date, the village administrator shall notify the applicant
in writing as to whether the application is complete or whether it has
deficiencies. The specific deficiencies shall be listed in the notification,
and no deficient application will be accepted unless and until such
deficiencies are corrected. In the event that the village administrator does
not deliver notice to the applicant within ten (10) business days after the
application filing date, the application shall be deemed deficient and
rejected.
      2.   The village administrator, or his/her designee, shall review an
application for final plat of minor subdivision approval for compliance with
applicable zoning and subdivision requirements. The village administrator shall
report the findings of the review to the planning and zoning commission.
   C.   Planning And Zoning Commission Review And Recommendation:
      1.   Notice Requirements:
         a.   The planning and zoning commission shall review an application
for final plat of minor subdivision approval only after public notice, as set
forth in this subsection, has been provided;
         b.   The applicant shall notify in writing, by first class mail or
hand delivery, all adjacent taxpayers of record, including taxpayers of record
immediately across streets and other rights of way, not less than fifteen (15)
days nor more than thirty (30) days in advance of the scheduled planning and
zoning commission meeting date. The notice shall contain:
            (1)   Street address, legal description or detailed location of the
subject property;
            (2)   Statement describing the name of the subdivision and the
number of proposed lots;
            (3)   Name and address of applicant;
            (4)   Name and address of the legal and beneficial owner, if any,
of the subject property; and
            (5)   Date, time, and location of the planning and zoning
commission meeting.
         c.   At the planning and zoning commission meeting, the applicant
shall present an affidavit that the above listed notice requirements have been
satisfied.
      2.   Public Meeting: Within forty five (45) business days of the village
administrator's acceptance of an application for final plat of minor
subdivision approval, the planning and zoning commission shall conduct a public
meeting to review the application and make a recommendation, by resolution duly
adopted, to the board of trustees to approve, deny, or approve with conditions
the final plat of minor subdivision. The planning and zoning commission review
period may be extended by mutual consent of the planning and zoning commission
and applicant. The failure of the planning and zoning commission to act within
the time period set forth in this subsection shall be deemed an approval of the
final plat of minor subdivision.
   D.   Board Of Trustees Action: The village administrator shall report to the
board of trustees the recommendation of the planning and zoning commission.
Within thirty (30) business days after receipt of the planning and zoning
commission recommendation, the board of trustees, at a regular meeting, shall,
by resolution duly adopted, approve, deny, or approve with conditions the final
plat of minor subdivision, as well as all related agreements and other
approvals. In the event that the final plat of minor subdivision is denied, the
village administrator shall notify the applicant in writing of the reasons for
such denial. The failure of the board of trustees to act within the time period
set forth in this subsection shall be deemed an approval of the final plat of
minor subdivision.
   E.   Copies Provided; Filing Final Plat: Following approval of a final plat
of minor subdivision, the applicant shall furnish the village administrator
with a mylar original of the final plat of minor subdivision that includes all
original certifications and signatures required under subsection F of this
section, and seven (7) copies of the fully executed mylar. The village
administrator shall cause the final plat of minor subdivision to be recorded in
the office of the county recorder. The applicant shall be responsible for all
such recording fees.
   F.   Standards Of Final Plat: A final plat for a minor subdivision shall, in
addition to the requirements of the Illinois plat act, 765 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 205/0.01 et seq., as amended from time to time, conform to the
following standards:
      1.   Be no less than eight and one-half inches by fourteen inches (81/2"
x 14"), nor more than thirty inches by thirty six inches (30" x 36") in size,
and include no more than three (3) sheets.
      2.   Have a scale not less than one inch equals fifty feet (1" = 50'),
with a north arrow.
      3.   Describe or identify the angular and linear measurements of:
         a.   Subdivision boundaries;
         b.   Blocks, lots, and outlots;
         c.   Lot corners and monuments;
         d.   Permanent and temporary easements;
         e.   Adjacent public and private rights of way;
         f.   Other information as may be required by the village engineer; and
      4.   Name and current mailing address of the Illinois professional land
surveyor who prepared the plat.
      5.   The following village signatures and certification blocks:
         a.   Mayor: Indicating date of plat approval by the mayor and board of
trustees; (Ord. 06-03, 1-17-2006)
         b.   Village Finance Director: Indicating that there are no delinquent
or current unpaid special assessments associated with the subject property;
(Ord. 06-03, 1-17-2006; amd. 2016 Code)
         c.   Village Engineer: Indicating that the final engineering plans and
specifications for the subject property meet the minimum requirements of the
village; and
         d.   Chair Of Planning And Zoning Commission: Indicating the date of
the planning and zoning commission recommendation regarding the plat.
      6.   The following state and county signature and certification blocks
(in the form prescribed by applicable laws and regulations):
         a.   County clerk: Indicating that there are no delinquent or current
unpaid special assessments or taxes associated with the subject property and
that all applicable fees have been received;
         b.   Illinois department of transportation: If the subject property
will have access onto a state highway, indicating that such access is approved;
and
         c.   County highway department: If the subject property will have
access onto a county highway, indicating that such access is approved.
      7.   The following certifications from an Illinois professional land
surveyor certifying that:
         a.   The subject property has been surveyed and subdivided in
accordance with a specific legal description;
         b.   Certain monuments and iron pipes have been located or will be
located on the subject property; and
         c.   Location of subject property in relation to special flood hazard
areas, as identified by the federal emergency management agency on the most
recent flood insurance rate map.
      8.   All owners of the subject property and all mortgagees shall sign, as
evidenced by the signature and seal of a notary public, that they consent to
the subdivision of the subject property.
      9.   If the subdivision and development of the subject property will
alter surface drainage patterns, the applicant's engineer shall sign the plat
and certify that the subdivision design adequately accounts for changes in
surface drainage patterns in accordance with section 2 of the Illinois plat
act, 765 Illinois Compiled Statutes 205/2, as amended from time to time.
      10.   The final plat of minor subdivision shall also include statements
and notations, in forms approved by the planning and zoning commission,
concerning the dedication of any land or granting of any easements, and any
restrictions thereto. (Ord. 06-03, 1-17-2006)
11-2-6: SUBDIVISION AND DEVELOPMENT AGREEMENT:
All final plat applications may include a proposed subdivision or development
agreement, as the case may be, in a form approved by the planning and zoning
commission and village attorney. The subdivision or development agreement
shall, without limitation, include or reference the following minimum
information: (Ord. 05-02, 1-18-2005; amd. 2016 Code)
   A.   Proposed site development schedule for installation of guaranteed
public and private improvements, referencing the final plat or development
plan, and final engineering plans, and stipulating the improvements which must
be installed prior to issuance of a building permit or certificate of occupancy
for the buildings or structures to be constructed.
   B.   Description and estimated cost of public and private improvements, in a
form and amount approved by the village engineer, providing a detailed
accounting of the various types and amounts of improvements included in the
estimate.
   C.   Type and summary of terms of performance guarantee for the construction
of public and private improvements.
   D.   Method of satisfying the applicable requirements for dedicating, or
contributing for the future acquisition or development of, public grounds in
accordance with chapter 3 of this title.
   E.   A summary of the covenants, restrictions and easements necessary for
the subdivision or development, including the responsibilities of a property
owners' association, if proposed.
   F.   Agreement to pay:
      1.   A fair and equitable share of all water, sanitary sewer and/or storm
sewer improvements developed in the area surrounding the property that benefit
the property, as determined by the village engineer.
      2.   All applicable costs, payments, permit fees or other fees
attributable to the subdivision or development.
   G.   An acknowledgment by the owner, subdivider or developer, as the case
may be, that the village is not and shall not be, in any way, liable for any
damages or injuries that may be sustained as the result of village review and
approval of any plans for the subject property.
   H.   Such other acknowledgments, indemnifications and hold harmless
agreements as the village administrator and village attorney may require.
   I.   All other provisions deemed necessary by the planning and zoning
commission in order to fulfill the purpose and intent of this title. (Ord. 05-
02, 1-18-2005)
CHAPTER 3
STANDARDS OF DESIGN AND REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
11-3-1: Minimum Standards
11-3-2: Streets And Alleys
11-3-3: Sidewalks
11-3-4: Blocks
11-3-5: Lots
11-3-6: Building Setback Lines
11-3-7: Easements
11-3-8: Dedication Of Public Grounds
11-3-9: Natural Features
11-3-10: Trees
11-3-11: Water And Sewer Systems
11-3-12: Inspections
11-3-13: Performance Guarantee
11-3-14: Acceptance Of Improvements
11-3-1: MINIMUM STANDARDS:
The requirements of this chapter are hereby adopted as the minimum standards of
design of the subdivision and of improvements required to be constructed or
installed therein. (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960)
11-3-2: STREETS AND ALLEYS:
   A.   Streets:
      1.   No topsoil shall be scaled off any property prior to issuance of
building permit.
      2.   A public street or streets shall be provided to afford convenient
access to all property within the subdivision. No private street or
thoroughfare shall be permitted.
      3.   The proposed street system shall extend existing adjoining streets
unless the extension thereof would not be practical.
      4.   Where, in the opinion of the village board, it is desirable to
provide for street access to adjoining property, the proposed streets shall be
extended by dedication to the boundary of such property.
   B.   Alleys: Alleys shall be provided at the rear of all lots or tracts
intended for business, commercial or industrial use, and multiple-family use,
but shall not be provided in residential blocks.
   C.   Widths Of Streets And Alleys:
      1.   The minimum width of right of way of a street, alley or
thoroughfare, measured between the lines of property abutting upon the right of
way, shall not be less than the following:
         a.   Major streets, being those to be used primarily for fast or heavy
traffic, and shown on the major thoroughfare plan, and streets through business
areas, eighty (80) to one hundred feet (100') as required.
         b.   Residential streets, sixty six feet (66').
         c.   Cul-de-sacs, which are permanent dead end streets, with permanent
turnaround having an inside diameter of not less than fifty feet (50'). (Ord.
60-13, 7-13-1960)
         d.   Alleys, to serve multi-family residential blocks, twenty feet
(20'). (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960; amd. 2016 Code)
      2.   The entire right of way shall be provided where any part of the
subdivision is on both sides of the right of way.
      3.   When the subdivision is located on only one side of an existing
right of way, which is less than the required width, the subdivider shall
dedicate additional right of way to meet the requirement, but not exceeding
one-half (1/2) of the total required width.
   D.   Grades Of Streets: Grades of major streets shall not exceed seven
percent (7%). Grades of other streets shall not exceed ten percent (10%).
   E.   Curves In Streets: Curves in streets shall be permitted, provided, no
curve shall be greater than that approved by traffic engineers as reasonably
safe for traffic at the particular location of the curve.
   F.   Street Jogs: Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one
hundred twenty five feet (125') shall not be permitted if the same can be
reasonably avoided.
   G.   Pavements:
      1.   Street Pavement:
         a.   All streets within the subdivision shall be improved with a
durable hard surface roadway. The pavement shall be equal to or superior to
existing paved streets in the village.
         b.   The minimum width of the paved roadway, back to back of curb,
shall be as follows:
            (1)   On residential streets, not less than twenty seven feet
(27').
            (2)   On major streets, not less than fifty feet (50').
            (3)   On streets through business areas, not less than fifty feet
(50').
         c.   Before any paving work is commenced, all street grading shall be
properly completed as shown on the grading plan submitted with final plat of
subdivision.
         d.   After grading of the streets is completed and approved, and
before the base course of the roadway pavement is laid, all of the underground
work, such as sewer, water and gas mains, house service connections therewith,
and any underground conduits for electric and telephone lines shall be
completely installed in place and approved by village engineer.
         e.   The surface course of the roadway pavement shall not be laid
until the backfilling of all trenches dug for the installation of the
aforementioned utility services have completely settled, or compacted to the
satisfaction of the village engineer.
         f.   Before the surface course of the roadway pavement is laid, all
depressions in the base course shall be properly filled and brought to the
required grade so as to create a level surface.
      2.   Alley Pavement: All alleys shall be improved with a roadway
consisting of not less than five inches (5") when thoroughly compacted or eight
inches (8") crushed stone or gravel of the following width: Through business
areas, not less than twenty feet (20'). (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960)
   H.   Curb And Gutter: A suitable curb and gutter shall be constructed along
the outside lines of all street pavements. (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960; amd. 2016
Code)
   I.   Street Names:
      1.   Proposed streets which are obviously in alignment or continuation of
existing streets already named shall bear the name of such existing streets. In
no case shall the name for proposed streets duplicate existing street names,
irrespective of the use of the suffix street, avenue, road, boulevard, drive,
place or court, or an abbreviation thereof.
      2.   All private driveways crossing public sidewalks shall have seven
inches (7") of concrete at the area where driveway crosses or connects with the
sidewalk. (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960)
   J.   Street Signs: An appropriate street sign shall be erected at each
street intersection within the subdivision. The type of sign and the location
thereof shall be subject to the approval and direction of the village
superintendent of public works. (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960; amd. 2016 Code)
   K.   Ornamental Street Lighting: Ornamental street lighting shall be
provided throughout the subdivision by the subdivider and shall be installed
subject to the approval of the village board. (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960)
11-3-3: SIDEWALKS:
If the property subdivided is located within the corporate limits of the
village, or immediately adjacent thereto, sidewalks are required to be
constructed to compare with existing village sidewalks. (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960)
11-3-4: BLOCKS:
Blocks shall be wide enough to allow two (2) tiers of lots, except where
fronting on major streets or prevented by topographical conditions or size of
the property, in which case, the village board will approve a single tier of
lots. (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960)
11-3-5: LOTS:
   A.   Insofar as practical, side lot lines shall be at right angles to
straight street lines or radial curved street lines.
   B.   Residential lots served by a public sewerage system and public water
supply system shall not be less than fifty feet (50') wide at the building
setback line, nor less than six thousand (6,000) square feet in area.
   C.   The size of lots or tracts laid out and intended for business use shall
be adequate to provide for off street service and paved parking facilities
required by the type of use and development contemplated.
   D.   The size and width of lots shall in no case be less than the minimum
requirements of the village zoning ordinance. (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960)
11-3-6: BUILDING SETBACK LINES:
The minimum depth of building setback lines from the street need not be greater
than the requirements fixed by the village zoning code. (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960;
amd. 2016 Code)
11-3-7: EASEMENTS:
Where no alleys are provided, there shall be dedicated easements of not less
than ten feet (10') in width for poles, wires, conduits, storm and sanitary
sewer, gas, water or other utility pipes or lines along the rear of each lot
and along the side lot lines where necessary. The easements shall be so laid
out that a proper continuity may be had for such utilities from lot to lot and
from block to block. No building shall be constructed upon the easements. (Ord.
60-13, 7-13-1960; amd. 2016 Code)
11-3-8: DEDICATION OF PUBLIC GROUNDS:
   A.   Whenever a proposed subdivision has an area of two (2) acres or more
(exclusive of public streets and thoroughfares), the subdivider may be required
to dedicate a reasonable area therein for public grounds for park, playground,
recreational or similar public purpose, and school grounds, which area so
dedicated shall be in addition to all dedications for public streets and
thoroughfares.
   B.   In determining the area to be so dedicated as public grounds, the
village board shall give due consideration to the present and anticipated
density of population within such subdivision, to the age range and other
characteristics of the anticipated population, which can influence the kind and
amount of public grounds and to the present and future prospective public
requirements for such public grounds.
   C.   No subdivider shall be required to dedicate as public grounds more than
five percent (5%) of the total area of any subdivision, exclusive of public
streets and ways, contained within such subdivision.
   D.   The subdivider shall be required to provide a title insurance policy,
acceptable in form and substance to the village attorney, for any public
grounds dedicated to the village that shall show such public grounds free and
clear of all liens and encumbrances. The subdivider shall also grant all
necessary easements and licenses, acceptable in form and substance to the
village attorney, to the village providing public and emergency access to the
public grounds.
   E.   All sites shall be dedicated in a condition ready for full service of
electricity, water, sewer and streets (including enclosed drainage and curb and
gutter) as applicable to the location of the site, or acceptable provision made
therefor. The sidewalks and trees normally included within the definition of
"improved" sites may be deleted due to the delay time between dedication of any
such school site and the construction of school facilities thereon. (Ord. 05-
02, 1-18-2005)
11-3-9: NATURAL FEATURES:
In all subdivisions, due regard shall be given to the preservation of natural
features such as large trees, watercourses, historical and similar community
assets, which, if preserved, will add attractiveness and value to the property.
(Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960)
11-3-10: TREES:
Trees are to be planted on part of the subdivision devoted to public use. The
species of trees and the location thereof shall be subject to the requirements
of title 8, chapter 3 of this code. (Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960; amd. 2016 Code)
11-3-11: WATER AND SEWER SYSTEMS:
   A.   Water Supply: When located within the service area of a public water
supply system, water mains not less than six inches (6") in diameter shall be
constructed throughout the entire subdivision in such manner as to serve
adequately all lots and tracts with connection to such public system, together
with shutoff valves and fire hydrants. Fire hydrants shall be installed
throughout entire water system in accordance with the regulations of this code
and with approval of the village engineer and chief of the fire department.
(Ord. 60-13, 7-13-1960; amd. 2016 Code)
   B.   Storm Drains: An adequate system of stormwater drainage shall be
constructed and installed, consisting of pipes, tiles, manholes, inlets and
other necessary facilities, that will prevent the accumulation of stormwater at
any place under normal conditions. Open ditches shall be prohibited. Such
drainage system shall be subject to approval by the village engineer.
   C.   Sanitary Sewers: When located within the service area of a public
sanitary sewerage system, sanitary sewer mains shall be constructed throughout
the entire subdivision in such manner as to serve adequately all lots and
tracts with connection to such public system.
   D.   House Services:
      1.   House services shall be constructed to connect with the utility
service mains constructed within any street or thoroughfare, to serve each
adjoining lot, tract or building site. Such house services shall extend from
the main to a point at least eight feet (8') beyond the outside curb lines of
the proposed roadway pavement in the street, and at least one foot (1') beyond
the outside lines of proposed alley pavement.
      2.   All such house services connected with utility mains constructed
within any street or thoroughfare shall be located at the approximate
centerline of each lot, and no deviation shall be made from this requirement
except upon prior approval by the village engineer.
