Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 210 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
14-3-9: OTHER DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   The board of trustees shall take into account flood hazards to the
extent that they are known in all official actions related to land management,
use and development.
   B.   New subdivisions, manufactured home parks, annexation agreements and
planned unit developments (PUDs) within the SFHA shall be reviewed to assure
that the proposed developments are consistent with sections
14-3-5,
14-3-6,
14-3-7 and
14-3-8 of this chapter and the need to minimize flood damage. Plats or plans
for new subdivisions, mobile home parks and planned unit developments (PUDs)
shall include a signed statement by a registered professional engineer that the
plat or plans account for changes in the drainage of surface waters in
accordance with the plat act 1 , as amended.
   C.   Proposals for new subdivisions, manufactured home parks, travel trailer
parks, planned unit developments (PUDs) and additions to manufactured home
parks and subdivisions shall include base flood or 100-year frequency flood
elevation data and floodway delineations. Where this information is not
available from an existing study filed with the Illinois state water survey,
the applicant's engineer shall be responsible for calculating the base flood or
100-year frequency flood elevation per subsection 14-3-4D of this chapter and
the floodway delineation per the definition of "regulatory floodway" in section
14-3-2 of this chapter and submitting it to the state water survey and IDNR/OWR
for review and approval as best available regulatory data.
   D.   Streets, blocks, lots, parks and other public grounds shall be located
and laid out in such a manner as to preserve and utilize natural streams and
channels. Wherever possible, the floodplains shall be included within parks or
other public grounds.
   E.   The board of trustees shall not approve any planned unit development
(PUD) or plat of subdivision located outside the corporate limits unless such
agreement or plat is in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (2016
Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 765 ILCS 205/2.
14-3-10: VARIANCES:
   A.   No variances shall be granted to any development located in a
"regulatory floodway", as defined in section
14-3-2 of this chapter. However, when a development proposal is located outside
of a regulatory floodway, and whenever the standards of this chapter place
undue hardship on a specific development proposal, the applicant may apply to
the village engineer for a variance. The village engineer shall review the
applicant's request for a variance and shall submit its recommendation to the
board of trustees.
   B.   No variance shall be granted unless the applicant demonstrates that:
      1.   The development activity cannot be located outside the SFHA;
      2.   An exceptional hardship would result if the variance were not
granted;
      3.   The relief requested is the minimum necessary;
      4.   There will be no additional threat to public health, safety,
beneficial stream uses and functions, especially aquatic habitat, or creation
of a nuisance;
      5.   There will be no additional public expense for flood protection,
lost environmental stream uses and functions, rescue or relief operations,
policing or repairs to streambeds and stream banks, roads, utilities or other
public facilities;
      6.   The provisions of subsections 14-3-5C and 14-3-7C of this chapter
shall still be met;
      7.   The activity is not in a regulatory floodway;
      8.   The applicant's circumstances are unique and do not represent a
general problem; and
      9.   The granting of the variance will not alter the essential character
of the area involved, including existing stream uses.
   C.   The village engineer shall notify an applicant in writing that a
variance from the requirements of section
14-3-8 of this chapter that would lessen the degree of protection to a building
will:
      1.   Result in increased premium rates for flood insurance up to amounts
as high as twenty five dollars ($25.00) for one hundred dollars ($100.00) of
insurance coverage;
      2.   Increase the risks to life and property; and
      3.   Require that the applicant proceed with the knowledge of these risks
and that he will acknowledge in writing that he assumes the risk and liability.
(2016 Code)
14-3-11: DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY:
The degree of flood protection required by this chapter is considered
reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on available information
derived from engineering and specific methods of study. Larger floods may
occur, or flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This
chapter does not imply that development, either inside or outside of the SFHA
will be free from flooding or damage. This chapter does not create liability on
the part of the village or any officer or employee thereof for any flood damage
that results from reliance on this chapter or any administrative decision made
lawfully hereunder. (2016 Code)
14-3-12: VIOLATION; PENALTIES:
   A.   Violation: Failure to comply with the requirements of a permit or
conditions of a variance resolution shall be deemed to be a violation of this
title.
   B.   Determination And Notice Of Violation: Upon due investigation, the
village engineer may determine that a violation of the minimum standards of
this chapter exists. The village engineer shall notify the owner in writing of
such violation.
   C.   Injunction And Penalty:
      1.   If the owner fails, after ten (10) days' notice, to correct the
violation, the village may make application to the circuit court for an
injunction requiring conformance with this chapter or make such other order as
the court deems necessary to secure compliance with this chapter.
      2.   Any person who violates this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof,
be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense.
      3.   A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues.
      4.   The village may record a notice of violation on the title to the
property.
   D.   Insurance Suspension: The village engineer shall inform the owner that
any such violation is considered a wilful act to increase flood damages and,
therefore, may cause coverage by a standard flood insurance policy to be
suspended.
   E.   Other Remedies: Nothing herein shall prevent the village from taking
such other lawful action to prevent or remedy any violations. All costs
connected therewith shall accrue to the person or persons responsible. (2016
Code)
14-3-13: ABROGATION AND GREATER RESTRICTIONS:
This chapter not intended to repeal, abrogate or impair any existing easements,
covenants or deed restrictions. Where this chapter and other ordinances,
easements, covenants or deed restrictions conflict or overlap, whichever
imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. (2016 Code)
CHAPTER 4
PAVEMENT DESIGN STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS
SECTION:
14-4-1: Introduction
14-4-2: General Specifications And Design Requirements; Street Classifications
14-4-3: Pavement Width
14-4-4: Pavement Design
14-4-5: Material Testing
14-4-6: Flexible Pavements
14-4-7: Rigid Pavements
14-4-8: Driveways, Driveway Aprons, Loading/Unloading Berths And Storage Areas
14-4-9: Allowable Pavement Construction Materials
14-4-10: Subgrade Preparation
14-4-11: Street Grades
14-4-12: Sight Distances
14-4-13: Curbs And Gutters
14-4-14: Sidewalks And Carriage Walks
14-4-15: Maintenance And Responsibility
14-4-1: INTRODUCTION:
   A.   The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all
streets to be dedicated to the public and all private streets shall be
considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to reasonable
circulation of traffic within the development and adjoining lands, to
topographical conditions, to runoff of stormwater, to public convenience and
safety, and in their appropriate relations to the proposed uses of the area to
be served. All traffic intersections and confluences must encourage safe and
efficient traffic flow.
   B.   Within this chapter, the design requirements for pavements, as well as
curbs and gutters and sidewalks, will be defined. Supplementary improvements,
such as sewer, water, lighting and landscaping, will be discussed in the
following chapters of this title. (2016 Code)
14-4-2: GENERAL SPECIFICATIONS AND DESIGN REQUIREMENTS; STREET CLASSIFICATIONS:
   A.   All street pavements within the village shall be constructed in
accordance with one or more of the following as they apply:
      1.   "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", state of
Illinois, department of transportation, current edition.
      2.   "Manual For Structural Design Of Portland Cement Concrete Pavement",
department of transportation, current edition.
      3.   "Manual Of Instruction For The Structural Design Of Bituminous
Pavements On Projects Involving MFT And FAUS Funds", department of
transportation, current edition.
   B.   Design requirements for the pavement will be related to the street
classification as set forth by the village engineer.
   C.   The classification of new streets as well as variations to street
classifications shown in table 1 of this section for a given street, must be
submitted to the village engineer for his review prior to submittal of the
preliminary plat to the plan commission.
   D.   Street classifications are defined as follows:
      1.   Arterial Streets: An arterial street is a federal, state, county or
township roadway linking consecutive municipalities, counties or townships. The
following streets are classified as arterial streets:
St. Charles Road.
      2.   Major Collector Streets: A major collector street is a municipal
roadway of considerable continuity that connects municipalities or various
sections of that municipality. The following streets are classified as major
collector streets:
   Reserved.
      3.   Local Collector Streets: A local collector street is a municipal
roadway that carries traffic from minor streets to major streets or arterials,
including principal entrance streets of residential developments. The following
streets are classified as local collector streets:
   Reserved.
      4.   Industrial/Business Service Streets: An industrial/business service
street is a municipal roadway bounded by property zoned industrial/business.
Industrial/business zoning on one side is sufficient for an industrial/business
service street classification.
      5.   Minor Multi-Family Residential Streets: A minor multi- family
residential street is a roadway that provides access to abutting property zoned
for multi-family. Multi-family zoning on one side is sufficient for the minor
multi-family classification.
      6.   Minor Single-Family Residential Streets: A minor single- family
residential street is a roadway that provides access to abutting property zoned
for single-family.
   E.   The pavement design and right of way chart (table 1 of this section) is
intended to show minimum right of way widths and the minimum design standards
for a particular street classification. If, in the opinion of the village
engineer, traffic use or geometric considerations for a road or a part of a
road warrant a greater right of way width, a wider pavement width and/or a
greater structural number than listed on the chart, the village engineer shall
submit his written reasons to the planning and zoning commission prior to the
approval of the preliminary plat. Variations to the requirements of table 1 of
this section shall be considered only as a variation of this chapter.

(2016 Code)
14-4-3: PAVEMENT WIDTH:
All new streets, either public or private, within the corporate limits of the
village proposed after the effective date hereof shall be improved with roadway
paving and bordered by portland cement concrete curbs, in accordance with the
pavement design and right of way chart in section
14-4-2, table 1 of this chapter. Driveways to individual residential buildings
do not require curb and gutter or concrete barrier curb. Driveways to all other
buildings require combination concrete curb and gutter or concrete barrier
curb. (2016 Code)
14-4-4: PAVEMENT DESIGN:
   A.   All pavement shall be designed in accordance with the previously
referenced standards and manuals of the department of transportation. The
design thickness shall be dependent on the soil support value and projected
traffic factor. However, in no case shall structural numbers be less than those
shown in section
14-4-2, table 1 of this chapter.
   B.   All subgrade material shall have a minimum Illinois bearing ratio (IBR)
of 2.5. Subgrade material having an IBR less than 2.5 shall be removed and
replaced with a suitable fill material, or the pavement must be designed to
compensate for the soil conditions. The soil support IBR values selected for
use by the designer shall represent a minimum value for the soil to be used.
   C.   At the request of the village engineer, a copy of all design
assumptions and computations on which the proposed design is based shall be
submitted. (2016 Code)
14-4-5: MATERIAL TESTING:
   A.   The requirements of this chapter shall be applicable where deemed
necessary by the village engineer.
   B.   Concurrent with construction of any pavement within the corporate
limits of the village, the developer must furnish the village engineer with
copies of the certificates of testing from the Illinois department of
transportation, Cook County highway department, or from a testing laboratory
which has been prequalified by the Illinois department of transportation for
bituminous aggregate mixture, bituminous mixture, class I and pozzolanic base
course, type A as follows:
      1.   Proportioning tests: Minimum of one plant inspection per day is
required to provide control of moisture and mix gradation.
      2.   Density tests: A minimum required of two (2) per day, one per
location, or one per five hundred (500) tons, whichever shall provide the
greatest number of compaction tests. The thickness of each lift will be
verified by string line and completed pavement by cores where required by the
village engineer.
      3.   Certificates of testing for portland cement concrete shall be
required to verify portland cement concrete design for a minimum of twenty
eight (28) day compressive strength of three thousand five hundred (3,500) psi:
One set of cylinders (1 to 7 day break, 2 to 28 day break) shall be required
for each day's pour or for every fifty (50) yards.
      4.   a. Prior to the installation of the bituminous surface course, but
after installation of the binder course, the contractor or developer shall
furnish the village engineer with a copy of a Dynaflect pavement evaluation
program report of the completed pavement improvements.
         b.   The Dynaflect pavement evaluation program shall be performed
according to the Dynaflect pavement evaluation specification on file in the
office of the village engineer. The program shall generally embody the
following testing/pavement evaluation techniques:
            (1)   Environmental study (frost cycle, drainage, etc.) pavement
surface evaluation.
            (2)   Soil borings at approximately one location per mile.
            (3)   Dynamic pavement deflection analysis (Dynaflect machine or
equal correlated with Benkelman beam or equal).
         c.   The program shall evaluate the existing condition of the base and
binder course in maximum two hundred foot (200') sections. It shall determine
whether or not the pavement section with the addition of the surface course of
design thickness will be projected to meet a ten (10) year pavement life or
greater.
         d.   If the pavement section is projected to meet life expectancy of
ten (10) years or more, then the contractor or developer may proceed as
indicated in subsection 14-4-6D of this chapter.
         e.   If the pavement section is not projected to meet a life
expectancy of ten (10) years or more, then the report shall propose asphalt
overlays in excess of the surface course design thickness or pavement
reconstruction to bring the new pavement section to a ten (10) year life
expectancy. The village engineer shall evaluate the results of the report and
inform the contractor or developer as to the required pavement operation for
each section in question. Upon resolution of these pavement operations, the
contractor or developer may proceed as indicated in subsection 14-4-6D of this
chapter.
      5.   The Dynaflect pavement evaluation program shall not be considered
valid unless the wearing surface was applied during the same construction
season. (2016 Code)
14-4-6: FLEXIBLE PAVEMENTS:
   A.   The design of all flexible pavements shall be based on the minimum
structural design number for the type of street in question.
   B.   A minimum of 2.5 inches of compacted asphalt is required on all
pavements with a structural number of 3.00 to 3.99. This surface shall consist
of one inch (1") wearing surface, class I, and 1.5 inches of binder course,
class I. Pavements with a structural number of 4.00 to 4.99 will require three
inches (3") of asphalt. This surface shall consist of one inch (1") wearing
surface class I and two inches (2") of binder class I.
   C.   The bituminous binder course for all flexible type pavements must set
for a minimum of nine (9) months, including a winter and a spring.
   D.   After receipt of the Dynaflect pavement evaluation program report, the
village engineer will review said report and will perform an inspection of the
existing base and binder courses. All base and binder course failures will then
be repaired to the village engineer's satisfaction. (2016 Code)
14-4-7: RIGID PAVEMENTS:
The design of all concrete pavements shall be based on the minimum thickness as
determined by the structural coefficient for concrete pavements and the
required structural number. The thickness shall be rounded up to the nearest
0.5 inch. Concrete pavement shall be reinforced with rigid wire mesh (6 inch by
6 inch no. 6 rigid fabric), if required by the village engineer. (2016 Code)
14-4-8: DRIVEWAYS, DRIVEWAY APRONS, LOADING/UNLOADING BERTHS AND STORAGE AREAS:
   A.   Driveways, Parking Lots And Storage Areas:
      1.   Driveways, parking lots and storage areas for residential buildings
must be constructed of a minimum two inches (2") bituminous concrete surface
class I over six inches (6") aggregate base course (crushed) type B or five
inches (5") concrete pavement or paving blocks installed in accordance with
manufacturer's specifications.
      2.   Driveways and parking lots for commercial or industrial buildings
shall be constructed of 1.5 inches of bituminous concrete binder class I and
one inch (1") surface class I over either ten inches (10") of crushed stone or
five inches (5") of reinforced concrete pavement (6 inch by 6 inch no. 6 rigid
fabric) shall be considered an acceptable alternate in lieu of the base and
surface combinations above.
      3.   All parking lots for multi-family residential, commercial, or
industrial buildings which have five (5) or more parking spaces shall have a
six inch by eighteen inch (6" x 18") concrete barrier curb type B or concrete
curb and gutter type B-6.12 constructed around the perimeter of the parking
lot.
   B.   Aprons:
      1.   Aprons for residential buildings must be constructed of a minimum of
five inches (5") nonreinforced concrete pavement or a minimum of a two inch
(2") bituminous concrete class I over six inch (6") aggregate base course type
B, or type B or paving blocks installed in accordance with the manufacturer's
specifications. The owner of the property assumes all liability for damage and/
or replacement of paving blocks within the village right of way. The village or
other utility company which damages or removes paving blocks when working
within the right of way shall not be required to make repairs or replace paving
blocks but may use either permitted concrete or bituminous concrete paving. The
owner of the property shall have the option to repair or replace the paving
blocks at his own expense rather than have the village or utility company make
the repair or replacement.
      2.   Aprons for commercial or industrial buildings shall be constructed
of a minimum eight inches (8") reinforced concrete (6 inch by 6 inch no. 6
rigid fabric) on a two inch (2") base of grade 9 gravel.
   C.   Loading/Unloading Berths: Berths provided in nonresidential areas for
the loading and unloading of materials or merchandise from vehicles must be
constructed to a minimum of eight inches (8") reinforced concrete pavement.
   D.   Pavement Requirements For Storage In Nonresidential Areas: All outside
areas used for the storage of materials, products or vehicles in nonresidential
areas shall be a minimum six inches (6") reinforced concrete pavement (6 inch
by 6 inch no. 6 rigid fabric). (2016 Code)
14-4-9: ALLOWABLE PAVEMENT CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS:
   A.   Table 2 of this section indicates the approved materials which can be
used for roadway construction within the village. Listed with these materials
are the coefficients to be used for approved pavement structural number. The
coefficients, when multiplied by the thickness of the materials, will yield the
structural number.

Code)
14-4-10: SUBGRADE PREPARATION:
   A.   The subgrade of all roads shall be graded and rolled in accordance with
section 212 of the "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction",
current edition, by the department of transportation, hereinafter referred to
as "state standard specifications". Particular attention is directed to the
requirements for the replacement of soft and unstable material as contained in
article 202.03. Embankment shall be placed and compacted in accordance with
section 207 of said specifications.
   B.   At least one standard density test (performed in accordance with AASHTO
T99) shall be taken in each fill section, with the maximum distance between
tests of three hundred feet (300'). One standard proctor test shall be taken
from each different source of borrowed material, if required by the village
engineer. The proctor and density tests must be submitted for review and
approval by the village engineer. Upon approval of these tests, an inspection
of the subgrade will be made by the village, and the subgrade must be approved
prior to placing any type of curb and gutter or base material. (2016 Code)
14-4-11: STREET GRADES:
   A.   The longitudinal gradient shall not be in excess of four percent (4%)
on primary, major or secondary streets, nor in excess of six percent (6%) on
other streets, unless approved by the village engineer, nor will it have a
minimum of less than 0.35 percent.
   B.   Where the gradient of the street warrants installation of vertical type
curb and other special design of improvements due to right of way conditions,
such as double inlets, the village engineer is authorized to require said
design.
   C.   The minimum length of vertical curves shall be one hundred feet (100')
for 1.5 percent difference of grade. For each additional one percent (1%)
difference in grade over 1.5 percent, a fifty foot (50') increment shall be
added to the length of vertical curve. If the grade differential is less than
1.5 percent, a vertical curve is not required. (2016 Code)
14-4-12: SIGHT DISTANCES:
The village engineer shall show at the points of intersection of proposed roads
with existing roads that the minimum stopping sight distance indicated below
for the legal speed limit is provided on existing roads:
 
Legal Speed Limit Minimum Stopping Sight Distance (Feet)
25 - 30           200
31 - 40           275
41 - 50           350
51 - 60           475
61 - 70           600
 
(2016 Code)
14-4-13: CURBS AND GUTTERS:
   A.   Combination curb and gutters shall be concrete with a two inch (2")
minimum compacted granular subbase and shall conform to the village standard
details.
   B.   On major collector, local collector or industrial/business service
streets, all curb and gutter at the parkway side of the road shall be B-6.12
barrier type except at driveways and ramps and except where the village
engineer approves a modification to conform with an existing curb and gutter.
On arterial streets, all curbs and gutters shall be B-6.18.
   C.   The concrete used for the curb and gutter shall be of class X and
conform with the Illinois department of transportation publication, "Standard
Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", section 500, entitled
"Concrete For Structures And Incidental Construction", and section 700,
"Materials".
   D.   On minor multi-family residential, minor single-family residential and
cul-de-sac streets, all curb and gutters at the parkway side of the road shall
be roll type except at driveways and ramps and except where the village
engineer approves a modification to conform with an existing curb and gutter.
At crosswalks, sidewalk ramps will be constructed in accordance with the
village standard details, "Sidewalk Ramps For The Handicapped".
   E.   At concrete medians, the curb and gutter shall be reversed slope B-
6.12.
   F.   All minor private streets shall have a six inch by eighteen inch (6" x
18") concrete barrier curb type B constructed on both sides. (2016 Code)
14-4-14: SIDEWALKS AND CARRIAGE WALKS:
   A.   All public walks designed for pedestrian travel shall be improved with
not less than five inches (5") of class X portland cement concrete pavement,
six inches (6") at driveways and extending three feet (3') each side of the
driveway. The width shall be at least four feet (4') in areas zoned residential
and five feet (5') in other areas. Sidewalks shall be poured on a two inch (2")
compacted granular subbase. Expansion joints are to be placed fifty feet (50')
on center.
   B.   Construction joints are to be troweled in four feet (4') on center for
four foot (4') sidewalks and five feet (5') on center for five foot (5')
sidewalks. The sidewalk shall have a cross slope of one-fourth inch (1/4") per
foot down toward the street and be elevated one inch (1") above the finished
grade of the parkway. The parkway shall be pitched down from the sidewalk
toward the street with a minimum pitch of one-fourth inch (1/4") per foot to a
maximum of three-fourths inch (3/4") per foot. Sidewalks shall meet the
requirements of the following applicable sections of "Standard Specifications
For Road And Bridge Construction" of the Illinois department of transportation:
section 600, "Incidental Construction", and diagram D; and section 700,
"Materials".
   C.   Whenever a side of a street in a block of a development is more than
seventy five percent (75%) completed by the building of structures on such
block, sidewalks must be installed by the developer on all vacant premises to
provide a continuity of sidewalks. (2016 Code)
   D.   Concrete carriage walks shall be improved with not less than five
inches (5") of class X portland cement concrete pavement, six inches (6") at
driveways and extending three feet (3') each side of the driveway. The width
shall be at least four feet (4') in areas zoned residential and five feet (5')
in other areas. Sidewalks shall be poured on a minimum two inch (2") compacted
granular subbase. Any addition of field or flagstone to further beautify the
walkway requires that all stone be mortared to the concrete.
   E.   Carriage walks constructed with paving bricks and sand shall be
improved with not less than two to three inches (2-3") of compacted sand over a
six inch (6") base of three quarter inch (3/4") gravel or stone. (amd. Ord. 18-
51, 10-2-2018)
14-4-15: MAINTENANCE AND RESPONSIBILITY:
   A.   The maintenance and responsibility for all CPD or private roadways
shall be accountable to the developer/owner or homeowners' association.
   B.   All streets, curbs, gutters and sidewalks shall be under warranty for
all defects and failures in base course, as well as surface course, for a
period of two (2) years. A guarantee for those improvements, which will be
dedicated to the village, shall be for a period of two (2) years after the date
of acceptance. Those improvements in private areas shall be guaranteed for one
year from the date of release of the subdivision improvement security. (2016
Code)
CHAPTER 5
STREET NAME SIGNS; TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES AND MARKINGS; STREET LIGHTING
SECTION:
14-5-1: Street Name Signs
14-5-2: Traffic Control Devices And Markings
14-5-3: Street Lighting
14-5-1: STREET NAME SIGNS:
   A.   Street name signs should be erected at all street intersections
regardless of other route marking that may be present. Lettering on street name
signs should be at least four inches (4") high. Supplementary lettering to
indicate the type of street (e.g., Street, Avenue, Road, etc.) or section of
the village (e.g., N.W.) may be in smaller lettering, at least two inches (2")
high. Conventional abbreviations are acceptable except for the street name
itself.
   B.   The street name sign should be reflectorized or illuminated. The legend
and background shall be of contrasting colors and should have a white message
and border on a green background.
   C.   In business districts and on principal arterials, street name signs
should be placed at least on diagonally opposite corners so that they will be
on the far right hand side of the intersection for traffic on the major street.
Signs naming both streets should be erected at each location. They should be
mounted with their faces parallel to the streets they name, and they shall be
installed at a height of seven feet (7') and not less than two feet (2') nor
more than six feet (6') from the edge of the pavement. Where possible, they
shall be installed adjacent to street lighting. Street name signs shall be
permanently anchored in concrete. (2016 Code)
14-5-2: TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES AND MARKINGS:
   A.   All traffic control devices and signals, except traffic control light
signals, shall be installed on all streets in accordance with the standards in
the "Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices", Illinois department of
transportation, Springfield, Illinois, and approved by the village engineer.
   B.   All streets shall be striped with lane markings in accordance with the
standards in the "Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices", Illinois
department of transportation, Springfield, Illinois, and approved by the
village engineer. (2016 Code)
14-5-3: STREET LIGHTING:
   A.   Description:
      1.   Streetlights and appurtenances shall be installed according to:
         a.   The "American Standard Practice For Roadway Lighting", current
edition.
         b.   The national electrical code, current edition.
      2.   The streetlight system consists of the poles, mast arms, luminaries,
wire and all other materials and work necessary to complete the street lighting
installation.
      3.   The street lighting system is to be constructed within the right of
way or easements for improvements to be accepted by the village and in
locations shown on the approved plan for comprehensive planned developments.
      4.   All streetlights and appurtenances and installation and operation
shall conform to the current requirements of Commonwealth Edison Company. All
streetlight engineering and plans must be approved by Commonwealth Edison
Company prior to final approval by the village engineer. Any requirements of
Commonwealth Edison Company shall override any requirements of this section
where appropriate.
   B.   Spacing: Streetlights are to be located at all intersections, as well
as along street blocks as indicated in the following table:
            Mounting             Spacing        Luminaries Type
Street Type Height   Pole Height Measured Along And Wattage     Initial Lumens
                                 Centerline
              Mounting             Spacing        Luminaries
Street Type   Height   Pole Height Measured Along Type And   Initial Lumens
                                   Centerline     Wattage
Arterial      35'0"    33'         175'           250        30,000
Collector:
 Major        30'10"   28'         175'           1501       16,000
 Local        30'10"   28'         200'           1501       16,000
Multi-family  25'10"   23'         250'           1501       16,000
Single-family 25'10"   23'         250'           1501       16,000
Private       25'10"   23'         250'           1501       16,000
Commercial    30'10"   28'         200'           1501       16,000
 
Note:
1.   HPS = High pressure sodium.
   C.   Location: Streetlights shall be located on one side of the street
unless, in the judgment of the village engineer, it is impractical to do so.
All streetlight poles shall be set three feet (3') back from curb line. At
intersections with only one standard, the bracket of each shall be
perpendicular to a street as determined by the village engineer.
   D.   Design Requirement And Approval: The complete lighting system shall be
designed by a registered professional engineer of the state of Illinois and
shall be submitted to the village engineer for approval. In special cases, the
village engineer may designate larger lamps, higher poles, two (2) masted
poles, or vary the spacing as he deems necessary to meet special conditions. In
no event shall streetlights in residential districts be spaced less than one
hundred fifty feet (150') apart.
   E.   Materials And Workmanship: All materials comprising the lighting
systems shall be the product of a firm or firms regularly engaged in the
manufacture of such materials and shall be covered by the manufacturer's or
installing contractor's warranty or guarantee. The materials shall be new, of
current manufacture and of standard design and free from all defects.
Workmanship shall be of the highest grade in accordance with standard practice.
All work shall be done in accordance with those standards requiring the highest
grade.
   F.   Material And Equipment Specifications:
      1.   Conduit: All driveways and street and sidewalk crossings shall have
a two inch (2") galvanized rigid steel conduit or PVC conduit used as a raceway
for underground cable with two inch (2") insulating fiber bushings.
      2.   Wire/Cable: All wire installed under this section shall be "USE"
copper with six hundred (600) volt insulation. Cable shall be of a type
approved by the village engineer for direct burial such as type "USE". Uniduct
cable shall be required for commercial and manufacturing areas. One conductor
shall be white to determine neutral. Wire installed in the trench shall be six
hundred (600) volt no. 6 copper "USE". All wire will be subject to an
insulation test to ground after installation. Any section of wiring failing to
pass the minimum insulation test or showing an obvious short circuit shall be
replaced. All wire is to be buried at least twenty four inches (24") below
finished grade.
      3.   Fuses: Each pole shall be fused with a ten (10) amp fusetron and
"USE" bussman, HEB type fuse holder with rubber boots. All hot conductors must
be fused.
      4.   Lamps: All lamps shall be rated 120/240 volts. All lamps shall be
high pressure sodium. All lamps shall be a minimum of one hundred fifty (150)
watts, except at intersections with state or county highways or at
intersections in business parks or industrial parks where they shall be two
hundred fifty (250) watts.
      5.   Luminaries: The luminaries for lighting improvements to be accepted
by the village for maintenance shall be a standard line of luminaries equipped
with photoelectrical control units and one piece reflector housing of anodized
aluminum. The luminary shall be equipped also with a hinged refractor holder
that shall be securely held in place by a suitable latch. The luminary head
shall embody a two inch (2") slip filter and shall be equipped with adjustable
latch lugs to permit the proper orientation of the light pattern on the street;
and EEL-NEMA standard, three (3) terminal polarized lock in type, photoelectric
control receptacle. In addition, sodium units shall be equipped with built in
ballasts. The luminaries shall provide lighting distribution equivalent to IES
type II except at intersections where IES type V or IES type II with four-way
distribution shall be provided. The luminaries for lighting improvements to be
installed in planned unit or other developments shall be approved by the
village engineer for construction.
      6.   Ballasts: Ballasts shall be of high quality grain oriented strip
steel, high power factor, constant wattage and shall have a primary voltage
rating of 120/240 volts. They shall be suitable for outdoor service and capable
of starting the lamp at minus twenty degrees Fahrenheit (-20°F).
      7.   Controls: Individual photoelectric control units shall be provided
with each luminaire. Said control units shall fit all EEL-NEMA standard
receptacles and shall be rated two hundred forty (240) volts, one thousand two
hundred (1,200) watts and constructed so as to prevent false turnoff by passing
automobile headlights or lightning flashes.
      8.   Mast Arm Brackets:
         a.   Mast arm brackets for lighting improvements to be accepted by the
village for maintenance shall have a minimum spread of approximately eight feet
(8') and shall be the upsweep type with wire inlet and necessary bracing. The
brackets shall be manufactured from aluminum alloy and shall be capable of
accommodating the slip filter arrangement of the luminaire.
         b.   The mast arm clamps and fittings shall be heat treated aluminum
castings, and shall be free of all imperfections to ensure an even grip on the
standard and to provide easy mounting of the mast arms.
         c.   Where drawn seamless tubing is used for the mast arm, it shall
conform to ASTM specifications 10-58T and GS10A-T6.
         d.   Aluminum for the mast arm clamps and fittings shall conform to
ASTM specifications S5A-F and B26-50T.
         e.   Mast arm brackets for lighting improvements to be installed in
planned unit and other private developments shall be of the type and length
approved by the village engineer.
      9.   Light Standards:
         a.   Light standards to be accepted by the village for maintenance may
be manufactured of concrete, centrifugally cast, prestressed, and steel
reinforced and of breakaway design. The standards shall have smooth ground and
polished surfaces. The cross section of the standard shall contain a raceway
extending throughout the length of the standard. The raceway shall have a
minimum opening of one and one-half inches (11/2") and shall not exceed two
inches (2") at the top of the standard. A handhold shall be provided and shall
be covered with a heat treated cast aluminum door, fastened to nonferrous
inserts in the standard with stainless steel bolts.
         b.   All standards shall be provided with an aluminum mast cap held to
the top of the standard by stainless steel screws and nonferrous inserts.
         c.   Aluminum for the handhold doors and mast caps shall conform to
ASTM specifications S5A-F or SG70A-T6 and B26-50T.
         d.   Roadway lighting standards shall be not less than eight inches
(8") in diameter with a butt base below final grade level. It shall be equipped
with mast arm brackets securely attached to the standard.
      10.   Splices: All underground cable shall be continuous. Necessary
splices shall be made aboveground and shall have the location recorded on the
plans. Splices shall be made by using 3M Scotch cast kits or approved equal.
Connection to Commonwealth Edison feeder lines must include a fuse box for
shutoff to Commonwealth Edison power supply. Said fuse box shall be of the type
approved by the village engineer.
      11.   Size Of Trench And Backfilling Procedures:
         a.   This work shall consist of constructing a trench for the
accommodation of cables or conduit and backfilling it at the location shown on
the plans or as directed by the village engineer. The trench shall be excavated
at least twenty four inches (24") below finished grade.
         b.   Backfilling material shall be deposited in the trench in layers,
not to exceed six inches (6") in depth, and shall be thoroughly compacted by
suitable tamping before the next layer is deposited in the trench. The trench
shall be located two feet (2') back of the curb or as directed by the village
engineer.
      12.   Tests: After the installation is complete and at a time convenient
to the village, all equipment shall be demonstrated to operate in accordance
with the drawings and specifications.
      13.   Warranty: The contractor and his surety shall guarantee and warrant
that the equipment, material and workmanship, regardless of the manufacturer,
will, for a period of two (2) years from the date of final acceptance by the
village or private owner, satisfactorily serve the purpose for which they were
installed. Any defective material or workmanship shall be repaired or replaced
by said contractor to the satisfaction of the village without cost to the
village.
      14.   Existing Utilities: The location of existing underground utilities,
such as water mains, sewers, gas lines, etc., can be determined from plans
available at the project. However, the village does not assume responsibility
in the event that the actual location may be different from the location as
shown on the available plans.
      15.   As Built Drawings: Upon completion of the installation and testing
by the village, the contractor must present a marked set of as built,
reproducible drawings to the village. (2016 Code)
CHAPTER 6
WATER DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM
SECTION:
14-6-1: General Requirements
14-6-2: Design
14-6-3: Allowable Materials
14-6-4: Construction Requirements
14-6-5: Water Main Pressure Testing
14-6-6: Water Main Leakage Testing
14-6-7: Preliminary Flushing
14-6-8: Sterilization
14-6-9: Final Flushing And Testing
14-6-10: Compliance With State Regulations
14-6-1: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   No residential, commercial or industrial subdivision or development
within the corporate limits of the village shall be approved unless it is
served by the village water supply system.
   B.   All water supply systems which are installed in the public ways or in
easements serving a central system shall be dedicated to the village. In all
cases where a central water supply system is installed pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter, said water supply system shall be dedicated to the
village. (2016 Code)
14-6-2: DESIGN:
   A.   General Specifications:
      1.   Water distribution mains shall be of adequate size and shall serve
the entire development.
      2.   The mains shall be designed according to the "Standard
Specifications For Water And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois" or according
to the "Recommended Standards For Water Works". The more stringent requirements
of either shall apply.
      3.   The mains shall, in general, be installed in the street right of
way. In no case shall mains be installed within seven feet (7') of a building
in a residential district and within ten feet (10') of a building in any other
zoning district.
      4.   The minimum size shall be six inches (6") internal diameter in
residential areas. In other developments, the minimum size shall be eight
inches (8").
      5.   All water mains shall be installed with a minimum depth of cover of
5.5 feet, measured from the established grade shown on the plans to the top of
the pipe.
      6.   Mains shall be extended to the far property line of the development
along public rights of way and at any other location indicated by the village
engineer.
   B.   Fire Protection System: The design engineer shall show in a separate
report that at several locations and at any other location that may be selected
by the village engineer, the proposed water main system, together with that
proposed in the master plan for the village, will supply the fire flow required
in excess of domestic consumption demands, using a "C" factor of 100 for cast
iron or ductile iron and 120 for asbestos cement or thick walled PVC water
mains, ignoring fittings, and with a minimum residual pressure of twenty (20)
psi.
      1.   Residence:
         a.   Dwellings, detached and semidetached: One thousand (1,000) to one
thousand five hundred (1,500) gpm.
         b.   Dwellings, attached (townhouses), each unit separated by an
approved firewall: One thousand (1,000) to two thousand (2,000) gpm.
         c.   Dwellings attached other than above and dwellings, multiple-
family: Three thousand (3,000) to four thousand (4,000) gpm.
      2.   Business:
         a.   Business and office uses: Two thousand five hundred (2,500) to
three thousand (3,000) gpm.
         b.   Commercial and mercantile buildings, including warehouses: Three
thousand (3,000) to six thousand (6,000) gpm.
      3.   Manufacturing: Three thousand (3,000) to six thousand (6,000) gpm.
      4.   Institutional: Three thousand (3,000) gpm.
   C.   Gridiron Or Looping Of Mains:
      1.   Each six inch (6") water main shall be looped (except cul-de-sacs or
stubbed streets unless deemed necessary by the village engineer) so that runs
between connections to six inch (6") or larger size mains shall not be greater
than one block not to exceed one thousand eight hundred feet (1,800').
      2.   Each eight inch (8") water main shall be looped so that runs between
connections to eight inch (8") or larger mains shall not be greater than one
thousand four hundred feet (1,400') in a commercial area or one thousand eight
hundred feet (1,800') in a residential area.
      3.   Each ten inch (10") water main shall be looped so that runs between
connection to ten inch (10") or larger size mains shall not be greater than two
thousand two hundred feet (2,200').
      4.   Each twelve inch (12") and larger water main shall be looped so that
runs between connections to twelve inch (12") or larger mains shall not be
greater than three thousand feet (3,000').
      5.   If the design engineer's report shows spacing greater than provided
in subsections C1 through C4 of this section for the required residual
pressure, then that spacing shall supersede the said requirements.
   D.   Fire Hydrants:
      1.   Whenever a water main is to be installed for the purpose of
providing fire hydrants, the local fire protection district having jurisdiction
and the village engineer must approve the hydrant spacing plan prior to
commencement of work.
      2.   Fire hydrants shall not be located closer than thirty feet (30') to
any building.
      3.   Fire hydrants shall be located at all corners and intersections of
public and private streets, and the minimum spacing allowed shall be such that
three hundred foot (300') radius circles centered on each hydrant cover all
construction on the site that will burn.
      4.   If the location or configuration of the building requires it,
private fire hydrants shall be installed. Private elevated or ground storage
reservoirs may also be installed as required.
      5.   Dead end six inch (6") main extensions serving hydrants in cul-de-
sacs shall not be more than four hundred feet (400') long.
      6.   Where water transmission lines or off site water lines are installed
in an existing right of way (or in easements to an existing right of way),
hydrants must be installed at three hundred foot (300') intervals. In other
locations, six hundred foot (600') intervals are required with tees for future
hydrants being provided within three hundred feet (300') of the fire hydrants.
      7.   Fire hydrants must be located such that access routes from all
points of any building to adjacent fire hydrants do not exceed three hundred
feet (300').
   E.   Valves:
      1.   Valves shall be located on water mains so as to effectively isolate
the sections from the system with minimum disruption.
      2.   Valves shall be installed so that not over eight hundred feet (800')
of main will be shut off at any given time unless the village engineer permits
spacing at greater intervals.
      3.   If a tee is installed, two (2) valves may be utilized.
      4.   The design engineer shall, by diagrams and/or written report, set
forth his basis for location of water main valves.
      5.   No more than thirty (30) single-family dwelling units shall be
without water with the shutting off of any three (3) valve locations.
      6.   Valve vaults are required on all valves 2.5 inches or larger. Forty
eight inch (48") vaults are required on valves ten inches (10") or smaller.
Sixty inch (60") vaults or larger are required on all other size valves.
      7.   A maximum of three (3) valves shall be used to isolate any given
section of a water main.
   F.   Services: The plans, except for residential developments with
individual service for each unit, shall show the calculated static water
pressure at the lowest and highest ground elevations on the site. Calculations
shall be presented showing that the proposed water services are of a large
enough size to supply an adequate flow of water at the outlet of the meter,
assuming the service is "fairly rough pipe" as specified in the Illinois state
plumbing code, current edition.
   G.   Thrust Blocks: Thrust blocks are required at all valves, hydrants, tees
and bends. Engineering drawings shall indicate the location of each concrete
thrust block to be installed. Where undisturbed earth is not available or not
likely to be available to back up pressure type concrete thrust blocks, the
engineer shall specify tie rods with or without anchor type concrete thrust
blocks and submit design data for such specifications. (2016 Code)
14-6-3: ALLOWABLE MATERIALS:
   A.   General Requirements:
      1.   All water main pipe, be it new installation, replacement and/or
repair, shall be ductile cast iron cement lined bituminous coated pipe class
52. All fittings shall be cast iron. The village engineer may allow other
materials, as listed in this section, only if soil conditions warrant alternate
pipe materials.
      2.   Water main pipe and fittings must conform to the applicable
paragraphs of section 40 of the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer
Main Construction In Illinois (SSWS)", current edition.
   B.   Water Main:
      1.   Ductile Iron:
         a.   Ductile iron pipe shall conform to AWWA specification C151-65.
Normal working pressure shall not exceed one hundred fifty (150) psi. Pipe
shall be furnished in nominal eighteen foot (18') laying lengths.
         b.   Ductile iron pipe shall be bituminous coated cement mortar lined
as specified in section 51-8.2 of AWWA specification C151-65. The ductile iron
pipe shall be coated on the outside as specified in section 15.8.1 with the
exceptions that the thickness of the coating shall be an average of two (2) to
four (4) mils and a minimum of two (2) mils.
         c.   Each pipe shall have the weight and class designation
conspicuously painted on it. In addition, the manufacturer's mark and year in
which the pipe was made shall be distinctly stamped or cast on the face of the
bell.
         d.   All fittings shall be connected to sections of water main pipe by
means of mechanical joints or approved push type joints.
      2.   Thick Walled PVC (Asbestos Cement Pipe):
         a.   Asbestos cement pipe shall conform to the requirements of AWWA
specification C400 or ASTM C296. Normal working pressure shall exceed one
hundred fifty (150) psi. Pipe shall be furnished in nominal thirteen foot (13')
laying lengths; except, that six inch (6") diameter pipe may be furnished in
nominal ten foot (10') lengths.
         b.   All fittings shall be connected to sections of water main pipe by
means of mechanical joints or approved push type joints designed for use on
asbestos cement water pipe.
      3.   Thick Walled PVC:
         a.   PVC pressure pipe (pipe class 150-SDR 18), available in sizes up
to twelve inches (12"), shall conform to the requirements of AWWA C900-75 and
shall be manufactured to cast iron dimensions. Normal working pressure shall
not exceed one hundred fifty (150) psi. The pipe shall not exceed twenty feet
(20') in laying length. Random lengths shall not be less than ten feet (10')
long.
         b.   All fittings shall be connected to water main pipe by means of
mechanical joints or approved push type joints.
   C.   Pipe Joints:
      1.   Ductile Iron Water Main:
         a.   Slip Joints:
            (1)   Sections of the water main pipe shall be connected by means
of slip joints, consisting of bells cast integrally with pipe which have
interior angular recesses conforming with the shape and dimensions of a rubber
sealing gasket, the interior dimension of which is such that it will admit the
insertion of the spigot end of the joining pipe in such manner as to compress
the gasket tightly between the bell of the pipe and the inserted spigot, thus
securing the gasket and sealing the joint. Such a slip joint shall be any one
of the following make or type or its equivalent:
               (A)   Super belltite: As supplied by James B. Clow And Son.
               (B)   Fastite: As supplied by the American Cast Iron Pipe
Company.
               (C)   Tyton: As supplied by the U.S. Pipe And Foundry Company.
            (2)   The lubricant used in conjunction with the slip joints shall
be that recommended by the supplier specified or commercially processed animal
fat or vegetable shortening.
         b.   Mechanical Joint Pipe: Mechanical joint pipe shall meet the
requirements of ASA specification A-U 11. Bolting materials shall meet the
requirements of the manufacturer.
      2.   Thick Walled PVC Joints: PVC pressure pipe joints (pipe class 150-
SDR 18), available in sizes up to twelve inches (12"), shall conform to the
requirements of AWWA specification C900-75 with an integral wall thickened bell
and an elastomeric gasket such that the minimum wall thickness of the bell at
any point shall conform to SDR 18.
   D.   Concrete Thrust Blocks: All thrust blocks shall be precast or poured
with class X concrete in accordance with the provisions of "Standard
Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction (STSRB)", section 5.04; except,
that the contractor shall bear the cost of the mix design. When poured, care
shall be taken so that the cement does not interfere with access to joints or
with hydrant drainage.
   E.   Pipe Sleeves For Augering Or Tunneling: Pipe sleeves for augering or
tunneling shall be fabricated of 0.312 inch thick rolled sheet steel, of the
diameter specified, with a continuous circular one-half inch (1/2") bead weld
and shall meet the requirements of ASTM A-120.
   F.   Castings: Castings for water valve vaults shall be Neenah R-1031 or
approved equal with type B lid stamped "Village of Berkeley – Water".
   G.   Curb Stops: Curb stops shall be the O-ring sealing type, Mueller
Oriseal Mark II model H-15154 with copper service thread connections at both
ends. The stop shall be quarter turn with a solid tee head which is an integral
part of the plug. The stop shall be of nominal size equal to the size of the
service line and be Minneapolis pattern type (11/2 inch threads for 3/4 inch
stop) with check and without drain.
   H.   Curb Box: Curb boxes shall be Minneapolis pattern base, telescoping
extension type, equipped with stationary rod, Mueller model H-10300 for three-
fourths inch (3/4") stops, model H-10302 for one inch (1") stops and model H-
10304 for one and one-half inch (11/2") or two inch (2") stops.
   I.   House Service: All house service water lines shall be a minimum of
three-fourths inch (3/4") copper type K complete with corporation cock, stop
cock and cast iron buffalo box. Service lines shall conform to ASTM B-88-58 or
equal and the village plumbing ordinance.
   J.   Corporation Stops: Corporation stops shall be Mueller H-15000, with
nominal size being equivalent to the copper service line.
   K.   System Valves:
      1.   Four inch (4") to twelve inch (12") gate valves shall be resilient
wedge type conforming to AWWA C-509-80, manufactured by Mueller. Valves larger
than twelve inches (12") in size shall be resilient seated butterfly valves
conforming to C-504 and shall be equipped with manual operators designed for
submersible service.
      2.   Four inch (4") to ten inch (10") system valves shall be installed in
a forty eight inch (48") precast concrete valve vault, and system valves
greater than ten inches (10") in size shall be installed in a sixty inch (60")
precast concrete valve vault.
      3.   All valve vaults shall be in accordance with the requirements set
forth in chapter 9, "Appurtenances To Water, Sanitary Sewer And Storm Systems",
of this title. Steps are not required for water vaults.
      4.   Fire hydrant auxiliary valves shall be furnished with a two (2)
piece, five inch (5") buffalo style cast iron screw type adjustable valve box,
Mueller H-10360 with the word "WATER" cast on the lid.
      5.   All valves shall have mechanical joint or push type ends, inside
screw, and shall be equipped with a two inch (2") operated nut. All valves
shall open by turning counterclockwise.
   L.   Fire Hydrants:
      1.   The fire hydrant shall have a valve opening of five inches (5") and
shall be equipped with two (2) 2-inch hose connections and one 4-inch male
pumper connection. The outside diameter of the male thread on the two inch (2")
hose connection shall be "National Standard" threads. Hose caps shall be
fastened to the barrel with steel chain of at least one-eighth inch (1/8")
thickness.
      2.   Each hydrant shall be provided with a drain that will leave no water
standing in the barrel of the hydrant when the hydrant is closed. This drain
shall close tightly before the hydrant begins to open.
      3.   All fire hydrants shall be equipped with a six inch (6") Mueller
resilient wedge gate valve flanged directly to the hydrant.
      4.   Fire hydrants shall be the break flange type, open against pressure,
and shall be one of the following:
         a.   Mueller Centurion as manufactured by Mueller Company, Decatur,
Illinois.
         b.   Clow Medallion as manufactured by Clow Valve Co., Oskaloosa,
Iowa.
      5.   The bowl of each hydrant shall be well braced against unexcavated
earth at the end of the trench with stone slabs or concrete backing, or it
shall be tied to the pipe with suitable rods or clamps.
      6.   All hydrants shall be thoroughly cleaned of dirt and foreign matter
before setting.
      7.   Fire hydrants shall be installed not further than seven feet (7')
nor less than three feet (3') from the edge of a lane of traffic that is to be
kept open to all weather and is adequate in width, clearance and strength for
firefighting equipment. Parking lots shall be designed to provide not less than
fifteen feet (15') of clearance on each side of the hydrant on which a steamer
or hose connection is located.
      8.   The height of the nut on a four inch (4") steamer connection shall
be no less than twenty four inches (24") nor more than thirty six inches (36")
above the finished grade at the hydrant.
      9.   All fire hydrants shall conform to AWWA C-502.
   M.   Air Release Valves:
      1.   Air release valves shall be placed on the water main at high points
as deemed necessary by the village engineer to serve as air vents preventing
air locking of the water main.
      2.   These air release valves shall be of the APCO 200 A type or an
approved equal. All air release valves (sic). (2016 Code)
14-6-4: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Excavation:
      1.   The trench shall be excavated so that the water main will be at a
minimum depth of 5.5 feet. The trench for the pipe shall be excavated at least
twelve inches (12") wider than the external diameter of the pipe and not more
than eighteen inches (18") wider than the diameter of the pipe at the top of
the pipe.
      2.   Bell holes of sufficient depth shall be provided across the bottom
of the trench to accommodate the bell of the pipe to provide sufficient room
for joint making and to ensure uniform bearing for the pipe.
      3.   Where a firm foundation is not found to exist for the bottom of the
trench at the required depth due to soft, spongy or other unsuitable soil, such
unsuitable soil shall be removed for the full width of the trench or tunnel and
replaced with well compacted unwashed gravel or an equal substitute therefor,
or crushed stone if such compacted material proved unsatisfactory. Where rock
in either ledge or bounder formation is encountered, it shall be removed below
grade and replaced with a well compacted cushion of unwashed gravel having a
thickness under the pipe of not less than eight inches (8").
   B.   Sheeting And Bracing:
      1.   Sheeting and bracing shall be placed in the ditch, as may be
necessary, for the safety of the work and public, for the protection of the
workers, adjacent properties, or structures and for the proper installation of
the work.
      2.   Sheeting and/or bracing shall be progressively removed as the
backfill is placed in such a manner as to prevent the caving in of the sides of
the trench or excavation and to prevent damage to the work.
      3.   Sheeting which is placed for the protection of the public, adjacent
properties or structures shall not be removed until the backfill has been
placed and thoroughly compacted. While sheeting is being withdrawn, all
vacancies shall be carefully filled with sand free from silt, rammed into
place, puddled or otherwise firmly compacted.
   C.   Laying Water Main:
      1.   The contractor shall keep the trench free from water while the water
main is being placed and until the pipe joint has been sealed to the
satisfaction of the village engineer or his representative.
      2.   Adequate provision shall be made for safety, storing and protecting
all water pipe prior to actual installation in the trench. Care shall be taken
to prevent damage to the pipe castings, both inside and out. Provisions shall
be made to keep the inside of the pipe clean throughout its storage period and
to keep mud and/or other debris from being deposited therein. All pipe shall be
thoroughly cleaned on the inside before the laying of the pipe. Proper
equipment shall be used for the safe handling, conveying and laying of the
pipe. All pipe shall be carefully lowered into the trench, piece by piece, by
means of a derrick, ropes, or other suitable tools or equipment, in such manner
as to prevent damage to water main materials and protective coatings and
linings. Under no circumstances shall water main materials be dropped or dumped
into the trench.
      3.   In making joints, all portions of the jointing materials and the
socket and spigot ends of the joining pipe shall be wiped clean of all foreign
materials. The actual assembly of the jointing shall be in accordance with the
manufacturer's installation instructions and/or directed in writing by the
village engineer. During construction, until jointing operations are complete,
the open ends of all pipes shall be at all times protected and sealed with
temporary watertight plugs.
   D.   Pipe Cutting:
      1.   The cutting of pipe for inserting valves, fittings or closure pieces
shall be done in a neat and workmanlike manner without damage to the cement
lining and so as to leave a smooth end at right angles to the axis of the pipe.
When machine cutting is not available for cutting pipe twenty inches (20") in
diameter or larger, the electric arc cutting method will be permitted, using a
carbon or steel rod. Only qualified and experienced workers shall be used on
this work.
      2.   The flame cutting of pipe by means of an oxyacetylene torch shall
not be allowed.
   E.   Water Service Connections:
      1.   House Services:
         a.   Water service connections for house services shall be located as
directed by the village or its representative and shall be laid at a depth of
not less than 5.5 feet and conform to requirements of the village plumbing
code, title 10, chapter 5 of this code.
         b.   Each service connection shall be connected to the water main by a
brass corporation cock, said pipe to extend horizontally at right angles with
the water main to the front line of the lot or parcel which it is to serve
unless otherwise shown on the plans or specified herein. Said service pipe
shall be provided with a brass stopcock at the location in the lines as
directed by the village over which a cast iron service box or valve vault shall
be set. Flared type joints shall be used between the service pipe and fittings.
      2.   Commercial Services: Water service connections for commercial
services shall be installed according to the requirements of the village
plumbing code, title 10, chapter 5 of this code.
   F.   Backfilling:
      1.   The contractor shall not backfill above the top of the pipe until
grade, alignment and the pipe joints have been made available for checking by
the village engineer or his representative.
      2.   Unless otherwise directed, all trenches and excavations shall be
backfilled as soon as possible, and the work shall be prosecuted expeditiously
after it has been commenced. As soon as it is laid, all pipe shall have the
space between the pipe and the bottom and sides of the trench packed full of
sand, grade 9 gravel, or clean, dry materials by hand and thoroughly tamped
with a shovel, hoe or light tamper, as fast as placed up to the level of the
middle of the pipe. The filling shall be carried up evenly on both sides. Care
shall be taken that no rock, frozen material, or other hard substances are
placed in contact with the pipe. The pipe shall then be covered at least
eighteen inches (18") with clean, dry material.
      3.   The remainder of the trench shall be backfilled by using the
material originally excavated from the ditch (except for conditions hereinafter
defined) to a height slightly above the original elevation of the ground.
      4.   Pipe constructed in open cut across any existing or proposed
pavement, existing driveways and sidewalks shall be backfilled to subgrade with
grade 9 gravel thoroughly flushed and jetted or tamped in nine inch (9") lifts
into place. (2016 Code)
14-6-5: WATER MAIN PRESSURE TESTING:
   A.   Pressure Test Required:
      1.   Each section of the water main and appurtenances shall be tested by
the contractor and village jointly. Any defects or leaks shall be corrected by
the contractor.
      2.   It is the responsibility of the contractor to reexcavate the pipe at
his expense if the system fails to meet the requirements of the test.
      3.   A hydrostatic pressure of one hundred fifty (150) pounds per square
inch shall be applied for the testing of the water main, valves, fittings and
fire hydrants. The duration of the test shall be for a period of not less than
two (2) hours. The section of water main shall pass if the pressure loss in the
pipe is not greater than 7.5 pounds per square inch during the test.
   B.   Procedure For Test: Each section of pipe to be tested, as determined by
the village engineer, shall be slowly filled with water, and the specified test
pressure shall be applied by means of a pump connected to the pipe in a
satisfactory manner. The pump pipe connection and all necessary apparatus
including gauges and meters shall be furnished by the contractor. Before
applying the specified test pressure, all air shall be expelled from the pipe.
To accomplish this, taps shall be made as necessary at points of highest
elevation and afterwards tightly plugged. Any cracked or defective pipes,
fittings, valves or hydrants discovered in consequence of this pressure test
shall be removed and replaced by the contractor with sound material, and the
test shall be repeated until satisfactory to the village engineer. Provisions
of AWWA C-600 and C-603, where applicable, shall apply. (2016 Code)
14-6-6: WATER MAIN LEAKAGE TESTING:
   A.   After completion of the pressure test, the village engineer may require
a leakage test to be conducted to determine the quantity of water lost by
leakage under the specified test pressure. "Test pressure" is defined as the
maximum operating pressure of the section under test and is based on the
elevation of the lowest point in the line or section under test corrected to
the elevation of the test gauge. Applicable provisions of AWWA C-600 and C-603
shall apply. Duration of each leakage test shall be a minimum of one hour in
addition to the pressure test period.
   B.   Allowable leakage in gallons per hour for a cast iron water main shall
not be greater than that determined by the formula:
 
L = ND P
    3,700
 
for mechanical joints; or
 
L = ND P
    1,850
 
for caulked bell and spigot joints.
Note:
L = Allowable leakage in gallons per hour.
N = Number of joints in the length of the pipeline tested.
D = Nominal diameter of the pipe in inches.
P = Average test pressure during leakage test in pounds per square inch gauge.
Tables of allowable leakage and basis of allowable leakage can be found in
table 4 of this section for cast iron water main.
Allowable leakage for asbestos cement water pipe shall conform to provisions of
AWWA C-603. Allowable leakage per one hundred (100) couplings based on one
hundred fifty (150) psi pressure represents a leakage of thirty (30) gpd per
mile of pipe per inch of diameter for pipe in thirteen foot (13') lengths. A
table showing the allowable leakage is provided in table 4 of this section.
   C.   "Leakage" is defined as the quantity of water to be supplied in the
newly laid pipe or any valved section under test which is necessary to maintain
the specified leakage test pressure after the pipe has been filled with water
and the air expelled.
   D.   Flanged pipe shall be "bottle tight".
   E.   In no case shall the leakage exceed the greater of either three
thousand (3,000) gallons per day per mile of water main or three percent (3%)
of total supplied water.

14-6-7: PRELIMINARY FLUSHING:
Prior to chlorination, the main shall be flushed as thoroughly as possible with
the water pressure and outlets available. Flushing shall be done after the
pressure test is made. It must be understood that such flushing removes only
the lighter solids and cannot be relied upon to remove heavy material allowed
to get into the main during laying. If no hydrant is installed at the end of
the main, a tap should be provided large enough to effect a velocity in the
main of at least 2.5 feet per second. (2016 Code)
14-6-8: STERILIZATION:
   A.   The preferred point of application of the chlorinating agent shall be
at the beginning of the pipeline extension or any valved section of it and
through a corporation stop in the top of the newly laid pipe. The water
injector for delivering the chlorine bearing water into the pipe should be
supplied from a tap on the pressure side of the gate valve controlling the flow
into the pipeline extension. In a new system, application of chlorine may be
made at the pumping station, the elevated tank, the standpipe or the reservoir.
When properly cleaned first, these units are thus chlorinated adequately.
   B.   Water from the existing distribution system or other source of supply
shall be controlled so as to flow slowly into the newly laid pipeline during
the application of chlorine. The rate of chlorine mixture flow shall be in such
proportion to the rate of water entering the pipe that the chlorine applied to
the water entering the newly laid pipe shall be at least forty (40) to fifty
(50) ppm, or enough to meet the requirements during the retention period. A
convenient method of determining the rate of flow of line full of water and
measure the rate of discharge at a hydrant with a Pitot tube. Great flexibility
is made possible by providing a series of orifices to give good gauge readings
at high and low flows.
   C.   Valves shall be manipulated so that the strong chlorine solution in the
line being treated will not flow back into the line supplying the water.
   D.   Treated water shall be retained in the pipe long enough to destroy all
spore forming bacteria. This retention period should be at least twenty four
(24) hours. After the chlorine treated water has been retained for the required
time, the chlorine residual at the pipe extremities and at other representative
points should be at least ten (10) ppm.
   E.   In the process of chlorinating newly laid pipe, all valves or other
appurtenances shall be operated while the pipeline is filled with the
chlorinating agent. (2016 Code)
14-6-9: FINAL FLUSHING AND TESTING:
   A.   Following chlorination, all treated water shall be thoroughly flushed
from the newly laid pipeline at its extremities until the replacement water,
throughout its length, shall, upon test, be approved as safe water by the
department of public works. This quality of water delivered by the new main
should continue for a period of at least two (2) full days as demonstrated by
laboratory examination of samples taken from a tap located and installed in
such a way as to prevent outside contamination. Samples should never be taken
from an unsterilized hose or from a fire hydrant because such samples seldom
meet current bacteriological standards.
   B.   Should the initial treatment fail to result in the conditions
specified, the chlorination procedure shall be repeated until such results are
obtained.
   C.   Three-fourths inch (3/4") bronze corporation cocks shall be installed
in all water mains at intervals not exceeding one thousand feet (1,000').
   D.   The contractor must notify the engineering department at least twenty
four (24) hours in advance to arrange for appropriate pressure testing and
water samplings. The contractor is to provide the engineering department with
sampling bottles at the time of sampling. All samples will be sent to a state
of Illinois approved testing lab for analysis. (2016 Code)
14-6-10: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE REGULATIONS:
   A.   Water main design and construction shall in all respects be in accord
with the regulations of the bureau of public water supply, environmental
protection agency, state of Illinois. No construction shall commence until a
copy of a permit from this agency is filed with the village or that the village
received verification from this agency that a permit has been issued.
   B.   All water mains must be constructed according to the rules and
regulations of the Illinois department of public health regarding the
protection of water mains, water service lines and appurtenances from
contamination. (2016 Code)
CHAPTER 7
SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM
SECTION:
14-7-1: General Requirements
14-7-2: Design
14-7-3: Allowable Materials
14-7-4: Construction Requirements
14-7-5: Inspections And Tests
14-7-6: Sewer Services
14-7-1: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Except as otherwise provided herein, no residential, commercial or
industrial subdivision or development within the corporate limits of the
village shall be approved unless it is served by sanitary sewers connected to
the village sewer system.
   B.   All sanitary sewers which are installed in the public ways or in
easements serving a central system shall be dedicated to the village. (2016
Code)
14-7-2: DESIGN:
   A.   Sewer mains shall be designed according to the "Standard Specifications
For Water And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois" or according to "Recommended
Standards For Sewage Works". The more stringent requirements of either shall
apply. Sewer mains shall be of adequate size to serve the entire development
proposed and, except as otherwise approved by the village engineer, shall be
installed in the street right of way or in an easement adjacent thereto. In no
case shall mains be installed within ten feet (10') of a building. The minimum
size of mains shall be eight inch (8") internal diameter. Manholes shall be
installed not more than four hundred feet (400') apart for sewers fifteen
inches (15") in diameter or less, and five hundred feet (500') for sewers
eighteen inches (18") to thirty inches (30") in diameter.
   B.   Before commencing the sewer layout, the developer shall confer with the
village to determine the required size and grades for any trunk sewers
traversing the subdivision to fit the village's available or proposed
capacities required for existing or proposed developments both upstream and
downstream. Construction required to accommodate the subdivision or development
shall be submitted as part of the engineering plans. Sanitary sewers shall be
extended to the edge of the development along public rights of way and at other
points indicated by the village engineer.
   C.   All sanitary sewers shall be constructed in accord with the provisions
of division II and division III of the "Standard Specifications For Water And
Sewer Main Construction In Illinois", 1967, as modified and/or more
specifically defined herein. In case of conflict, the provisions of the
following subsections shall apply.
   D.   For pipe depths less than three feet (3'), pipe shall be case iron,
ductile iron or thick walled PVC, or vitrified clay of ACP in a concrete cradle
or encased in concrete.
   E.   Type 2 bedding, consisting of at least four inches (4") of clean,
uniformly graded granular aggregate CA11 or CA13, shall be furnished and placed
across the trench bottom under all sewer pipe, except ductile iron, and shall
completely cover the pipe to a point six inches (6") over the top of the sewer
pipe. Material shall be placed and formed as described in ASTM specification
C12-64.
   F.   Sanitary sewer service laterals of a minimum of four inches (4")
internal diameter shall be provided for each lot, parcel or tract prior to the
construction of street pavements. Services shall extend to the property line.
Service connection shall consist of one-eighth (1/8) sewer pipe bend set in the
bell of the eye or tee and the necessary lengths of pipe.
   G.   1. If a lift station is part of the engineering design, it shall be
shown in plan elevation. Specifications for said lift station shall be
submitted with engineering plans. The lift station shall be of the dry well or
wet well type, and shall conform in all respects to the standards established
by the state of Illinois environmental protection agency and MSD. However,
every reasonable effort shall be made to avoid a lift station in engineering
design.
      2.   A separate source of power shall be furnished to each sewerage lift
station. This shall be from another electrical source provided by a separately
powered engine. Engine, enclosure and mounting shall be subject to approval by
the village engineer. An alarm shall be installed to the village master panel
in the event of failure at the lift station. (2016 Code)
14-7-3: ALLOWABLE MATERIALS:
   A.   Sewer Pipe:
      1.   Extra strength vitrified clay pipe (ESVCP) conforming to the
requirements of ASTM C-700.
      2.   Extra strength concrete sewer pipe (ESCSP) conforming to the
requirements of ASTM C-14 or C-76.
      3.   Cast iron main conforming to the requirements of ASA A21.11 and
A21.6, class 150.
      4.   Ductile iron main shall conform to AWWA specification C151-65.
      5.   Thick walled PVC pipe shall conform to the requirements of ASTM D-
224.1 or D-3034, SDR 35. (SDR, or standard dimension ratio, is the ratio of the
pipe OD to the minimum wall thickness (SDR = D/t). The structural stability and
supporting strength of the pipe decrease with the increase of SDR.) The pipe
shall not exceed twenty feet (20') in laying length. Installation and selection
of bedding material shall conform to the requirements of ASTM specification D-
2321.
